TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Homes: Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and senators assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia points out that aged and disabled people who require accommodation and support in nursing homes are entitled to the highest possible standard and quality of nursing care.

We, the petitioners, request the Government to ensure that provision of funds for nursing homes in Victoria is sustained at least at a level sufficient to maintain the high standard of care now available in nursing homes in this State.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: Deregulation and Privatisation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and senators, in the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The humble petitioners of the undersigned citizens of Australia wish to express their opposition to the privatization and de-regulation of the Australian telecommunications system and to the proposed implementation of timed local calls and directory assistance charging.
Your petitioners pray that the Australian Government will take the necessary action to prevent any such privatization, de-regulation, timed local calls, and directory assistance charging.
And we, your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Elector-Initiated Referenda
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:

that while having some reservations on individual aspects of the Constitutional Initiative (Electors Initiative) 1987 your petitioners wish to express our strong support for the concept of people's democracy implied in that Bill.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled will

Refer the above mentioned Bill to an appropriate Parliamentary Committee and will examine the operation of direct democracy procedures overseas with the intention of passing legislation granting such facilities to your petitioners during the Bicentennial year.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Commercial Sponsorship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate and the Commonwealth Parliament assembled
The petition of these residents of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth
that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation provides the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia with the only nation-wide independent radio and television service
that the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation must be preserved in the interests of the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia
that the introduction of commercial sponsorship or any form of advertising material from commercial sources would destroy the independence of the Corporation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Honourable Senators will oppose the introduction of any form of sponsorship or advertising material from commercial sources into the programmes of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: STATE GOVERNMENT INSURANCE COMMISSION OF WESTERN AUSTRALIA

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Chaney, I ask: Is the Minister representing the Attorney-General aware of the requests for information made by the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) of the State Government Insurance Commission of Western Australia concerning its deals with Mr Robert Holmes a Court? Does the Minister agree that such cooperation by the State Government Insurance Commission is essential if the National Companies and Securities Commission is to carry out its role as a corporate watchdog in a situation where, so far, the market is very inadequately informed of these events? Has the Minister ascertained that the Western Australian Government will ensure that its instrumentalities cooperate fully with the investigation into the facts of this matter?

—The very short answer is that I have no information about any approach by the National Companies and Securities Commission to the Western Australian instrumentality referred to. I will seek further advice from the Attorney-General.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister agree that the matters I have raised are the responsibility of the NCSC? Will the Minister take up with the NCSC the matter of cooperation between the Western Australian Government Insurance Commission and the NCSC on this issue?

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to comments made by the New South Wales Premier, Mr Greiner, reported in yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald, that:

QUESTION.PARA: We-
the States-
are not prepared to take an unfair share of the financial burden.

Can the Minister tell the Senate whether the States or the Commonwealth have borne an unfair burden of restraint in government spending? What action can the Commonwealth take to correct any discrepancy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did read some of the statements made by Mr Greiner on Sunday on behalf of a couple of other non-Labor Premiers and one or two non-Labor Opposition Leaders. He said that the States were not prepared to take an unfair share of the financial burden. Of course, Mr Greiner's proposition is that the States should take no share at all of the financial burden and that spending for the States should be frozen in real terms. It is not surprising that Mr Greiner should choose this moment to put up such a proposition because in 1986-87 the Commonwealth's `own purpose' outlays grew by 0.3 per cent. In the same year, the State and local government sector's own purpose outlays grew by 3.4 per cent. The rate of growth in the State-local government sector was 11 times that of the Commonwealth. In the next year, 1987-88-and since the year has not finished these figures are estimates, but they are pretty precise estimates-the Commonwealth's own purpose outlays are actually falling by 2.2 per cent, that is, minus 2.2 per cent. The State and local sector's own purpose outlays are still growing by 1.6 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: It is no wonder Mr Greiner says that this would be a good time to guarantee funding to the States from the Commonwealth Budget in the same real terms. It is no wonder that he picks this time. At the end of a great spending splurge Mr Greiner says, `We'll do our bit. We won't blow out the spending splurge any more than we already have'. In 1984-85, the Commonwealth's own borrowings, net, were of the order of 3 per cent of gross domestic product. Many people thought that was too high at the time. I am sure that Senator Stone would have been one of them. However, that was three years ago. It has now reached the point where the Commonwealth's own purpose borrowings are negative. In the same period-that is, from 1984-85 to 1987-88-the State government's net public sector borrowing requirement has trebled. So on both the expenditure side and the borrowing side the major part of the adjustments which have taken place has been on the Commonwealth's own purpose Budget. It is certainly not fair that that should continue. I was asked what action the Commonwealth would take to correct any discrepancy. There is certainly a massive discrepancy. Action will be taken, but Senator Aulich will have to be patient and wait until later in the week to find out what that action will be.

Mr Greiner, of course, has a particular problem. He has $1 1/2 billion-worth of irresponsible election spending promises hanging over his head. That is his big problem-$1 1/2 billion-worth of irresponsible election spending promises. What he is trying to do now is set up an arrangement under which the blame for his fiscal irresponsibility is transferred to the Commonwealth Government. It should also be noted that Mr Peacock thinks that the proposal of the Business Council of Australia to cut $3 1/2 billion off the Commonwealth Budget was a pretty wimpish thing to put up. How Mr Peacock would cut $3 1/2 billion-plus off the Commonwealth Budget while still maintaining this extravagant demand from his State Liberal Party colleagues is a great mystery. Likewise, I notice today that Mr Howard has promised a massive reduction in taxes from a Liberal government but supports Nick Greiner's ambit claim that there should be no reductions in Commonwealth payments to the States. There is only one way in which that contradiction can be reconciled-one does not have to have a very long memory to realise what the reconciliation will be-and that is to go back to a $10 billion deficit, like Mr Howard left behind him the last time he was in government. In other words, when one looks at the discordant statements coming from various members of the Liberal Party in State and Federal parliaments, it becomes quite apparent that they are just as big a bunch of fiscal ratbags in 1988 as they were in 1982.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: STATE GOVERNMENT INSURANCE COMMISSION OF WESTERN AUSTRALIA

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I refer to the underwriting deal between the State Government Insurance Commission of Western Australia and Mr Robert Holmes a Court whereby the SGIC is reported to have guaranteed payment of $150m to Mr Holmes a Court, for convertible bonds held by his family interest in the Bell Group. Is it a fact that the current market value of these bonds is in the order of $90m? Would the Minister agree that the arrangement appears to amount to an additional price for the Bell Group shares purchased by the SGIC? If so, what implications does this have for the securities industry and in particular for the surveillance processes of that industry by the National Companies and Securities Commission?

—As I have already indicated in my answer to the first question asked by the Opposition, I have no brief on what is obviously an extremely technical matter to do with the purchase by a Western Australian State instrumentality of certain shares relating to Mr Holmes a Court's various possessions and companies. The fact is that without such information I am certainly not going to speculate and try to give an answer off the cuff. As I indicated previously, I am seeking the fullest possible answer and will provide it when I can.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. If I am to understand correctly the response just given by the Minister, he has informed the Senate that he has no brief at all on the events that have taken place in this matter which has been in the public Press now for over a week, if I recall correctly. Will the Minister therefore inform the Senate as to which of two conclusions we should draw. Does he inform us that he has not sought any information from the NCSC, through the Attorney-General's Department or, alternatively, does he intend to assure us that he is not interested in the matter?

—I am simply reporting to the Senate that if I am to aid the Senate in providing it with information which it is obviously seeking, I intend to do so with the fullest possible brief at my disposal. I will do so when that is provided.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Has the Minister seen the special report in the latest issue of the Amnesty International Australia newsletter on human rights abuses in Colombia in South America? What additional information, if any, does the Government have on the matter? Has the Government taken any actions through Foreign Affairs channels on this disturbing list of human rights abuses?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is aware of the tragically high level of human rights abuse and political violence in Colombia which has been highlighted in a report recently published by Amnesty International to which Senator Maguire refers. The report reveals a quite dramatic increase in the level of so-called disappearances and political killings in Colombia since the early 1980s. There were in fact more than 1,000 political killings during 1987. The report cites convincing evidence that many of these violations are carried out directly by the Colombian police and armed forces or by anonymous death squads controlled by the armed forces acting on their behalf. The Government is aware that as a result of the Amnesty International report a committee for human rights has been created by the Catholic Church in Colombia.

ANSWER.PARA: So far as the response of the Australian Government is concerned, we have regularly expressed our concerns over the situation. When Australia's non-resident ambassador presented his credentials on 6 April this year he raised the Australian Government's human rights concerns at the highest level. Again, Australia has made frequent representations to the Colombian authorities over specific cases of human rights abuse. In fact, 26 such representations on behalf of individuals and groups were made during 1987.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. What is the Minister's response to the claim of the Australian Mining Industry Council (AMIC) that the mining industry may be locked out of almost half of Australia? Further, is there any substance to recent claims that buffer zones are being created around World Heritage areas, especially in north Queensland?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of an AMIC study entitled Shrinking Australia-The Problem of Access to Land and I am aware of a Press conference conducted by Mr Mark Rayner, the President of the Mining Industry Council. He has claimed that the mining industry is worried that it will be locked out of almost half of Australia. The present Government is committed to developing land use decision-making processes which will enable a balance to be sustained between mining and other extractive industries, exploitative industries, and conservation. Given the contribution that the AMIC study makes, the Government welcomes it. I have to say that neither I nor the Government welcomes some of the statements that Mr Rayner has made. He has not made a positive contribution to the debate.

ANSWER.PARA: I shall give honourable senators some examples. Alcoa of Australia Ltd, which in the late 1970s was, I think, the largest producer of alumina in the world, gets its bauxite from jarrah forests in Western Australia. Those forests were certainly locked up in accordance with what AMIC considers the term to mean. That is how it got to its figures. Nonetheless, that extractive industry proceeded, and obviously proceeded successfully from Alcoa's point of view. So the idea that the access of mining companies to these areas is restricted is simply not right.

AMIC claims that 23.5 per cent of Australia is either restricted or closed. To arrive at a figure of that size, AMIC had to include all Australian urban areas and all Aboriginal lands, including those lands under claim and not necessarily granted. I think we will find within those Aboriginal areas Ranger, Weipa, Gove and a whole number of other sites where very large mining operations, even by world standards, are conducted-again giving the lie to any suggestion of a lock-up.

It is alleged that another 20 per cent of Australia is to be locked up by other single interest groups. One assumes that that means conservationists and, I suppose, some Aboriginal groups. While these groups may all have their own agendas for what they want to see happen with land use decision-making, those agendas are not necessarily the agendas of the Government. I can assure the Senate that in some cases they are not.

I make the point again, in case it is necessary, that the Government is not working on any secret hit list of heritage areas. I must confess that I have made that point a number of times, but after listening to Mr Rayner it is apparently necessary to repeat it. If the single interest group in this case is the mining lobby, it certainly has plans for a whole lot of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —They want to create a few jobs.
—And will have our assistance in doing so. As Senator Boswell well knows, I recently spent some time in north Queensland creating jobs.
—I was there with you.

—The honourable senator was, and his presence was welcome. We were creating jobs. That is what the $75m package was all about. I am glad I have had the opportunity to repeat just how good a package it was. However, the need to maintain ecological processes and life support systems is as important to human welfare as is access to each and every mineral find. Mr Rayner's inflammatory claims about World Heritage listing processes were as unproductive as some of those earlier claims to which I referred. Obviously he was not aware that the wet tropics region of north Queensland was of only moderate prospectivity. Furthermore, the only two people who so far have come forward with suggestions for mines have received indications that, even though those mines are within the World Heritage area, they can proceed. The claims that the World Heritage area is therefore absolutely locked up are also untrue; they have no basis in fact.

ANSWER.PARA: Equally ridiculous in past weeks, as Senator Devereux has said, is the question of buffer zones. One of Senator Boswell's colleagues-I forget his name; he is very forgettable, but he is a State member from north Queensland-came out with another statement on buffer zones. He suggested that because some areas of north Queensland were being listing on the National Estate this meant that we were building buffer zones around the World Heritage areas. That is absolute nonsense. A property being registered by the Australian Heritage Commission does not and cannot bind local government, State governments or private landholders. It places a restriction only on the Commonwealth and that restriction is to consider the heritage values before proceeding with development. It does not even bar them.

Those claims by Mr Rayner, repeated by that member from north Queensland, are further examples of a process of misinformation which has gone on and on about World Heritage areas. I hope that people will get sick of saying it, just as I get sick of answering it. I hope that when we look at the next 200 years we will try to do a little better in managing our environment than we have done in the last 200 years, during which the mining industry and a whole lot of other industries have done irreparable damage in many cases. All this Government is about is ensuring that we get land use decisions that will prevent that damage occurring in the future.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: STATE GOVERNMENT INSURANCE COMMISSION OF WESTERN AUSTRALIA

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. I refer to the sale by Mr Holmes a Court of his controlling stake in Bell Group, 19.9 per cent to the Western Australian State Government Insurance Commission and 19.9 per cent to Bond Corporation. Does the Minister agree that provisions of the take- over laws which come into effect upon the sale of 20 per cent are designed principally to protect the interests of small shareholders? Does the Minister further agree that the sale of the two parcels of shares each fractionally under the limit is on its face designed to avoid such provisions and that small shareholders have therefore suffered by not being offered the same price? What is the Minister's attitude to a government instrumentality being a party to such an avoidance of the law to the disadvantage of small shareholders?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already indicated that the Government is concerned that the provisions, and indeed the spirit, of the legislation controlling the acquisition of shareholdings be adhered to. In that respect it is true that the provisions are drawn up in a way which is designed to protect the interests of smaller shareholders, and in particular there are some artificialities which can be devised along the lines pointed to by Senator Hill which may give shareholders not participating in a particular acquisition of whatever it may be-19.9 per cent-the opportunity to share in a particular attractive proposition. But in that respect the National Companies and Securities Commission, as I understand it-I have repeated this several times and do not see the point of being peppered with questions on it--

—Well, if honourable senators want real information, it would be better done on the basis of a complete brief but, as we all know, the National Companies and Securities Commission has a role. As I recall from Press reports, it has asked for a cooling down period, in which case, as I recall, it has been asked that there be no change in the directors on the board and so on, in order to try to come to an arrangement which may be more commercially acceptable to other shareholders.

ANSWER.PARA: In that situation we should allow the National Companies and Securities Commission to undertake the sorts of inquiries it is undertaking. In regard to the particular question relating to 20 per cent-that is, under section 11 of the Act, as I recall-the National Companies and Securities Commission obviously would need to look at that. But there are other provisions in the legislation-I think in section 60-which also give a role to the Commission. As I say, it may be that, as the cooling off period that the Commission asks for takes place, some arrangement will emerge which clearly protects the interests of other shareholders. I am awaiting a full brief, which I will make available as soon as I can.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. What I am asking, which does not require a specific brief, is what the Minister's attitude is to government instrumentalities using what he refers to as artificialities in these circumstances to the disadvantage of small shareholders.

—I did not say that in this instance the purchase by the Bond Corporation or by the State government instrumentality could be characterised that way. I said simply that, where artificialities can be employed, obviously we have proper cause for concern. I am confident that the National Companies and Securities Commission will endeavour to carry into effect the will of the Parliament in relation to those matters. I have already indicated the sections, sections 11 and 60, which the Parliament has incorporated in the legislation to enable the National Companies and Securities Commission to undertake that task. I am sure that over the next several weeks that is what it will be doing.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What action has the Government taken to protest to the Polish Government about the brutal eviction by police of striking mill workers at Nowa Huta steel mill? What action has the Government taken in protesting to the Polish Government about the arrest of Solidarity leaders in Poland over recent weeks? Is it not a fact that the action of the Polish Government in making the acceptance of a wage rise conditional upon the workers abandoning Solidarity is a contravention of the International Labour Organisation (ILO) convention of freedom of association and deserves the condemnation of this Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have a brief as to the actual representations that we have made, if any, in the last few days in response to the very recent events to which Senator Harradine refers. We will respond to developments as they occur. I will certainly let him know, and let the Senate know, in a supplementary answer at an appropriate stage what action we have taken. I can say a number of things about the situation: in the first place, we urge the Polish authorities to accord to workers rights to which they are manifestly entitled under ILO conventions and other international treaties to which Poland is a party. We have no indication that troops are likely to be used in the present circumstances, but we very much deplore the reports of excessive force by riot police. We are deeply concerned by reports that workers have been seriously injured in recent police action against striking workers, who in some cases have been beaten unconscious.

ANSWER.PARA: I can say also on behalf of the Foreign Minister that we call more generally on the Polish authorities not to step back from the process of liberalisation of Polish society on which the Polish Government, up to this point anyway, apparently had been embarked. It is clear that the process of economic reform cannot proceed independently of the political and institutional reforms that are required in Poland. That perception, and our expression of that perception, will govern any more specific response we make to what is manifestly the very unhappy situation that is developing in that country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer to the 5,000-strong rally of textile, clothing and footwear (TCF) industry workers outside Parliament House today claiming that the Minister and his Government have welshed on a deal with the TCF industries and their employees. The Minister will recall an answer to me in this chamber on 18 April when he claimed that there was a worthwhile process of consultation occurring between government, industry and unions on tariff cuts. I ask the Minister: Is not the presence of such a large TCF rally evidence that the Minister's consultative process has broken down, particularly considering that the rally follows an admission by the Minister that there was also a communications gap between the Government and the Australian Manufacturing Council on the issue of consultation? How many more demonstrations by unionists are needed and how much more evidence that business is delaying investment plans is needed before he will end the damaging uncertainty created by Government-inspired speculation about tariff cuts?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I attended the rally outside. I did not count for myself, so I do not know whether there were 5,000 there or not.
—A large crowd.

—It was a significant crowd, yes. To return to the honourable senator's question, this matter is like an answer I gave Senator Haines a week or two ago: one can summon spirits from the vasty deep on these issues, and that has been done in a sense. That does not prevent the process of dialogue to which Senator Lewis referred in his question. Senator Lewis's question contained a number of emotive phrases, if I can so describe them. He referred to the Government `welshing on a deal'. First of all, let me say to the honourable senator that in matters of policy concerning these issues the Government does not make deals; it gives undertakings sometimes, and we gave undertakings--
—And then welshes on them.

—If Senator Baume will just listen to the rest of the answer he may be further enlightened than he is at the moment. The Government certainly gave undertakings about continuity and predictability for the development, hopefully, of the textile, clothing and footwear industry. We gave undertakings about a safety net provision. None of those undertakings will be broken by this Government. But the textile, clothing and footwear plan, as it was discussed in 1986, will be subject to a wide range of considerations in 1988 and beyond which will affect the environment in which the plan was projected from 1986. I think it is important that an industry which has a particular relationship with protection for manufacturing generally should maintain that relationship and should not be a beneficiary of changes to other industries while it is excluded from any possible change.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Lewis said in his question that on 18 April I referred to a worthwhile process of consultation. That consultation has not been concluded, and it is obvious from the demonstration here today that there is not agreement about all aspects of that consultation. Let me say that it will continue. It is not concluded and no decision has been made by the Government on this issue of tariff changes to the textile, clothing and footwear plan; nor has a decision been made by the Government on the question of tariff changes generally. A very widespread process of consultation has been embarked on by the Government through the Manufacturing Council, and let me say that the environment for change is vastly different from what it was two, three, four or five years ago. The Government will not be deterred from making the changes which it feels to be appropriate in respect of these matters, but the changes will be made in a process of consultation.

The honourable senator's reference to the communications gap, to which I referred when the Manufacturing Council representatives met with the Government, is a matter on which I have already answered a question from the honourable senator. It is, if I might say so without detriment to the profession we both once followed, lawyers' `sleigh' of hand to intrude that particular reference into this question.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is pronounced sleight of hand.

—I am sorry. I am corrected by the Leader of the Opposition, who has found his voice again. It is lawyers' sleight of hand to put that matter into this question, because I said there was a communications gap about that meeting and the arrangements for that meeting. That has nothing to do with the question of whether there is a communications gap between the Government and a wide range of interests which are concerned about tariff changes. Since the honourable senator has raised that matter, I might say that, following that meeting with the Manufacturing Council, a very good piece of work was done by that Council which has been immensely helpful in facilitating possible change.

ANSWER.PARA: The final part of the honourable senator's question was about businesses delaying investments because of speculation about tariff cuts. Looking at the import figures, as I do on a fairly regular basis, I do not think that is happening at all. The honourable senator has referred to an article in the Daily Commercial News-a journal which we both read avidly-which dealt with the question of delays in investment caused by discussion about tariff cuts. I appreciate that one can never make changes to anything without there being some speculation, concern and anxiety. If one looks at the figures of what is actually happening in terms of investment, I do not think one can really draw that conclusion. I think I have covered all of the points that the honourable senator has raised.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does not the Minister understand that the answer he has just given will create further speculation about this area? We have now had the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, Mr Dawkins and the Minister continuing the speculation that is going on in the industry. The question that I am putting to the Minister is: When is this Government going to bring an end to this speculation? Must we wait right throughout the whole consultative process or must we wait until after the May statement before we ultimately find out what is going to happen with regard to tariff protection for Australian industry?

—I suppose the honourable senator and I start from a totally different point on this issue. The honourable senator and I are like two Edinburgh housewives arguing from different premises. The honourable senator starts from the point of view that speculation or discussion about issues is bad. I start from the point of view that it is probably good because people ought to have their minds concentrated on issues. I think it is a very good thing if that happens. The honourable senator asked me how long these speculators, these anxious people, will have to wait. Try 24 May.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer the Minister to radio news reports that a number of Kanaks charged with offences following the recent violent events in New Caledonia have been flown to Paris by French military aircraft to stand trial. What is the Government's response to this reported development in the light of the very sensitive and distressing situation currently prevailing in New Caledonia? Does the Government expect any improvement in the situation in the light of President Mitterrand's victory in the presidential election?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has obviously heard the reports to which Senator Schacht refers about the flying back for trial of the FLNKS members in question. We are not in a position at this stage, however, to confirm the details of that. In any case, I have to say that internal judicial processes are a matter for the French Government to determine within the boundaries of its domestic jurisdiction. I do not think it would be appropriate for an Australian Minister to comment further on that point.

ANSWER.PARA: On the more general issue, let me begin by congratulating, on behalf of the Australian Government, President Mitterrand on his re-election as President of France. He now has the distinction of being the first President of the Fifth French Republic to be elected by universal suffrage for a second term. The strength of the Mitterrand victory signals French support, of course, for policies of a fraternal democratic socialist party, which we very much welcome in this country. In this respect, the Australian Government anticipates and would very much welcome efforts by the new Mitterrand Government to revive the process of conciliation and dialogue in New Caledonia in the way that was foreshadowed by President Mitterrand during the campaign and, indeed, in statements made immediately afterwards. Certainly, the very complex, tense and polarised situation in New Caledonia is one of the most important issues that the recently re-elected President Mitterrand and his new Government will need to address. I note the encouraging sign in this respect that the re-election has been cautiously welcomed by the FLNKS, which has indicated it will accordingly scale down its campaign of disruption.

So far as the Australian Government is concerned, we look forward very much to working constructively with President Mitterrand and the new French Government to enhance the security and well-being of the South Pacific region, particularly in relation to New Caledonia where Australia and the other South Pacific Forum countries share President Mitterrand's very obvious and very well articulated desire to see an end to the division and turbulence that have characterised the territory.

One of the things that President Mitterrand has constantly done is draw attention to the evident social and economic inequalities in New Caledonia which have manifestly contributed a great deal to the present divisive situation. We certainly wish him well in endeavouring to address these inequalities and we look forward to a return to meaningful dialogue between all parties, which we hope, in turn, will lead to progress toward a viable long term political situation which is acceptable to all political parties and all interests in New Caledonia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister for Justice recall my asking him a question on 28 April about the liability of Australian World War II bomber crews for prosecution under the War Crimes Amendment Bill and in particular my focusing his thoughts by referring specifically to the devastating bombing raid in February 1945 on the defenceless city of Dresden? Does the Minister recall saying that Australian airmen would not be liable for prosecution, and buttressing this statement by pointing out that they had been liable for prosecution for 33 years under the War Crimes Act 1945, and the fact that none had been prosecuted in those 33 years was clear evidence that they had nothing to fear from the War Crimes Amendment Bill? Did the Minister make a statement later that day confessing that he had misled the Senate, that Australians had never been liable under the War Crimes Act 1945, and therefore his argument had no foundation? Will the Minister now make the situation completely clear by confirming that Australian airmen-to use the specific example that I have quoted-who, under orders, bombed Dresden in February 1945 might be liable for prosecution under the War Crimes Amendment Bill as it stands?

—I did make a statement to the senator, on the eve of our getting up at the end of the last week of sittings, indicating that the War Crimes Amendment Bill, as it is presently drafted, would create a new situation for Australian ex-servicemen who had served in the various theatres of the Second World War. In relation to the question of the fire bombing of Dresden to which Senator Hamer refers, the basis for my remarks that Australian pilots and aircrew involved in those particular bombing raids would not be subject to prosecution under the War Crimes Amendment Bill if it were enacted rested on the fact that during the trials of war criminals that took place after the Second World War that particular matter was specifically considered by the tribunals concerned and a decision was made that those particular types of bombings did not fall within the categories of war crimes which were of concern to those tribunals. Obviously, I do not have those cases before me, but I can certainly provide Senator Hamer with one particular decision that I recall-I think it was of the United States Military Tribunal-to that effect.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I think the Minister is referring to the Nuremberg Charter. Does the Minister not agree that this refers to war crimes as acts which are reckless or wanton or which are not justified by military necessity? Are not these conditions disjunctive? In view of the importance of this issue to many gallant Australian ex-serviceman, I am sure that the Minister would have asked his advisers the obvious questions to check that the answer was credible before he gave his earlier answer to this question. I now ask him: What answer did he receive from his advisers to his question on the military necessity for the bombing of Dresden in February 1945?
—As I recall it, the answer I was given by my advisers was to point to the case to which I have referred Senator Hamer. I will make that case available to him.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to ask a question of the chairperson of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade which relates not to the substance of the Committee's inquiry but only to procedural matters.

QUESTION.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the chairperson of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade and relates to the current inquiry on the adequacy of current contingency planning by Federal and State authorities to deal with the accidental release of ionising radiation from visiting nuclear powered or nuclear armed vessels in Australian waters and ports. I refer to the fact that community groups and individuals invited to testify before the Committee have been given only two working days notice to appear at the inquiry tomorrow. Given that for the last 18 months these community groups have had no indication that they would be called to speak at the hearings, and indeed, if anything, have received quite the opposite impression, I ask the chairperson whether it is reasonable to allow them such short notice, given that they need time to update their 18-month-old submissions and to study transcripts of hearings to date. Can Senator Maguire clarify the impression I have been given that if such groups or individuals cannot appear tomorrow, they will not be given another opportunity to do so? Can the Committee undertake that, in the true spirit of inquiry, groups and individuals who have made submissions will be provided with a list of alternative dates with more notice being given to them?
—I call Senator Maguire if he is prepared to answer that statement.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I can advise that we did receive a letter from Senator Vallentine last week in con- nection with our inquiry into the safety of nuclear armed and nuclear powered ships coming into Australian ports. On 29 April, the Committee decided to hear Senator Vallentine and other witnesses tomorrow-that is, 11 May. I have been advised that four different witnesses and groups have made arrangements and will be attending the hearing tomorrow.

ANSWER.PARA: I have looked at standing order 98a (c) and I note that I am able to answer this question only on behalf of the Committee as a whole. I can only say that there has been no formal business meeting of the Committee since the receipt of Senator Vallentine's letter and, therefore, no decision has been made regarding her letter or the request to appear at a different time. I expect the Committee to consider Senator Vallentine's letter at its next business meeting. Obviously, the decision is one for the Committee to take rather than me as Chairman.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to the many Press releases on the proposal that Russian fishing vessels be allowed to exploit Australian fishing resources within the 200-mile fishing zone. Does the Minister realise the significant contribution of the Australian fishing industry to our export earnings and employment? Is he aware of the potential of Australia's fishing resources to acquire more export income and employment for many more thousands of Australians? As the third ranking member of the Government, is the Minister prepared to meet a deputation from the fishing industry to discuss ways in which the industry can develop its technology to capitalise on the abundant deep water fishing resources, or is the Minister content to leave the development of this Australian resource to foreign communist powers?
—This question is appropriately a matter for the Minister responsible for primary industry.
—No, it is not. I am asking about industry. It is about how to catch fish.

—I see. The question is primarily a matter for the Minister responsible for primary industry. But having said that, let me say that I am aware that the Commonwealth Department, in conjunction with State departments, has plans for various sectors of the fishing industry, whether it be the northern prawn fishing industry or the southern Tasmanian tuna fishing industry. There are plans in place which are subject to negotiation between State and Federal governments. Those negotiations and plans have been there for a considerable time. The Commonwealth Government does take a very real interest in the development of the fishing industry in this country. Senator Boswell asked me whether I was content to leave these matters to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Of course I am content to leave--
—No, I did not ask you that. I asked whether you would meet a deputation and discuss it.

—That is what I understood Senator Boswell to be saying. The answer is that I am very content to leave these matters to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy because I think that he is one of the best Ministers for primary industries that this country has ever had. That is widely recognised in almost all circles in Australia, except perhaps the more troglodytic section of the National Party to which Senator Boswell belongs. I have taken some interest in the fishing industry in terms of the importation and building of fishing vessels and particularly the replacement of imports by the Australian fishing industry and the development of export markets. I have taken quite a keen interest in many of those matters. I will continue to do so. Whether there is point in my meeting a deputation is not a matter appropriately to be discussed in the Senate. If a deputation wishes to meet with me about these matters, I think the most courteous course would be for those concerned to write to me seeking an appointment and telling me what it is they want to discuss. If they do that, I will respond. I do not either receive or answer invitations at Question Time in the Senate.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the Press release of the Leader of the Opposition, issued this afternoon, on coalition tax policy. I ask: What arguments has Mr Howard ignored in reaching this latest position on tax policy? What would be the implications for the Australian economy if the changes to base-broadening measures proposed in the Press release were to be implemented? Finally, will the Government consider implementing any of the proposals contained in the aforementioned statement?

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. Senator McKiernan has asked three questions. Mr President, I put it to you that certainly the first and the last of those questions are entirely out of order. In particular, the first question, which relates to what arguments Mr Howard may have used or may have ignored, is not within the competence of the Minister. It is within neither his knowledge nor his competence. It calls for a series of tendentious conclusions to be reached by the Minister. Clearly, they are not part of his portfolio responsibility.
—I agree that the first part of the question was out of order. I ask Senator Walsh to answer the second and third parts of the question as they relate to areas within his portfolio.

—I have seen the Press release of the Opposition Leader on coalition tax policy, and a remarkable document it is-although those who have studied the twists and turns up blind alleys of the coalition over the last few months might not think that it is all that remarkable. Essentially what it promises to do is reduce taxation. It proposes to do that by abolishing the capital gains tax, except for some Clayton's capital gains tax that ceases to apply after five years-so Mr Elliott has had his way on that. The coalition Opposition here is a proxy for Mr Elliott, who is the real determiner of tax policy. Although it does not use the word, the Press release goes on to speak in glowing terms of the concept of incentivation-a term coined about 15 months ago by the Opposition, which has decided not to resurrect that unfortunate and misbegotten word. The Press release also says that the coalition will abolish the existing fringe benefits tax. It goes on to say that there will be no need to keep records and that log books or unnecessary records will need to be maintained for such items. Of course, what that effectively means is that there will be no substantiation; fringe benefits taxes will notionally be taxed in the hands of employees, but there will be no substantiation. The cost to revenue of that would almost certainly be in excess of $1 billion. The direct cost to revenue of the abolition of the capital gains tax may, at this stage, not be more than $100m or so, although we have yet to get a full year's capital gains tax collection figures. However, the significance of the existing capital gains tax is not the amount of money it explicitly raises; it is the fact that it puts a floor under the whole income tax system. It closes off the loopholes that were outrageously and disgracefully rorted by a wide variety of people, but principally by senior members of the Liberal Party, when John Howard was Treasurer. Of course, that is why they want to get rid of the present Government's capital gains tax policy.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. While the Minister may technically be in order in making reflections on persons outside this Parliament, it is clearly not within the purview of the Standing Orders for him to reflect in the way he has on the motives of Mr Howard in making the particular announcement in relation to that matter. One is used to this sort of abuse from this honourable senator, but there are standing order provisions about the way in which he is allowed to abuse persons. He has defied a ruling which you have previously given about this particular matter, and I would ask you to make some attempt to bring him to order, to ask him to confine himself to those things which are within the Standing Orders and to try, if it is actually physically possible for him, not to be some sort of abusive grub.
—Order! I remind Senator Walsh to observe the Standing Orders.
—Even Elliott's latest proxy did not suggest that I had not been observing the Standing Orders, Mr President. He just does not like the things I am saying.
—Order!

—Mr President, let me take the point of order. I draw your attention to standing order 418, which says that all imputations of improper motives shall be considered highly disorderly. It is quite clear that Senator Walsh was in the process of making an imputation about the reasons why the Leader of the Opposition had said certain things in his Press release. Senator Walsh was drawing a conclusion, and the conclusion contained a most improper imputation. That was the point of the objection. It is not a question of asking Senator Walsh to come to order; with all due respect, it is a question of ruling him out of order and requiring him to stay within the Standing Orders.
—Order! Senator Walsh made a clear imputation of improper motives and I would ask him to withdraw it.

—Very well, Mr President, I withdraw it. I freely recognise, of course, that it is in conflict with the Standing Orders to impute improper motives. To impute improper conduct is presumably okay, but to impute improper motives is not. The general thrust of the Press statement released by the Opposition Leader today is to narrow the income tax base without-and the release is quite explicit on this-offering any mechanism to offset the very large loss of revenue that that would entail. Indeed it explicitly rejects any form of broad-based consumption tax, value added tax or anything like that-I could quote from it but it is explicit on that point-and in doing that it of course disregards all the arguments in favour of, in particular, the broad-based consumption tax suggested by the then Mr Stone on 2 July 1985, in an interview the transcript of which I now table, as a replacement for the present wholesale sales tax.

—I refer the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories to an answer he gave earlier in Question Time to Senator Devereux in respect of a statement made by the President of the Australian Mining Industry Council, Mark Rayner. In that answer the Minister stated that he would ensure-I think this is a fair precis-that the devastation caused by mining, and I think he added `other industries', over the past 200 years would not be repeated. As our major mining and export industries have been the gold, silver, lead, copper, coal and iron ore industries, will the Minister specifically advise of Australian mainland areas devastated by the mining industry over the past 200 years, and which of these industries he would not have allowed, in retrospect, had he been the Minister responsible?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not a bad question, and I take some pleasure in answering it. First off, I did say originally that I was concerned about the damage to the environment that had been done over the past 200 years.
—Devastation.

—Whatever it was, I said we ought to make sure that it does not occur in the next 200 years. I stand by that statement. As to the mining operations I was referring to, I was referring not only to mining--
—You said mining.

—I do not know how much Senator Parer has travelled but if he were to go to Kakadu, one of our great natural environments, and have a look at what occurred with the uranium mining that took place there in the 1950s and the damage that was done along the headwaters of the South Alligator River, some of which has been repaired only in the last few years and some of which still remains to be repaired, he would see some classic examples of what happens when mining goes ahead in a totally unregulated way.
—Are you going to get rid of all the buffaloes that are doing the damage too?

—I was appalled by what I saw there. I am often more than appalled by Senator Walters, as well, but I will try to stick to the question. If one looks at Rum Jungle, even with the massive amounts of money spent on repairing that, one still sees in the river area terrible damage that no amount of money can repair. Examples of that sort occur all around Australia. I am surprised that Senator Parer is not aware of them.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Further to the Minister's recent reply to Senator Cooney concerning arrests in Singapore, I have received a number of questions from constituents regarding recent developments in Singapore particularly relevant to these people. Does the Minister have any further information about developments in the case and the Australian Government's response to it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In reply to a question by Senator Cooney on 29 April on recent arrests in Singapore, I did foreshadow that representations would be made to the Singapore Government expressing the Australian Government's concern at the arbitrary character of these Internal Security Act detentions. I am certainly aware of the widespread concern in the community and parliament that these arrests have caused. The representations to which I have referred will be made this afternoon when the Singapore High Commissioner is called to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to hear the Government's views. However, the pace of recent developments in Singapore requires that some further comment be made publicly at this stage.

ANSWER.PARA: On 28 April the Singapore Government stated that the eight detainees who had previously been arrested in 1987 for their role in an alleged conspiracy had now retracted their accusations of mistreatment. The Singapore authorities then claimed that these retractions removed the need for a commission of inquiry to review the 1987 arrests and the Singapore Government charges of a Marxist conspiracy. On 6 May a former Solicitor-General, who was representing two of the detainees, was also arrested under the Internal Security Act and another of the 1987 detainees was detained on 8 May.

The Australian Government's views on human rights issues are well known. They have been clearly stated whenever the occasion has warranted. We continue to regard the use of the Internal Security Act in Singapore as a matter of considerable concern. The Government is particularly disappointed that the foreshadowed commission of inquiry will not now take place. Our own Australian experience has shown the value of independent judicial reviews of controversial and complex issues. In addition to expressing the Government's concerns and regret over the detentions, our representations will accordingly register our disappointment that the commission of inquiry will not now take place.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 April 1988, Senator Chaney asked me a question about the submarine construction project in South Australia. In my reply on that day I mentioned that there was some hope of resolution of the matter and that I would not wish to prejudice that resolution by fixing a two-week deadline. I also undertook to provide Senator Chaney with additional information as it came to hand. The Minister for Industrial Relations has provided the following additional information:

ANSWER.PARA: The position which the Minister put to the South Australian unions has not changed-that is, that unless there is an early and satisfactory resolution to the outstanding matters the Government will give serious consideration to the continuance of the project in South Australia.
I did not put to the South Australian unions that consideration to relocate the project would be predicted on resolution of disputes within four weeks.
Since my discussions with relevant parties in Adelaide on 13 April the following has occurred:

(a) Resolution of the building and construction phase dispute. A building and construction site agreement has been signed by employers and all unions. All bans have been lifted. Work is proceeding without disruption.

(b) The consultative framework established at the meeting with unions on the assembly phase of the project has been completed. Many unions have now concluded that their claim for a presence on site during the phase was unwarranted.

(c) In accordance with the agreement reached the matter of union representation during the assembly phase has now been referred to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in the form of a dispute notification by the AMWU.
An early hearing of the matter by Deputy President Keogh is expected.

The attitude of the parties now appears to be more positive and the Government is hopeful that the matter of union representation during the assembly phase will be amicably resolved, as was the building and construction site agreement.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 April Senator Bishop asked me a question in my capacity as Leader of the Government in the Senate, namely, whether I would confirm or deny that the Government was considering the introduction of a common identifying number, a CIN number, by whatever name, which involved external uses beyond the Australian Taxation Office and whether it contemplated the use of an external power requiring legislation. I undertook to provide an answer to that question. Officials of the Australian Taxation Office are currently examining ways to improve the effectiveness of the tax file numbering system so that it can play a greater role in the fight against tax evasion. I cannot pre-empt the outcome of this review but I can assure the honourable senator that the Government is committed to the protection of civil liberties and acknowledges the need for effective protection of personal privacy in relation to data held by government agencies.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Newman asked me a question some weeks ago about certain investigations relating particularly to allegations by Dr Menon as to health insurance fraud. On 7 December 1987 Dr Blewett wrote to the Minister for Justice requesting that the Australian Federal Police (AFP) interview Dr Menon and obtain details of cases from him which allegedly indicated widespread internal fraud within the Health Insurance Commission (HIC). On the same day I requested the AFP to investigate the allegations. I am informed that on 10 December 1987 Dr Menon was interviewed by AFP officers. He produced copies of documents which related to his allegations. He also undertook to supply a comprehensive list of doctors who had reported the receipt of suspected bogus cheques to him. There was insufficient evidence available at that time to support his allegations.

ANSWER.PARA: Dr Menon referred the AFP to a doctor in Sydney who claimed knowledge of a cheque fraud. The documents involved were given to the AFP. Subsequent inquiries with the HIC revealed that this case was the result of a computer error. The HIC advised that the error had been rectified. Dr Menon provided copies of five cheques, three dated October 1987, one dated November 1987 and one dated February 1988, to the AFP which he alleged were fraudulently issued.

On 15 April the AFP wrote to the manager of the HIC in Sydney requesting assistance in establishing the reasons for issuing those cheques. The HIC advised on 29 April that four of the cheques in question were issued due to a computer error and one due to a clerical error by the claiming doctor. Since Dr Menon has not yet provided the AFP with a comprehensive list of doctors who have allegedly received bogus cheques, the AFP will not at this stage be making inquiries.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time today Senator Hamer revived his questions of previous weeks which implied that Australian bomber crews involved in the fire bombing of Dresden, as he put it, were engaged in activity which might be characterised as a war crime. I said that I had received advice that that was not a correct characterisation of that tragic part of the operations involved in the Second World War. When he further asked me about any advice I had received to that effect I pointed to my memory of a particular case which my advisers had drawn to my attention. That case, I am now able to say, was In re Ohlendorf and Others, known colloquially as the Einstazgruppen trial, before the United States Military Tribunal at Nuremberg, dated 10 April 1948. The accused were officers in one or more branches of the German Security Service, the SS, the SD or the Gestapo. I will not go into the allegations against them, but by way of defence the question was raised as to the legality of aerial bombardment of towns and cities. I will quote from the judgment. It will take some time, Mr President, but I hope that, given the seriousness of the charge against Australian ex-servicemen that has been made by Senator Hamer, you will indulge me.
—Order! I ask Senator Tate to withdraw that clear imputation.
—I am sorry if I chose my words incorrectly. I understood Senator Hamer to be making the allegation that the fire bombing of Dresden could be properly characterised as a war crime.
—I would like to make it quite clear that I made no such accusation. I asked whether it would be considered a war crime under the Government's proposed legislation. That is quite different.
—Order! I ask Senator Tate to withdraw.
—I withdraw any imputation against Senator Hamer in that respect. I will quote from the judgment of the United States Military Tribunal at Nuremberg, dated 10 April 1948:

ANSWER.PARA: It was submitted that the defendants must be exonerated from the charge of killing civilian populations since every Allied nation brought about the death of non-combatants through the instrumentality of bombing. Any person who, without cause, strikes another may not later complain that the other in repelling the attack uses sufficient force to overcome the original adversary. That is fundamental law between nations as well. It has already been adjudicated by a competent tribunal that Germany under its Nazi rulers started an aggressive war. The bombing of Berlin, Dresden, Hamburg, Cologne and other Germany cities followed the bombing of London, Coventry, Rotterdam, Warsaw and other Allied cities; the bombing of German cities succeeded, in point of time, the acts discussed here. But even if German cities had been bombed without Germans having bombed Allied cities, there still is no parallelism between an act of legitimate warfare, namely the bombing of a city with a concomitant loss of civilian life, and the premeditated killing of all members of certain categories of the civilian population in occupied territory. A city is bombed for tactical purposes: communications are to be destroyed, railways wrecked, ammunition plants demolished, factories razed, all for the purpose of impeding the military. In these operations it inevitably happens that non-military persons are killed. This is an incident, a grave incident to be sure, but an unavoidable corollary of battle action. The civilians are not individualized. The bomb falls. It is aimed at the railway yards, houses along the tracks are hit and many of their occupants killed. But that is entirely different, both in fact and in law, from an armed force marching up to those same railroad tracks, entering those houses abutting thereon, dragging out the men, women and children and shooting them. It was argued on behalf of the defendants that there was no moral distinction between shooting civilians with rifles and killing them by means of atomic bombs. There is no doubt that the invention of the atomic bomb, when used, was not aimed at non-combatants. Like any other aerial bomb employed during the war, it was dropped to overcome military resistance. Thus, as grave a military action as is an air bombardment, whether with the usual bombs or by atomic bomb, the one and only purpose of the bombing is to effect the surrender of the bombed nation. The people of that nation, through their representatives, may surrender and, with the surrender, the bombing ceases, the killing is ended. Furthermore, a city is assured of not being bombed by the law-abiding belligerent if it is declared an open city. With the Jews it was entirely different. Even if the nation surrendered they still were killed as individuals. It has not been shown throughout this entire trial that the killing of the Jews as Jews in any way subdued or abated the military force of the enemy, it was not demonstrated how mass killings and indiscriminate slaughter helped or was designed to help in shortening or winning the war for Germany. The annihilation of defenseless persons considered as `inferior' in Russia would have had no effect on the issue of the war. In fact, so mad were those who inaugurated this policy that they could not see that the massacre of the Jews in many instances actually hindered their own efforts.
I quoted that particular passage from that particular decision of the United States military tribunal at Nuremberg as the case to which I referred during Question Time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer.

I should like to make quite clear at the outset that I do not for a moment suggest that our bombing crews or other servicemen who served their country in the Second World War are war criminals. My concern is that the War Crimes Amendment Bill, as it is at present drafted, will do that. I am also not suggesting that under that proposed Act they will be prosecuted. But, as the War Crimes Amendment Bill stands, I believe it says to our servicemen, who with great courage bombed Germany in the Second World War, `You are war criminals'. We want to make quite clear that that is not what this Parliament thinks. I do not find the Minister's answer relevant. He quoted a case before the Nuremberg tribunal, but he should remember that the charter under which that tribunal was operating specifically exempted Allied servicemen from its terms. So we have to look back to what this Government is now doing in proposing the War Crimes Amendment Bill. The Bill refers to the definition of a war crime in the Nuremberg charter. Eliminating the provision that applied then, about allied servicemen not being covered by that definition, that charter says that it is a war crime to bomb a country recklessly or wantonly or if the bombing was not justified by military necessity. It is no defence to argue that people were acting under orders, that they were not aware of whether a certain action was or was not a military necessity because they had no means of knowing. If they did it, according to the way in which the Government's Bill is now drafted, they would be liable as war criminals. I do not find the Minister's answer at all relevant to the issue. What we must make quite clear in this Bill is that allied servicemen, acting in good faith and fighting a war at great personal danger in what they regarded as the defence of their country's interests, are not going to be vilified by this Government as war criminals.
Debate (on motion by Senator Peter Baume) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Stone proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the government to address the question of abuse of power by elements of the trade union movement as typified by recent behaviour in the building industry in Canberra.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call Senator Stone on this matter of public importance, I indicate that I have been advised that writs have been issued against persons involved in the building industry dispute in Canberra alleging defamation in relation to the conduct of the trade unions in the dispute. It was put to me that there may be a problem with the sub judice convention. The essence of the sub judice convention is that, subject to the right of the Senate to debate matters of public interest, debate in the Senate should not be such as to involve a substantial danger of prejudice to proceedings on foot before the courts.

INTERJECT.PARA: The issuing of writs, of course, does not necessarily mean that proceedings will take place, and, in this instance, strictly speaking, there are no proceedings as such to prejudice. Moreover, until proceedings have actually commenced, the danger of prejudice must be regarded as much less than when the proceedings have started.
