TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr President. I have noted carefully what you have said by way of your prefatory remarks and, of course, I shall abide scrupulously by your guidance in the debate on this matter of public importance. I say at the outset that one of the reasons I am speaking first in this matter of public importance debate is that the Leader of the Opposition in this chamber, Senator Chaney, was so overcome by cheering Her Majesty yesterday or, for that matter, by cheering the excellent speech made by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) at the opening of the new Parliament House that he has temporarily lost his voice. I think that is a matter of great regret. I am sure that the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) would agree with me on that point.

SPEECH.PARA: Without spending too much time on the new Parliament House, I think it is apposite that that matter be referred to in the context of the debate on this matter of public importance, which, as the President indicated, relates to the failure of the Government to address the question of abuse of power by elements of the trade union movement as typified by recent behaviour in the building industry in Canberra. Although the particular matter to which I shall be referring later so far as the latter part of the matter is concerned is a more recent event, nevertheless, as we are all aware from several debates in this House and particularly from the work of Senator Warwick Parer and his rorts committee, there can have been few greater examples of abuse of power by elements of the trade union movement than those which occurred in the course of construction of what is-and we all agree-in the end an extremely fine building, the cost of which has been enormously increased as a result of those abuses.

Let me come to the matter for debate. The abuse of power by elements-and I emphasise the word `elements'-of the trade union movement is, I regret to say, an acknowledged part of our industrial relations scene today. I emphasise that word `elements' because I am perfectly well aware that we have many decent trade union leaders in this country and, of course, a great body of decent members of trade unions. I distinguish clearly between the members of trade unions and, in some cases, the bosses of trade unions, but we are speaking about the activities of a certain element of the latter in this debate this afternoon. The abuse of power undertaken by those elements is an acknowledged part of our industrial relations scene.

We recently saw, at long last, the conclusion of a most serious industrial relations dispute which began almost three years ago-the so-called Dollar Sweets matter which involved the affairs of a small family company situated in Melbourne. This company is responsible for the creation of hundreds and thousands, as they are called, which used to delight me as a small child and which are used on cakes prepared for small children-or at least they were in my day. In 1985, that company experienced very serious industrial disputes amounting to intimidation and other forms of threats of violence. In his original judgment, which I think is called the interlocutory judgment, Mr Justice Murphy of the Supreme Court of Victoria had a number of things to say about the actions of the trade unionists, including some members-not merely leaders-involved in the Dollar Sweets case. I will read to the Senate one or two extracts from the judgment of Mr Justice Murphy. There was an industrial dispute and a number of the employees of Dollar Sweets went back to work. A number refused to do so and formed a picket line at the entrance to the company's plant. The judgment of Mr Justice Murphy, delivered on 12 December 1985, states:

On one occasion a truck driver, an electrical contractor, having been told by the picket line in the lane that he could not proceed to the said premises, then attempted to enter the premises from the front, but was again warned by the second defendant, Mr. Frizziero, that he could not enter because there was a picket line and that if he did attempt to do so, there would be trouble. Not wanting trouble, the electrical contractor departed without performing the repair work on a machine which he had come to repair for reward at the plaintiff's request.
The plaintiff was the proprietor of the company, a Mr Frank Stauder. His Honour continued:

It was submitted by Mr Strong of Counsel, who appeared for all the defendants, that the electrical contractor may have been in sympathy with the Union cause. I prefer the inference that he was intimidated by the veiled threats by Mr Frizziero and the picket.
His Honour went on to say:

A serious incident occurred on the 23 July, 1985, shortly after the picket line commenced. The plaintiff company by contract with Rowntree Hoadley Company received at approximately weekly intervals regular deliveries of about two tonnes of material which it used for making hundreds and thousands . . . On 23 July the truck driver from Rowntree Hoadley attempting delivery was deliberately turned back by the picket . . . This deliberate act of turning back the driver was calculated to interfere with, and has interfered with, the plaintiff's business and contracts for supply quite seriously, and its inability to supply its regular customers with hundreds and thousands has contributed to a considerable loss of profit.
At a later point in his judgment, His Honour referred to what might be, in the minds of many, an even more serious offence. I quote from page 7 of the judgment:
It seems from the evidence that the activities of the defendants on the picket line have not been confined to obstruction and besetting-
I understand `besetting' is a legal term of a rather minatory and intimidatory kind-
of customers and invitees of the plaintiff company. The picket has been indiscriminate, and the material before me-
that is, before Mr Justice Murphy-
satisfies me that the picket has obstructed all persons-
not merely people wishing to do business with the plaintiff company, but all persons-
who have wished to do business with other shops in the said lane, shops unconnected with the plaintiff. This form of what, I think, must be described as anarchy-
I will come back to that word later in my remarks-
has of course also the effect of dissuading clients of the plaintiff from proceeding in the normal way to perform contracts with it, and I consider this particular action only in that light.

Finally, Mr Justice Murphy noted some further activities on the part of some members of that picket line. He said that on 1 August 1985, Mr Lendon, who was a truck driver, a commercial carrier, with his own small business-he was a truck owner-driver engaged full time in the carriage of commercial goods-was followed for a considerable distance by another vehicle driven by one of the defendants who happened to be the vice president of the Victorian branch of the defendant union in this case. He noted:
Mr. Lendon was fearful enough to seek assistance by radio from another taxi truck which came to his aid. However, although Mr. Lendon asked Mr Johnson-
that is, one of the defendants-

not to follow him any further, during the following week Mr. Lendon's vehicle was followed again by a blue Commodore driven by . . . Mr. Frizziero, the second-named defendant. He deposed, and I accept-
that is, Mr Justice Murphy-
that after this had happened some ten times, Mr. Lendon contacted the police and soon after Mr. Frizziero ceased to follow him.

Mr Justice Murphy went on to detail, in a rather compelling, minute way, the forms of personal intimidation and violence to which people seeking to go about their lawful business were being subjected. He detailed the forms of personal harassment by those elements of the trade union movement. In conclusion, one can only note that recently the real courts-as distinct from the arbitral tribunals-found or were about to find in favour of those defendants, to the point where the matter was settled out of court, with considerable damages being awarded to the injured parties. What does this mean? It points very clearly to the importance of having a system which generally binds both sides-employers and those who work for them. The importance of that need is acknowledged by the Government. The Minister for Industrial Relations, the Hon. Ralph Willis, said when he presented the first version of his Industrial Relations Bill on 14 May last year:
An essential element of any industrial relations system which provides benefits and protections to registered organisations-
trade unions, in this context-
and their members is that there should be effective means of ensuring compliance with the decisions of its institutions-
that is, institutions of the industrial relations system. He went on to to say:
The principal initiative-
the principal initiative in his then Bill-
is that the present bans clause provisions, which have long since fallen into disrepute and are now substantially moribund, will be replaced by a new direction and injunction process.

One might say that that was said a year ago and that since then there has been an election and other things have happened, but despite his personal humiliation over the dropping of that Bill prior to the 1987 election campaign, the Minister, Mr Ralph Willis, kept on insisting that in due course he would bring in a better compliance system than that which he described as moribund. What we have today is nothing of the kind. As late as June of last year, which was after the Government had come partially to its senses in relation to its proposed legislation and had abandoned the attack on the Trade Practices Commission in relation to the powers under sections 45d and 45e of the Trade Practices Act and the previously proposed attack on the common law rights of employers and employees, the Minister was still saying, as he said on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio program The World Today:

That will leave us with a compliance system which is more similar to the one which currently exists but with some very substantial differences, a direction system which I believe will be much more effective than the current bans clause which has virtually been moribund for 20 years and also with an array of non-monetary penalties where unions or the employers refuse to accept Commission decisions or orders.

This debate takes place in the context of the Government's failure to do anything of the kind-its failure to take any action at all in this regard. Indeed, on the contrary, today the Government or its representatives are continuing to accuse those even raising issues of this kind of being not interested in what is euphemistically described as a positive approach to industrial relations. The fact is that this is a continuing problem in a number of industries, particularly the industry which is mentioned in the matter of public importance letter-namely, the building and construction industry.

I wish to refer briefly to a dispute in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) involving White Constructions Ltd. The first thing to note about that dispute, which was between that company and the Transport Workers Union of Australia and others, is that the Transport Workers Union simply failed to turn up for the hearing of the dispute. It sent a telegram saying that it had not been advised of the dispute, which was totally untrue. It had been advised, as the transcript of proceedings made clear. The union failed to turn up. Mr Commissioner Baird, who is a very well respected Commissioner of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission operating in the Australian Capital Territory, had a number of things to say about the behaviour of trade unions in the Australian Capital Territory in these matters. I quote from page 27 of the transcript, which records the Commissioner as saying:

I deal with sometimes four disputes a day, and I have got to say while Parliament House has been described by various people as some sort of circus, it may have been, at one time, the circus, but I can tell you it is only a very small potato in the circus that goes on in the rest of the industry up there.
Mr Commissioner Baird went on to say:

I might say, that I have been unofficially informed . . . that there are substantial payments being made to crane drivers in tower cranes to get lifts done on sites in the Australian Capital Territory, which are totally illegal.
He went on to say, and I think this is a key passage in his remarks:

My attitude to the whole situation in Canberra, and the building industry, is that I have endeavoured to hold the industry to the principles set out in the wage guidelines and to the criteria that applies in regard to claims, and site allowances, and so on, and particularly the settlement of dispute clauses, and I find that while there are a number of cases where they are adhered to, the preponderance of disputes occur as if no agreements existed of any kind . . .

We have just heard the Leader of the Government in the Senate tell us by way of a statement after Question Time that some agreements have been entered into in relation to the submarine construction project in Adelaide. But what does that mean? Nobody has the slightest faith any longer in the willingness-I almost said `ability'-of the trade union movement to adhere to agreements entered into. Certainly, Mr Commissioner Baird, in the remarks which I have just quoted, made his view on that matter very plain. He went on to say in a further point in his remarks:
Now, am I to assume that the union is going to support liars and frauds, because that is really what I am faced with, and I must say, it is getting to a stage where the description of anarchy-
that is the word I said I would come back to-

is the only description. I mean, we have just had a case where I dealt for 12 months with a case, gave every opportunity for the union to appear, put its arguments, leaned over backwards to ensure that the union's position was put, discussed it with the shop stewards at inspections, raised it in every recorded hearing before the commission, and the union simply failed to appear in 12-once in 12 months-twice in 12 months.

Now, the position with the other unions, is similar. There are a series of breaches of agreements that have been made in regard to such things as claims for payment while people are on strike, which are quite outside the undertakings which are given. There are bans imposed without regard for any of the settlements of disputes clauses, and we have got that many settlement of disputes agreements when people talk about them and point to this agreement, and that agreement and the other agreement, I must say I get confused which one we are talking about.
Commissioner Baird continued:

I must say, if I were an employer I would have no hesitation, if I could not get the work done, and have issued a lawful instruction to take whatever course was available to me to either enforce the order or shut the job down. That is my approach to them.

That is to say, to the wreckers in the trade union movement within the building industry in the Australian Capital Territory. The Commissioner's description of the situation as anarchic is, if anything, an understatement. The Government's response to various pleas for intervention has been to ask both parties to behave reasonably. Its approach has been to put an equality of blame, so to speak, on both unions and employers. The fact of the matter is that that kind of response from the Government is a pathetic and inadequate response to a situation where one side and one side alone in this case-I emphasise that-is behaving totally unreasonably. This is something which I am sure my colleague Senator Reid will draw out. There is in fact no difficulty in prescribing a remedy. The Government itself presented a remedy in a previous Bill in May last year. Indeed, Senator Chaney has put forward a private member's Bill which is before the Senate at present. What we have from the Government on this matter is a simple, clear and downright abrogation of responsibility.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am rather astounded that the Opposition has brought on today, on a single sitting day straight after the opening of the new Parliament House, this matter of public importance. What we have just heard is a quite extraordinary contribution by Senator Stone. If this were an Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission hearing, there would be no need for the Government to reply because there would be no case to answer. What we have as a matter of public importance is a request for the Government to take action in regard to industrial relations in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) as a result of particular incidents. We have a very thin, if not pathetic, effort to make a case by weaving some materials together, resulting in the claim that the Government has a case to answer. In replying for the Government I will deal with some of the things Senator Stone has said.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter of public importance is a curious affair. It is curious from several points. Firstly, I recognise that the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Chaney, is suffering a voice affliction today-perhaps the worst injury a politician can have-and, therefore, Senator Stone has been chosen to carry this issue for the Opposition. Senator Stone is a curious choice to carry this for the Opposition. He is a member of the H. R. Nicholls Society, a notorious extreme--

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not just a member; I am the President.

—I thank Senator Stone for informing me that he is the President of the H. R. Nicholls Society, a notorious right wing organisation in Australia given to extraordinary and extreme comments about industrial relations which all reasonable commentators dismiss as being on the lunatic fringe. We have a full front bench for the Opposition. Many other front bench Opposition members could have been chosen. However, Senator Stone was called. That is like putting Dracula in charge of the blood bank.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter of public importance is curious as well because industrial relations is one of the strongest points in this Government's record. We have a very good record in industrial relations. Perhaps we can now look forward to being attacked because we have brought the Budget deficit, bequeathed to Australia by the Liberal-National Party in 1983, into surplus. Perhaps we can be attacked for creating one million jobs since we came to power in this country. That is a thing of which the Opposition disapproves. Perhaps we can be attacked for that. Perhaps we can be attacked for the success of our family package-for recognising the needs of Australian families and improving their conditions. Perhaps we can be attacked for those important, compassionate and worthwhile social reforms. If we can be attacked for all those things we can be attacked in regard to industrial relations. We have a very good record on industrial relations matters. The Opposition has chosen to attack us on one of our strongest points. I congratulate the Opposition on it. I ask honourable senators opposite, `Please keep it up, fellows; we would like to see a bit more emphasis on what we have done that you think is bad because the Australian people don't share your opinion'.

The matter of public importance is curious as well because the Opposition does not come to this debate with clean hands. Honourable senators opposite cannot stand here in this chamber and say, `We speak with a perfect record of industrial relations in Australia'. They cannot do that for the very good reason that the Opposition has had one of the worst records in industrial relations of any Opposition in terms of its intervention in industrial relations debates. When it was in government under Malcolm Fraser it presided over one of the most divisive eras of industrial relations in Australia. It is curious that honourable senators opposite have come in here without clean hands and have dared to accuse us.

It is also curious that nothing new has been added by the Opposition. We have heard all this before. This is Cold War rhetoric. I listened to Senator Stone carefully. To put it in pure, straight logical terms he raised three particular incidents. One was the reference to the new Parliament House construction-a matter on which Senator Stone vaguely touched. When the Fraser Government was in power it had an opportunity to do something about that. We did something about it; honourable senators opposite did not. I ask honourable senators opposite not to criticise us on that. We heard a long and boring excerpt from the Dollar Sweets judgment. It was very interesting. We understand-Senator Stone concluded-that the case was settled out of court. We then heard a bit about construction in Canberra. We have heard of three cases. Out of a total work force in Australia of over 6 1/2 million workers we have had three cases. We have an absolute logical fault. The Opposition is trying to make a general case from three incidents. Any student of logic could tell the Opposition that that is not the way logical progression is constructed. The Opposition would fail in that elementary exercise.

Having said all those things, let me say that we do not shrink from debating the matter. We will answer the points. I will take the first point concerning the Quadrant construction contract in the ACT. I want to table for the information of the Senate a Press statement by the Minister for the Arts and Territories, the Hon. Gary Punch, on this subject. His Press statement is instructive. He said that if there are allegations of a criminal nature those allegations should be taken to the police. He enjoined the people who make those allegations to take that route. We do not shrink from that. We are not a government that supports criminality in any form. However, if someone has an allegation to make let him take it to the proper authority and submit it to due process.

Secondly, what did the Minister say? He said that the employers in this particular case had not availed themselves of the full range of opportunities available under the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. They should do that. They should do it immediately. It is no good Senator Stone putting forward argument in this chamber that ought to be put to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, a properly constituted Commission, to settle a particular issue. This is not the forum. Senator Stone may not have noticed but this is the Senate-the proper place for political debate. Debate settling industrial relations matters should be in the proper forum.

Thirdly, Senator Stone has said that if there are broader allegations to be made or broader issues to be canvassed they should be canvassed before the building industry inquiry which is being conducted by the Full Bench of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. That inquiry has already sat for 21 days; it has 15 more days scheduled. All of the parties concerned are participating in that inquiry. Emerging in the process of that inquiry is a common desire to seek solutions to the problems in the industry. That inquiry is looking at relationships under the award, at industrial relations management on the employers' side and contractual arrangements, as building companies enter into them, in order to see the impact of those contractual arrangements on industrial relations. I table the Press statement of the Minister. That document is a clear, open and proper rebuttal by the Government of the issues raised by Senator Stone. Some of my colleagues in this debate may wish to canvass that matter more fully.

Let me go back to one of my opening comments concerning the records of this Government and the Fraser Government-a government under which Senator Stone played a unique advisory role when he was Secretary to the Treasury. The most favoured index to chart whether the industrial relations course is rocky or smooth is the industrial disputes figures. Under the Fraser Government the average number of working days lost per month totalled 249,600. Under the Hawke Government, the figure is 116,100-a reduction of 54 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't have a dispute when you are bludgeoned into submission, Minister. You don't have a dispute under those circumstances.

—The raw figures show that under our Government there has been a 54 per cent reduction in the number of disputes in this country. Senator Stone might wish to quarrel with that, but I do not think even he can go past the figures. Another perhaps more important benchmark than the figures I have given is a table I have showing the annual average working days lost per 1,000 employees. This is important because, as we have created one million new jobs and the number of people employed in the work force has increased, we would expect the propensity to dispute to increase accordingly.

SPEECH.PARA: From 1976 to 1982-that is, the Fraser period-there was an annual average of 591 working days lost per 1,000 employees. From 1983 to 1986, on average 243 working days were lost per 1,000 employees. That is a reduction of 59 per cent. We do not have all the figures for 1987, but in the 12 months to the end of November 231 working days per 1,000 employees were lost. Those figures indicate a consistent pattern. The Australian people understand this, and all the polls that have been taken show that. The people respond, `Yes, we believe Labor governments can handle industrial relations better'. They remember the divisiveness of the Fraser years. They remember when Australians were pitted against Australians on the industrial relations front. People listening to the debate today will regard the sort of rhetoric typified by Senator Stone's speech as an echo from an older era, the Fraser era.

I turn to another area of industrial relations in which I have a particular interest in my role as Minister for Resources. It is an area which stands for many Australians as a model for improvement in industrial relations under the Hawke Labor Government. I refer to the Pilbara, because by doing so we are able to make an important point--

TALK.START.PARA: —Try Robe River.

—I am going to try Robe River, and I think Senator Stone will be sorry he invited me to do so by the time I have finished. It is no secret, it is a matter of public record, that industrial relations in the Pilbara during the Fraser years of office were tragically at a high level and it is a matter of recrimination from both sides as to who was responsible for that. Indeed, it can be said that on some occasions workers were responsible. On some other occasions employers were responsible. Certainly the cultural psychology of the region was such that it was a highly disputatious area. In 1984 we established the Western Australian Iron Ore Consultative Council, with the Western Australian Government, and we talked with the industry about the need to make it more competitive so that employers could reward their shareholders, so that workers could obtain job security and better remuneration for the activities they were engaged in and so that, because of the better competitiveness of an Australian export industry, there would be more returns to the Government and thus to the public pocket.

SPEECH.PARA: What is the record of the consultative process we established in the Pilbara? The number of days lost in the iron ore industry went as high as 166,000 in 1979 and, in the year preceding the establishment of the Council, 105,000 days were lost. In 1984, the year in which the Council was established, the number of days lost dropped dramatically, to 40,000. Since then, even with the Robe River disputes, overall disputation has remained at historically low levels, at less than half the average pre-1984. The figures for 1987, up to October-which is the latest available published material-show the lowest incidence of days lost in the last 10 years, down by 21,000. The 1987 performance is all the more impressive given that it includes strike action which occurred at the Robe River operations for most of January. Disputation for the remaining nine months was exceptionally low.

The point is that not only because of our approach on the macro-stage, across the whole sweep of the Australian economy, have we done better but also in particularly disputatious industries, with our conciliation processes, the bringing together of the parties and the harmonising of interests, we have been able to reduce industrial disputation and develop a competitive industry in the Pilbara-with the exception of Robe River. What is unique about Robe River? There are a number of things unique to Robe River.

TALK.START.PARA: —It doubled its productivity in the last 12 months; that is what is unique about it. It had done what Australia has to do-double its productivity.

—My understanding is that it has increased its productivity but it has not increased it startlingly out of line with productivity increases in the rest of the iron ore industry in the Pilbara, and it has not done it in such a way that in the longer haul the figures per worker engaged to tonne of output will remain consistently high, because it has done it at the cost, I am advised, of running down all its maintenance on plant and equipment. Because it has not employed workers on maintaining its plant and equipment it is facing the inevitable-that is, sooner or later it will have to stop doing some mining work and start repairing its plant and equipment. Then, when we get a full and proper sample of its figures, we will be able to see the truth about Robe River.

SPEECH.PARA: But this is not a debate about Robe River. Had it been I would have looked forward to filling my available time by pointing out the contrast between Robe River and the rest of the Pilbara. At the end of last year and the beginning of this year we wrote new contracts for the supply of iron ore to Japan. We regained a significant share of the Japanese market. The companies that regained that market were Hamersley Iron Pty Ltd and the Mt Newman Mining Co. Pty Ltd. They were the companies for which the Iron Ore Consultative Council approach worked; they were the companies that could demonstrate real gains-not illusory gains and not asserted gains but real gains in productivity of up to, I am advised, 40 per cent. This was able to be done through the consultative process.

The point I was making earlier was that the macro figures speak eloquently across the scope of the economy in a particularly disputatious area. They speak eloquently, again, in terms of what this Government has been able to achieve in industrial relations. We are able to apply those figures and compare situations. There is a problem in the Australian Capital Territory with the Quadrant site, there was a problem with the new Parliament House and maybe the Dollar Sweets dispute was a bit shonky, but logicians would sit here and gape at someone of Senator Stone's education and background bringing into this chamber what he purported to be a credible argument concerning these three situations. It clearly was not a credible argument.

However, it is not the case that the Commonwealth sits back in rapturous contemplation of its own successes in this field and thinks, `Well, that is enough; we have done sufficiently well to prove our credentials, to establish yet again in the minds of the Australian electorate that we are better at industrial relations'. On 28 April, just a few weeks ago, Ralph Willis introduced into the House of Representatives a new Bill to amend the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. This Bill, for the first time in 84 years, comprehensively overhauls the provisions of the existing Act. Anyone who has had anything to do with industrial relations in Australia knows that the patchwork quilt of endless amendments and amendments on amendments which then amend further amendments that constitutes the existing Act is a playground for lawyers, and cases drag on endlessly because the legislation itself is some sort of impediment to the conduct of better industrial relations. It is only during the period of a Labor government that there is a cushion to enable reviews to take place and amendments to be brought in.

The Willis Bill does a number of important things. It removes the unintelligible sections from the Act and introduces a number of amendments, which will mean that an Australian Industrial Relations Commission will be introduced to replace the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and a number of specialist tribunals that have applied in this country as well. There will be the provision of greater powers for the new Commission to deal with union demarcation disputes-an important area that needs greater attention. There will be speedier and simpler union amalgamation procedures. I hope that this will mean that there will be fewer unions in Australia and they will be better able to manage their resources and therefore better able to play a role in representing their members and thus prevent disputes in advance of their arising. It will provide new requirements which will restrict future registrations of unions to organisations with more than 3,000 members. There will be provision for fixed term certified agreements which are not necessarily constrained by the Commission's wage fixing or other principles. There will be greater emphasis on dispute settlement procedures at workplace level, including new rules for the use of grievance procedures. There will be a requirement for union elections to be by secret ballot conducted by the Australian Electoral Commission unless an exemption is granted; and provision for greater cooperation between the Federal and State industrial tribunals.

That is a list of the main features of the new Bill. This Bill arises in the landscape of industrial relations in this country at a time when we have demonstrated huge gains in improving industrial relations. It arises after an extensive round of consultations between unions and employers. Though no one is saying, `We wholeheartedly endorse it', because that is the nature of the industrial relations business, it is going forward in a climate in which it is possible for the Government to say accurately that no-one is going out stringently to oppose it either. In the concluding minute that remains to me in this debate, I wish to rest my case on Senator Stone's argument by quoting from the Melbourne Herald on 26 April 1988. The person being quoted by the Herald said:

I frankly am in no doubt that the wages outcome which has been delivered so far by the Government could not have been achieved by a coalition Government, even if I had been Industrial Relations Minister.

Who was the speaker? Who was the Herald quoting? Was it a member of the Australian Labor Party? No. Was it a Democrat? No. It was quoting the former Minister for Industrial Relations under the Fraser Government, Ian Macphee. In that quotation he gave an accolade to the Hawke Government's achievement in industrial relations-an accolade that was supported later when, at a Liberal Party-organised function of top business talent, the businessmen gathered also underlined what Mr Macphee had said in support of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pity that the Australian Democrats see this matter of public importance in the way mentioned by Senator McLean. We would like the debate to be more positive. Certainly we in Canberra would like the debate to be much more positive, because the catalogue of industrial history in recent times in the Australian Capital Territory, which I shall go into in a moment, will indicate to honourable senators that it is very important for this Territory to attain a better industrial relations environment. It is very important to the future development of this Territory to have an environment in which people will consider investing, which will bring business here and which will further widen employment opportunities-particularly for young people, so that they are not as dependent on the Public Service for jobs, if they want to live in Canberra, as they have been in the past. The Democrats say that there is a requirement to get on with business. Yes, there is, because the Government has put forward a program that is beyond reason for this period of parliamentary sittings. If the Government thinks that it can take that step and tell the rest of us that we are not able to raise matters which are of importance in our electorates, I believe that we will not fulfil some of the purposes for which we have been elected.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) dealt at some length with a reduction in disputes, but did not bother to tell us about the number of bans that have been imposed not only in the ACT but throughout Australia-but particularly in this Territory. How often are there threats which result in an issue being avoided before becoming a dispute? I refer to threats which have required drivers to become members of unions or be put out of work; threats aimed at carpenters on the Parliament House site in times gone by to the effect that if they did not join the union they would never work again. We have not heard much about that sort of thing. One may well be able to produce figures to show that there have been fewer strikes. We know why that has been the case-bans can bring an industry to its knees without any loss of income to union members, whereas there is loss if there is a strike.

The Government's new industrial relations package which was introduced into the Parliament last month and which has been referred to is critically deficient in that it does not include provisions to enable the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to enforce compliance with its orders. That is why this matter is important now. The Bill that was envisaged last year did make such a provision, and we know that that is why it went away. Senator Chaney's private member's Bill, which has been referred to, seeks similar provisions, and they are important.

Sufficient evidence is available to indicate that such powers are needed for the Commission if we are to get on with increasing productivity and, in the particular instance to which I am referring, creating in the Australian Capital Territory an environment in which it will be easier to attract business-to make this a place where businesses will want to come and to feel that there will be some benefits to them if they do so.

Let us look at the history of Canberra in recent times. I want to run through a few examples of industrial matters in this Territory. The Quadrant dispute has now been going on for about 12 weeks and is the latest in a long line of industrial disputes. I shall come back to that later. Let us look at 1987, at some of the more major disputes; there were lesser disputes than those to which I shall refer. Plumbers on the new Parliament House site were on strike for two months. They went on strike after the implementation of an Arbitration Commission decision to deduct about $50 per week from their wages as a punishment for conducting an industrial campaign for a log of claims outside the current wage guidelines. They returned to work only when the money was restored. The Commission had no power to do otherwise. In early August social workers went on strike over pay anomalies. In September there was a dispute involving the Professional Officers Association in the Australian Capital Territory Health Authority, a dispute which had been current in the previous June. That dispute involved a ban on work in the pathology laboratories. In September there was an industrial dispute involving Canberra's garbage service. In that month also one saw the culmination of industrial action by ACT nurses, who had been fighting to have a new career and pay structure implemented by the Health Authority. The Authority's refusal to comply with the pay and career structure prescribed by the Full Bench of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, which was to have been in place by 10 August, was another instance of the Commission not being in a position to enforce its orders. It was a clear case of the employer ignoring the Commission's ruling. The dispute continued; nurses walked out of hospitals, and elective surgery was cancelled. How often have we heard that in this chamber in relation to the ACT over the last four or five years? Honourable senators know the impact on patients when elective surgery is cancelled. That dispute continued for more than a month.

In October doctors passed a vote of no confidence in the ACT Health Authority. There were bans on freight deliveries by members of the Transport Workers Union. There was a health inspectors' ban over pay and conditions. A demarcation dispute between three unions at the ACT Electricity Authority went on for 10 days before it was referred to the Commission. There was a printers dispute, threatened ward closures at public hospitals and a TAFE teachers strike over work claims in October.

The Hospital Employees Federation (HEF) placed bans on the collection of waste at the Woden Valley Hospital over safety issues which prevented supplies going into the hospital. Again, as I indicated, that ban slowly brought the hospital to a halt while not interfering with the pay of those who were involved. The Commission gave the Authority stand-down orders for unionists who refused to perform duties. At the time the Salvation Army was feeding the patients in the hospital. The union maintained a picket line outside it. In spite of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission orders to the HEF to try to settle the dispute, it continued for more than a week. Two weeks later contaminated waste was found at ACT tips. No-one would deny that that should not occur. It led to bans on garbage collections which affected the people of Canberra generally and caused the closure of the tips.

Interestingly, at that point Mr Willis was prompted to observe that industrial relations in the ACT health industry were dreadful. But he did not seem to have remembered that when he got around to the legislation he drafted recently. The garbage dispute continued, with tips closed for more than a week. There were bans on garbage collections from homes. The dispute affected the hospitals. There were calls for the dispute to end because of the hazard to the newborn and the sick in the hospitals resulting from the non-collection of garbage. The matter was before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission for six days. It was only when the Health Authority agreed to pay the stood-down workers, whose bans had prompted the stand-downs, that it was resolved. The Commission rescinded its stand-down orders because the hospitals were to be closed down if the garbage was not removed. What is that, if not threats of the kind which ought to be abolished by the Arbitration Commission?

In November there were problems with the teachers over staffing issues. Also that month firemen in Canberra refused to carry out duties other than emergency calls. In December there was a social workers' strike. The situation continues this year. Another garbage dispute commencing in January affected street sweeping and the like. Some restaurants were forced to close because they could not get rid of their garbage. On 18 January this year the Arbitration Commissioner, Mr Bain, said that he thought most of the issues had been resolved. But the strike went on. On 19 January the union decided not to meet again about the dispute for another two days, in spite of the fact that the Commission hearing had been scheduled for that day and the following day.

The dispute dragged on until the Australia Day weekend. The union returned to work on the Friday but did not fully re-open the tips until the following week. So the workers got paid for the holiday weekend but the dispute was not resolved. It ended on 27 January. There was further industrial action in February.

In January there were problems with nurses at the Blood Bank. There were motor vehicle registry bans in support of the second tier wage claim affecting the re-registration of vehicles. In February there were bans by members of the FEDFA, disrupting bus services, just as the school year began. Many children in Canberra need buses to get to school. Also in February wardsmen at the Woden Valley Hospital imposed bans. Licence restrictions at the motor vehicle centre affected trainee taxi drivers. Many of the 40 would-be taxi drivers were not able to take tests which would have enabled them to proceed with employment.

Then there was the Quadrant dispute. There are 45 employees on that site and three full-time union officials. This is in spite of the fact that when the matter was before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in February the Commissioner hearing the case ordered a lifting of bans and a return to work. It is interesting to note the comments of Commissioner Baird, a responsible and well-respected Commissioner. He said:

I deal with sometimes four [ACT] disputes a day, and I have got to say while Parliament House has been described by various people as some sort of circus . . . it is only a very small potato in the circus that goes on in the rest of the industry up there.
In dealing with the dispute in question he said:

I find that no sooner is an agreement made, or an undertaking given, that it is broken. I just do not understand that kind of situation. There is almost no credibility with the undertakings given by the union. One of the problems I have with the unions is that demands are made, bans are imposed. It is nothing for an organiser to go onto the job and simply ban this machine, that machine, this job and that job, and walk away from it, sometimes without even discussion with management. My attitude to the whole situation in Canberra, and the building industry, is that I have endeavoured to hold the industry to the principles set out in the wage guidelines and to the criteria that applies in regard to claims, and site allowances . . .

He described the situation in the ACT as bordering on anarchy. One cannot blame the Commissioner for the frustration he has felt arising out of this situation which he has described so vividly in his findings. I hope that the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, reads those findings carefully and gives some thought to the Bill he is introducing, recognising the need for this situation not to continue. The Commissioner outlined his further difficulties in attempting to resolve the issue in dispute when he attempted to contact the union involved:

I have tried to find-on one occasion I actually spoke to the FEDFA office, asked for Bob Elkin to discuss a matter. The lady on the switch asked Bob was he in, he said `No', all of which I heard on the phone. Now, am I to assume that the union is going to support liars and frauds, because that is really what I am faced with, and I must say, it is getting to a stage where the description of anarchy is the only description.

I hope that Mr Willis reads those words and takes them into account. The Commissioner described how it has been impossible to get the union to appear to put its position in hearings before the Commission. He also said that other unions are similarly unwilling to cooperate.

As I indicated at the beginning of my speech, there are other disputes. Other statements by the Commissioner could easily be read out here. They are all part of the story. I reiterate the need for us to be able to get on with the building industry and other industries in Canberra without these interruptions which gives the area a particularly bad name. It seems that the Government is unwilling to tackle the issue. It is just not prepared to do anything which might upset the unions, to which the Government seems to be totally mendicant in its industrial relations policy. The threat by the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions last August that the Government can still introduce a Bill, but that it will have to be a Bill that does not do anything on compliance, seems to have overwhelmed the Government. The Government does not appear to be willing to deal with this issue. I say to the Government that it is necessary for the Bill to be looked at again from this point of view. It is certainly necessary for the ACT. I hope that that will be the case before the debate that has already been foreshadowed for later in this session commences.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I was interested to read the words used in this matter of public importance about the power of the trade unions. I am always interested to hear honourable senators opposite talk about how the trade unions and the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission operate. They do so on the basis of having read newspaper reports or a transcript of a particular Arbitration Commission case. I have had 20 years experience in the trade union movement with industrial matters. I know how it operates. I know how people think. I know how some people try to take advantage of others. There are those on both sides who keep their word and believe that honour is important. Others do not. To suggest that, because of some hiccup in Canberra, the Government should create legislation that would be used to make industrial and economic slaves, to bludgeon workers and deprive them of their rights, is a gross distortion of what needs to be done.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Stone raised the matter of Dollar Sweets Co. Pty Ltd. There was, and is currently, legislation on the books which enabled Dollar Sweets to take legal action. Dollar Sweets has had a decision; the people who were involved in that dispute have paid the price. But Senator Stone still had to talk about the matter. I think he quoted Justice Murphy, who preferred the version of events that intimidation was used on the picket line to the version that someone may have turned back at the picket line because he supported the cause that the workers were involved in as just. Let me say, as the person who has experienced and who has been on many picket lines: if I experienced any intimidation on picket lines it was the other way round. If, after having explained the workers' position, you suggest to an interstate truck driver who is about 14 stone-and you are about 10 stone-that he might give you some assistance, there is certainly intimidation, but it does not come from the person on the picket line.

We heard about the powers of the unions-this abused term. The unions have power all right-they have the power of persuasion. They have power from their members' knowledge of the way they have been exploited over many years. As anybody who has read history knows, the trade unions started out as friendly societies with unpaid officials. They were defensive and they were conservative. Sure, they had to have industrial and political conflict with authority. When that occurred in the shearers' strike earlier this century the army and the police were lined up against the union. The leaders were put in gaol. In later times some of them were able to show their capacities when they entered the State Parliament in Queensland. Why did these things occur? It was because of the greed and the authoritarianism of the employers who used those government forces of the police and the troops.

Of course, the general society view in those days was that owners had a right to rule-there were the trappings of authority and the riches that went with that authority. The view was that workers ought to be content with poverty and having no rights and that they should depend upon the patronage of the people who did have power. The trade union movement and the Australian Labor Party have a proud record of having changed that order of society. The trade union movement and the Labor Party have been instruments in achieving justice and fair play. Sometimes this has been through industrial disputes. But whenever there is an industrial dispute the workers involved lose their total earning capacity-something their families cannot afford. Does anybody in this chamber or anybody in the community believe that they would do that out of a desire to show that they are honourable or want to hurt their employer? I defy anyone who uses any degree of intelligence to come to that conclusion. Of course they do not; they do it because of an unjust situation and because that is the last weapon they have to use.

When talking about suppressing the workers we should look at some of the awards. For instance, in the metal industry award there is a provision that a person found stealing from the boss or engaging in some other misdemeanour can be charged in the court and fined in accordance with the law-and I have no complaint about that-and then have the employer take $1,000 of holiday pay away, $1,000 that the family cannot afford. That is a double penalty. This could happen where a person has worked for 11 months and has accrued $1,000 in holiday pay. I have no problem with one or other of the penalties being applied by the employer. If anyone in this chamber walks in off the street and commits the same act he can be brought before the court, but cannot lose wages. There is a heavier onus on workers and unionists.

I recall a dispute at Clyde Engineering more than 30 years ago under the old system involving the court and the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The penalties were heavy and the Commissioner was not even allowed to look at what the dispute was about. It was about welders who were welding on a surface that would poison their lungs. The Commissioner said, `I am not interested in the merit of the dispute. You are illegally in dispute-fined #500'. Is that what members of the Opposition want? If they do they ought to be ashamed of themselves. Honourable senators opposite want an aggressive adversarial system in which people cannot talk to seek solutions to their mutual benefit. We have to look to the future and we should look at current practices.

Senator Reid reeled off a whole list of disputes. There was not one word about who was to blame. There was not one word about what they were about. She quoted Jim Baird, a good friend of mine for over 30 years. This man was secretary of the metal industry national negotiating committee and he always strove for fair play for the workers. But he used to be attacked in the Press and maligned by people in the Opposition and those associated with them during those years of his service to the trade union movement. Now he has some new-found wisdom that the members of the Opposition want to quote in this chamber. I question their sincerity; I am certain of their hypocrisy.

Ian Macphee was quoted by Senator Cook, I think wisely so. Anyone who makes a statement as straightforward and honest as the statement Ian Macphee made deserves recognition. But, of course, Senator Stone, who has now gone from the chamber, said, `He did not know; he made a mistake'. Let us examine the record of both people and their experience. Senator Stone was a public servant all his life. He worked in Treasury. He used to put forward views on how the economy worked. Now he has other views, which sometimes Senator Walsh questions. But Mr Macphee worked for the employer organisations for many years. He knew what industrial relations were all about; he understood. He worked in the field and he knew-unlike people on the other side of the chamber. He made an honest comment. History will show, and anybody who wants to examine recent events will know-and I can say from being in those negotiations over recent years-that the slowing down of wage increases and the loss in real wages that have occurred as a result of the agreements and the cooperation between the Labor Party and the trade unions could not have been achieved by the Liberal Party of Australia in conjunction with the trade unions. Why? All honourable senators opposite want to do is bludgeon, deceive and disadvantage workers. They do not care about workers; workers cannot trust them. So Ian Macphee was totally right.

A man of some eminence, Mr Fraser, also made a statement recently that the Labor Government has really now reduced the argument to who is the best manager and that ideology is no longer the question. I agree that there is the question of who is the best manager, and I know whose side most fair minded people would come down on. But I do not believe that the question of ideology is gone, and I hope it never is. But the national interest should be paramount in the view of all of us. We must all change, and in seeking a better life we must seek to create better management situations-which, of course, goes to the question of how labour operates, how workers are paid, costs to industry in terms of management's capacity to operate, the terms and the way in which money is invested, the new methods of just-in-time and all those things that are now buzz words being used in industry.

They are the sorts of things that will create wealth in this country. That wealth will go towards financing other programs, which people are so fond of talking about in our community and in this place, to help the disadvantaged and do the things that need to be done. Adequate defence against people who may wish to attack this country and the ability to provide better education for more people also depend on our ability to create wealth.

What are our chances of creating wealth in the manufacturing industry? After all, manufacturing provides most jobs and is capable of creating a tremendous amount of wealth compared with other areas. In this respect I suppose I cannot refer to wool to the same extent as coal, because wool is more valuable. Certainly nobody in the Labor Party has ever questioned the importance of the role played by the wool growers in this country. If one sends a shipload of coal to a foreign country one does earn income. But if one sends a shipload of computers or other manufactured goods one earns 100 times more. That is where the creation of wealth is-in the manufacturing industry. Is such wealth going to be created by a work force coming to work every day of every week threatened with not having a say in its future? Are they not considered to be worthwhile people? Do they not have a contribution to make? It seems that they can have an idea as long as they keep it to themselves.

The employers have cornered the market in terms of expertise and intelligence and the ability to be creative and to build this country. The workers are really machine fodder-they are an extension of the machines they work. Employers have no hesitation in sacking 500 workers and putting in a machine on economic grounds. They do not worry about the workers. But the workers are still expected to make a contribution. They are expected not to enter into disputes as a means of trying to protect their livelihood. They are not expected to worry about working under conditions which expose them to loss of life or limb or destruction of their health. They are expected not to worry about that but to continue to work in the interests of the country. What is meant by that, of course, is that they should work in the interests of the people who control capital.

I do not want it to be thought that I am saying that all employers, anyone who has had any authority in industry, are bad or dishonest people. Only most of them fall into this category. I have met a small minority of employers who are decent people, to whom honour is important, who keep their word, who are concerned about the people who work for them and who look at things on a team basis.

Work is being done by various committees on this subject. The Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology has been given a reference by this chamber in respect of the refurbishment of manufacturing industry. It has come through to us from talking to witnesses, through our own attitude and certainly through our own experience as people in the community, that there needs to be an attitudinal change both in respect of management and amongst the workers. We have to come to the conclusion that if we can build something bigger and better for this community, if we can make the cake bigger, we can all have a bigger slice. But we have to take into account the rights of people in industry. It could be that jobs will be lost as a result of reorganisation of work and management. Such a change has to be carried out slowly. People should know what is happening. There will have to be retraining and jobs will have to be created in other industries. Where it is not possible to do that, the community must play a legitimate role in supporting people who are between jobs. People must be given more education. We must do this rather than bringing more immigrants to this country. I am not suggesting that we should close our doors. Certain people deserve consideration in that regard. But I think more emphasis has to be placed on the financing of the measures that I have mentioned.

I am talking about cooperation between management and labour. The trade union movement needs to be seen as an agent for good. Amalgamations will allow trade unions to become more viable. Their income will be greater and they will be more efficient. They will be able with management to take on projects which will change the face of this community. The trade unions have gone a long way along that road. I might inform the chamber that they have gone a lot further than have many employers. The trade unions have suggested changes that will be in the interests of the community, changes which in many cases have been resisted by employers. I think the proposition put forward by Senator Stone is ill thought out. It is a cheap political manoeuvre that has been put forward by someone who does not understand the issue that he is raising.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating this afternoon the following matter of public importance put forward by Senator Stone:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Government to address the question of abuse of power by elements of the trade union movement as typified by recent behaviour in the building industry in Canberra.

In the course of my speech I would like to recap on the debate that the coalition has put forward thus far; to look over the contribution put forward by the Government, namely that of Senator Cook and, to a more limited extent, that of Senator Burns; and, finally, to suggest some points which Senator McMullan, who will speak after me, could take the opportunity to address.

Let me first recap the points that the Opposition is seeking to make. We are talking about the abuse of power by elements of the trade union movement. Senator Burns does not seem to understand that. He seemed to be putting forward the proposition that we are saying that all unionists are bad and evil people in the way that he implies nearly all employers are. Obviously, he has not read the wording of the matter of public importance.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have been saying it for years. Have you changed your mind?

—As the honourable senator has had the opportunity to speak, he might like to take the opportunity to be quiet and let other people put their case forward. We are making the point that elements of the trade union movement, not the entire trade union movement, are causing significant trouble in the community by abusing the power that is bestowed upon them.

SPEECH.PARA: We want to put forward the proposition that there is a real need to have a system which binds both sides, both the employee and the employer, in industrial relations. This seems to be acknowledged by the Government. One needs only to turn to the second reading speech of Mr Willis on the Industrial Relations Bill to see that. In the election campaign last year, after the withdrawal of the industrial relations legislation, Mr Willis acknowledged the need for effective sanctions. Yet, one had listened to what Senator Burns had to say.

We are concerned that the Government continues to accuse people who raise the problem of abuse of union power as not being interested in a positive approach to industrial relations. That is, of course, a ridiculous proposition to put forward for two reasons. Abuse of union power is a continuing problem in certain industries and in particular in the construction industry. It is just not sensible to deny that. What is sensible is to try to address that problem and see what part the Government can play in doing something about it. Of course, there are a number of ways in which one can take a positive approach. One can point out the positive steps that one thinks can be taken. One can also do that by pointing out where one thinks there are faults and by highlighting those faults. It is only by highlighting the faults and the problems in the system that those with the capacity to do something about it can have those faults brought to their attention and be set upon a path of actually doing something about them. So I see nothing wrong with the coalition raising the problems that exist in the construction industry, particularly in Canberra but in all industries across Australia. There is nothing wrong with pointing out those problems. Quite the opposite, it is our job to do so. Senator Burns does not seem to understand that it is the Government's job to respond in some sort of constructive way, not in an emotive or abusive way, about what it is going to do about it. That would seem to me to be a positive way of handling this matter.

It is true that in raising this matter of public importance we have chosen to concentrate on the Quadrant building dispute in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). We have done so not because it is the only dispute that one could pick but because it happens to be a current and topical dispute. It is a dispute with which undoubtedly many members of this chamber are familiar as a consequence of reading the Canberra Times in a way that they would not be if we picked a dispute of a lesser nature in another State. That is not to say that the Quadrant dispute is the only one or that it has a higher priority than others. But it is a dispute which is before us at the moment and which, therefore, is worth addressing in this debate.

The Government's response thus far to the Quadrant dispute has been for the parties to behave reasonably. I understand that Minister Punch put out a Press release in which he said that both parties to this dispute ought to come to their senses, stop this petty squabbling and childish fighting, sit around the table, work out their differences and get on with the industry in Canberra. I only wish that Minister Punch had offered that advice to the participants in this debate thus far. It is my view that the contribution of Government senators has been one of squabbling and childish fighting. I will come to Senator Cook's contribution later. It is a pity that Government senators have not applied their Minister's advice to the contribution that they have made in this debate. Government senators have made a pathetic and inadequate response to the situation surrounding the Quadrant dispute which is the subject of the debate we have raised today. As we have said, there is no difficulty in prescribing the remedy. The Government put it in the May 1987 Bill and the Opposition has it in a private member's Bill which is before the Senate. It is simply a matter of the Government not wishing to face the problem full on.

You may recall, Mr Acting Deputy President, that Senator Cook set himself up as an arbiter of whether there was a case to answer, or whether Senator Stone had made a good enough case for the Government to bother to respond to. He said that there was not a good enough case to respond to and then proceeded to respond. Thus, he placed himself in a somewhat illogical position. The main point that I understood Senator Cook wanted to make was that the coalition did not come to this debate with clean hands. He said that our industrial relations record had been far worse than that of the Government and therefore, with dirtier hands than the Government, we had no right to raise the matter. Clearly that is a ridiculous proposition to put forward in the first place, but let me turn to the record on this matter. I would like Senator McMullan, if he has time in his speech, to address some of his remarks to the point I am about to make.

It is true that there has been a reduction in the industrial dispute statistics, especially when one looks at the number of working days lost. The number of working days lost has fallen. However, what is not recorded in those statistics is the number of disputes which involve bans and limitations. These do not show up in the statistics but can be extraordinarily damaging. I am informed that those sorts of disputes approximately doubled between 1982 and 1986 and have remained at an extraordinarily high level. Given that Senator Cook raised the matter of industrial dispute statistics and chose to concentrate-as I understood him-on the question of the fall in the number of working days lost, I would appreciate Senator McMullan addressing in his speech the question of the rise in the number of disputes involving bans and limitations, which can be just as costly, if not more costly, than working days lost.

In addition, Senator McMullan may wish to put forward some sort of explanation of why the Government claims that the fall in industrial disputation is a consequence of its capacity to handle industrial relations, when the figures show that between 1980 and 1985 working days lost due to industrial disputation fell internationally. In Australia, the fall was 62 per cent; in West Germany, 73 per cent; in the United States of America, 64 per cent; in France, 56 per cent; in Italy, 77 per cent; in the United Kingdom, 46 per cent; and in Canada, 65 per cent. It is not as though Australia is alone in having a fall in industrial disputation. In his contribution Senator McMullan might like to explain why Senator Cook seems to think that this fall is purely a consequence of this Government's efforts.

With respect to the Quadrant site, the Government has said that the employers should seek use of the bans clause option, which I understand they have now done. But the Minister should not come into this chamber and suggest that the employers should take up an option and proceed as far as they can before this Government is prepared to turn its mind to the role it can play in improving industrial relations across Australia and, in particular, the ACT. I remind Government senators of the words of their Minister, the then Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis), who had this to say about the present bans clause provisions in relation to the Industrial Relations Bill which he introduced on 14 May last year:

The principal initiative is that the present bans clause provisions, which have long since fallen into disrepute and are now substantially moribund, will be replaced by a new direction and injunction process.

So, the Minister responsible for these matters says that the bans clauses are totally ineffective and that, if he had his way, they would be thrown out and a more effective system would be introduced. Yet honourable senators opposite still say, `Oh, well, that's good enough for the employers; that's the path that they can follow and until they follow that, we are really not going to worry too much about what they have to say'.

The other point that Senator Cook tried to make was that the coalition, in presenting this argument, had concentrated on three disputes: Dollar Sweets, the new Parliament House site and the Quadrant site. By some feat of gymnastics in logic, he seemed to say that therefore the case was not good enough. He said, in effect, that the coalition needed to present a long list of cases before the Government would be prepared to listen. That is clearly an inappropriate way to suggest that Parliament should behave because, by the time we listed all the industrial relations problems that we could list in order to substantiate the case, there would be no time left for us to put forward further elements of the debate. I noticed that Senator Cook did not deny that these problems have existed and do exist.

Senator McMullan might like to make some comment on the effectiveness of industrial relations in the ACT and what he thinks about the number of times people cannot catch the bus to work because of disputes and the number of problems in the ACT Health Authority. I am not sure whether he listened to Senator Reid. She referred to many more examples, admittedly concentrating on the ACT. She referred to the August 1987 social workers' strike over pay anomalies, the September 1987 dispute between the Professional Officers Association and the Health Authority, and problems with the garbage services and nurses in the ACT in that same month. In October there were problems with the doctors in the ACT and bans on freight deliveries by members of the Transport Workers Union. There was a health inspectors ban over pay and conditions and a demarcation dispute between three unions at the ACT Electricity Authority and a printers' dispute. Again, in October there was a strike by technical and further education teachers over work claims. In October-November there were bans by the Hospital Employees Federation of Australia over the collection of hospital waste. Senator Burns made the point that in Senator Reid's speech there was no reference to who was right and who was wrong. TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what your matter of public importance says. It does not say, `It could be anybody's fault; we are not sure'. It blames the unions.

SPEECH.PARA: I could go on and give some other interesting examples of things which have happened; threats about demonstrations when I-
