TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to fall into the trap of letting somebody else dictate the agenda of the matters which I ought to address, but I am confronted with an interesting question to start with. The question is: Why is this matter before us today? There has been no new information. All we have had is a rather turgid tour of a number of old and well worn cliches and the stringing together of a few non-analysed and isolated examples without any reference as to why any of those examples which were listed by my colleague Senator Reid did or did not constitute an abuse of power by unions, employers or whatever. It really has been a very limited attempt to establish a case of what the matter of public importance describes as `an abuse of power by trade unions' but which was not really addressed in the proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: So why is this matter before us? Is it that somehow or other this is the biggest issue in Australia today? That is obviously not the reason. I suspect that it is a diversion. Senator Stone is raising this matter because he is not allowed to talk about tax any more; the various parties in the coalition cannot agree on media ownership. The coalition's policy on constitutional reform is divided and it has to start making up things that it knows to be untrue about constitutional reform proposals. Its members have to be quiet about industry policy in the hope that, if they do not say anything, both sides might think they agree with them. This is not, by any measure, the biggest issue in Australia today. Has the matter been brought on for discussion simply because strikes are suddenly getting out of hand? Obviously that is not the case. I know that people do not like it when figures show that disputes in Australia are falling by 60 per cent. They like to quote things slightly out of context and make bold assertions that other things that cannot be measured are getting worse. It is a case of, `I can't prove it, but if you would like to respond to it, I would be very pleased'. I am sure that they would be very pleased, but it would be a waste of my time when I could be pursuing the substantial question of the Opposition's failure to establish its case. Senator McLean made a most effective analysis of Senator Stone's remarks and established quite clearly that no case to answer had been proposed.

Perhaps there is another reason why this matter has been raised. Perhaps the Opposition thinks that the Government has not done anything about industrial relations in the building and construction industry or about industrial relations in general. Of course, we negotiated the 1987 building agreement which contained a number of elements designed to significantly reduce lost time and improve efficiency and productivity. In any industry that has had a very long history of industrial relations difficulties, there are no magic wands. This matter will be solved by neither magic wands nor big sticks. These new provisions have been in operation for only a few months and they need more time to be bedded down, but they do appear to be making a significant contribution to the improvement of industrial relations in the building industry nationally.

A number of other positive developments are going on. Union amalgamations have occurred and others are at an advanced stage. These will improve substantially the potential for the sensible management of industrial relations in a number of industries, including the building industry. The 1987 building agreement set up the restructuring sub-committee which is examining the very important question of award classifications, productivity and training. We are starting to get positive proposals from the Government, not a litany of sad excuses. The Construction Industry Council, under the chairmanship of the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones), is also looking at developments in the industry. Furthermore, as Senator Cook said, there is a major inquiry into the building and construction industry to which matters of general concern can be referred. If the problem really is one of some misuse of power by the trade unions, the Industrial Relations Bill contains tougher sanctions against corrupt practices by union officials-not that we think that they are frequent; there is no evidence of that, but there is some evidence that they have occurred. That is a cause of concern and the Government is acting to resolve that matter. I reiterate that the only reason I am not surprised that this matter comes before us is that the Opposition is probably in desperate need of a diversion.

I now turn to the substance of the matter, as it relates to the ACT in general and Quadrant in particular-we did not hear anything else about the building industry in the ACT-and the suggested failure to address it. What does the Opposition propose? Some reference was made to Senator Chaney's Bill. Senators from the Liberal and National parties are concerned that there are only two big sticks with which to hit unions, not three. They want to have triple jeopardy. They could have penalties under common law, the Trade Practices Act and some new penalty introduced in Senator Chaney's Bill. They fail to understand the internal logic of the 1987 proposal of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) which would not have allowed that triple jeopardy to occur. The Liberal and National parties want to introduce a Bill by Senator Chaney that will let an employer appeal against a refusal of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission member to give a direction but will not let a union appeal against the direction itself. They want to set up a Bill that has no maximum penalty for a breach of an injunction. As I have said, they want to establish the triple jeopardy option and proceed with a lopsided approach, going back to the old destructive adversarial behaviour which they love so much. That shows the total deficiencies of their approach to industrial relations.

What distinguishes my capacity to speak on the Quadrant dispute in the Australian Capital Territory from that of those who have spoken in this debate is that I have actually spoken to the people involved. I have spoken to the employers, not just to the association that purports to represent them. I have spoken to the association, the employers, the unions and the workers on the job. I have been to the site and have looked at it. I have examined the facts of the situation. I do not, as Senator Vanstone does, just read the Canberra Times and hope that it will contain something useful. In my discussions with representatives of the employers they have made it absolutely clear that they do not want the Government to become directly involved in resolving the dispute. Quite sensibly and properly, they want the normal, proper processes of industrial relations to solve the dispute. The conciliation process, which no-one has bothered to mention in this debate, regarding the dispute in question is continuing directly between the unions at a territorial and national level and the employer, White Industries Ltd. I understand that as recently as last week further proposals were put forward arising from that process of conciliation, including the good offices of Commissioner Baird. Those proposals may not in themselves lead to an immediate settlement of the dispute, which everybody would welcome, but they do indicate that the process is continuing and that it would be entirely inappropriate for the Government to come in with a big stick, thumping one side in the dispute, which was the failed Liberal Party tactic of industrial relations during its all too long seven years in office.

People involved in this debate should be aware of the appropriate activities that the Government is taking at three levels to deal with the question that is raised. With regard to the specific dispute, the conciliation process is continuing and that is the only way in which, in the end, the dispute will be solved. With regard to the broader issues of possible misuse and inappropriate activities by individuals, whoever they may be and on whichever side they may be in the building industry in general, a Full Bench inquiry is proceeding to which all parties have made submissions and to which people involved in this dispute have been urged to make submissions. If illegal activities are being undertaken, there is the police power to examine and prosecute. As Senator Button has made clear in the Senate previously, if there are activities appropriate for the attention of the police, that is the place to which they should be referred. All those processes are under way. The tragedy for the Opposition is that if only it knew anything about this dispute and the general situation in the building industry, which it does not, it would know that the Government has all the resources at its disposal properly in train.

I am aware of and concerned about the comments of Commissioner Baird on 26 February. Like Senator Burns, I know and have a very high regard for Commissioner Baird. He is a person with a long history of involvement in industrial relations. When he expresses concerns, I take it very seriously. It is very interesting that today in the Senate we have this breathless urgency about matters raised by Commissioner Baird 10 or 11 weeks ago. Suddenly it has become a matter of public importance that a very respected former union official and now arbitration commissioner raised some matters of concern 11 weeks ago. Those important questions have been addressed quite properly and, in many instances, have been referred to the police, for general inquiry, or continue to be the subject of conciliation. So how does it suddenly become a matter of public and breathless importance before us today?

In this debate there was some passing reference to the question of corrupt payments. I have to say two things about that: firstly, at this stage it has not been established that this has taken place and, secondly, it always seems to be ignored in such questions that if corrupt payments are being received somebody is making corrupt payments. It certainly cannot be, as the matter of public importance implies, that this is solely a problem concerning the trade unions. Nobody has ever been bribed by himself. A person can be bribed only by somebody else; it takes two. If that problem exists, it should be investigated properly. It is not a question of saying that there are terrible workers out there who are absolutely abusing their position. There is certainly no indication that any trade union has ever at any stage endorsed a unionist taking such payments. If they are being made, they are not supported by the trade union movement. They are certainly not supported by this Government, nor should they be. Firstly, the evidence has to be presented and, secondly, there has to be some indication why this constitutes an abuse of union power. If the unions had the power they would stop those practices.

Were there other corrupt or illegal practices? There has been no sign that the police have found evidence of any. If they do find evidence, the proper legal processes should take their course. Although the matter has been referred to the police, somewhat belatedly, by the people who have made the allegations, there have been no indications that there is such evidence. I think that we have had a very one-sided approach by the Opposition today. In regard to Quadrant we have had essentially the reading of a series of Master Builders Association Press releases into the Hansard in the pretence that this constitutes analysis. There is no indication that anyone has spoken to anyone else-not even to the employer directly concerned in this dispute, let alone to the union or the workers.

I do not want to take all the 15 minutes allocated to me. The contribution from honourable senators opposite has not been worth that much time. In summary, I would like to say that the Government has in place a comprehensive range of initiatives dealing with the specific issues in this dispute. If the allegations are true-this has not been proved; merely asserted-they are neither typical, which the matter of public importance implies, nor an abuse of trade union power by the trade union movement, which does not support such practices. There may be some criminal activity by one or two individuals, if that can be established. I think that here we have a failed attempt at diverting the attention of the Senate. It is a sad waste of the Senate's valuable time when we have all gathered here to try to deal with the necessary and important business that the Australian people call upon us to do. I hope that in future when we have to deal with matters of public importance they are indeed matters of substance and matters of importance.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMUNITY SERVICES AND HEALTH LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Tate) agreed to:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Bill will amend the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954, the National Health Act 1953, the States Grants (Nurses Education Transfer Assistance) Act 1985 and the Australian Institute of Health Act 1987. The major purpose of this Bill is to introduce new nursing and personal care staffing and related funding arrangements in nursing homes. It also provides for improved respite care. These measures will enable better targeting of Commonwealth funding to those aged people most in need of residential care and will achieve greater efficiency and equity in Commonwealth funding of nursing homes. The Bill also provides for increased freedom of choice for members of health insurance funds currently locked into a single health benefits organisation. This will be done by removing existing impediments to transfer between such organisations.

SPEECH.PARA: Over the past 10 years, major criticisms of the nursing home program have been made by representatives of the industry, aged people, unions, Commonwealth parliamentary committees and other representative bodies. The criticisms have covered a broad range of matters, including unfair distribution of taxpayers' funds between facilities; the significantly varying levels of staffing between individual residents, homes, industry sectors and States; poor standards of care provided in many nursing homes; the amount of nursing and personal care funded in nursing home bore little relationship to the actual care needs for residents; the lack of flexibility in the nursing home arrangements and the absence of incentives for improving efficiency in management; and the growth in expenditure which has characterised the nursing home program over many years and the resultant high costs to residents and the taxpayer.

The Government has responded to these very serious criticisms in a positive way. The Government outlined early in 1986 an integrated program of reform of residential care services for aged people. The program of reform has been undertaken on a phased basis to ensure that the process of adjustment was smooth and to avoid disruption of the care of the 110,000 frail aged residents and the employment of the tens of thousands of dedicated people providing that care.

In the 1986-87 Budget and subsequently, the Government has provided significant additional resources to implement the strategy. Initiatives taken in the first three stages of the reform process have included a needs based planning system for expansion of nursing home and hostel places, development of geriatric assessment services, new quality of life and quality of care standards in nursing homes, increased hostel recurrent funding and new flexible arrangements for the capital funding of new hostels. Also, as part of this process, the first major step was taken to introduce an equitable national standard funding approach to financing nursing home care with the transition phase to be completed in 1991. The first element of this process, the standardisation of infrastructure costs, commenced on 1 July 1987.

This Bill will enable the implementation of much of the fourth stage of the reform strategy and will do much to enhance the care of the aged. The package of reforms includes a range of measures to improve the quality of care for nursing home residents by a substantive increase in total funding for needed nurses; linking Commonwealth funding to the needs of individual nursing home residents, based on national nursing and personal care standards and resident classification; further increases in funding for geriatric assessment, gerontic nurse training and nurse reskilling; special provisions to support small nursing homes and, where appropriate, to help them restructure and rationalise their management; creation of an additional 4000 respite care places by 1995 and a supplementary respite care benefit.

To help ensure that nursing home care is affordable by all Australians who need it, this package of reforms will provide that, by 1991, residents will no longer face the burden of substantial fees over and above the statutory minimum resident contribution of 87.5 per cent of the pension plus rental assistance. There will also be funding for a crackdown on fraudulent practices engaged in by a small minority of nursing home proprietors. These reforms aim at higher quality care for residents in nursing homes throughout Australia by giving the management of each home flexibility in the use of its nursing and personal care staff to tailor services provided to the individual needs of each resident. For the first time in Australia this Government initiative, foreshadowed in 1987, will link Commonwealth funding for nursing homes to the needs of individual nursing home residents.

In developing the package, the Government recognised that a significant input was required from service providers and community organisations if the objectives were to be achieved. To this end extensive consultations have taken place with service providers, consumer and welfare organisations, unions and State governments on the package. The Government sees this consultative and participative approach as vital and will ensure the closer involvement of these groups also in the monitoring and review of the new arrangements.

The Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) will also shortly announce new approvals totalling around $80m for funding of 3,000 hostel and 500 nursing homes places to help expand hostel care generally and fill serious gaps in the network of nursing home services. Geriatric assessment services are helping to ensure that aged people receive proper professional help in finding the type of services which best meets their needs. As a result people are not going into nursing homes when there are alternatives which better meet their requirements. Increasingly, nursing home care will be targeted at more highly dependent people. Commonwealth spending on nursing and personal care staffing has increased by 38 per cent in money terms from $420m in 1985-86 to an estimated $580m in 1987-88. It is essential that these substantial resources be targeted to those most in need of care through the implementation of the proposed national nursing and personal care standards.

These arrangements, provided for in the Bill, are based on the recommendations of the Commonwealth-State working party on nursing home standards established in 1986 to provide advice on these issues. The Minister has paid tribute to the State and Territory governments and their representatives who played such an important role in developing the new arrangements in conjunction with the Commonwealth and the nursing home industry. I support these sentiments.

There will be a direct link between the service needs of nursing home residents and approved staffing levels. Staffing levels will be established on the basis of categorisation of individual residents; that is, a specified staffing level will be approved for each resident per week. This staffing level will be uniform for a resident with a given service need level across Australia and will entail a redistribution of both funds and hours across the whole non-government aged nursing home sector. There will also be a deliberate targeting of resources to those most in need of nursing and personal care services.

The standardisation of nursing and personal care staffing hours and costs will increase the level of financial control for the Commonwealth and will provide, for the first time, a sound, equitable and efficient basis for determining staffing levels. While nursing and personal care staff hours will be uniform across Australia, the hourly rates at which they are reimbursed will of course be consistent with different State award rates. No longer will the Commonwealth simply set fees to reimburse whatever the nursing home happens to incur on staffing levels.

Under the new arrangements nursing homes which spend more than the amount determined through the nursing and personal care staffing standards arrangements, plus a small tolerance, will not be permitted to impose that excess cost on their residents or on the taxpayer.

Under the new categorisation arrangements, a resident classification instrument (RCI) will be completed by a geriatric assessment service or the director of nursing in each home, in respect of each person newly admitted or to be admitted on or after 1 July 1988, to permit such a person to be classified into one of five categories, depending on the assessed level of care they need. There is provision for review by the Secretary of the Department of Community Services and Health and by the Minister. The Bill also provides for each category to be allocated a specific number of nursing and personal care staff hours, which will be used in calculating nursing home fees. A fee will also be set for the existing unclassified residents.

The Bill amends the National Health Act 1953 to provide that a resident contribution will be set. Existing residents will not be required to pay more under the new arrangements than they would have under the current system. Also, under the new arrangements, the amount a resident pays will not increase as fees increase as under the current arrangements. This will provide greater certainty for residents and remove a cause of serious concern, particularly as over 80 per cent of residents rely solely on the pension.

The Bill provides for transitional arrangements which allow any necessary adjustment to be undertaken gradually. These arrangements will also include assistance for small nursing homes. For example, the Minister for Housing and Aged Care intends to allow small nursing homes the choice of either joining the new system from 1 July 1988 or waiting until 1 March 1989. Small homes, even though they account for only 5 per cent of beds, are an important part of the industry, particularly in remote areas. In the past, they have been relatively highly staffed for their residency dependency levels. It may also be necessary to provide assistance for some small homes to restructure or to supplement the resources of those small homes which need to remain small, for example those in remote areas or catering for Aboriginal or ethnic groups. All homes will be able to take advantage from the outset of the increased flexibility that the new system will give them to manage their resources more effectively.

Since residents in the highest categories of service need attract the greatest resource levels, almost all homes will overall have scope for further increasing their staffing resourcing by admitting such residents. By the end of the transition period, the funded staffing levels for about two-thirds of all nursing home residents will have risen. All residents should benefit from the capacity of nursing home management to draw flexibly on their approved hours to provide special services including the various therapies whenever these are required.

The Bill also provides for the monitoring of the accuracy of the resident classification instruments submitted by the nursing homes, and the reclassification of residents where necessary. Measures will also be able to be taken under the financial arrangements principles to ensure that nursing homes do not routinely use nursing and personal care staff, whose cost is directly reimbursed to the home, to carry out the tasks of other staff whose costs are intended to be met by the standard grant under infrastructure cost funding arrangements.

In implementing these changes, the Minister intends that an additional hour per resident per week of nursing and personal care be provided nationally across the board. In particular, this extra time will allow homes to provide increased therapy services to their residents, services which are sadly lacking under the present arrangements. It will also allow for increases in in-service training to maintain and develop staff skills. Both these elements are critical to the provision of high quality care.

The Minister proposes to make allowance for 24-hour coverage to be provided by a registered general nurse in all homes and nursing and personal care administration time for each home's director of nursing. These proposals recognise the importance of professional nursing in the provision of high quality care, and that more effective management of staffing resources will lead to more efficient and effective care provision. The introduction of the nursing and personal care arrangements will result in a net increase of some 2,000 jobs nationally by the end of 1989.

The Government is concerned that some 23 per cent of nursing home residents across Australia are required to pay more than the statutory contribution of 87.5 per cent of pension plus rent assistance. Nursing home costs are such that these aged people pay, on average, about $1,600 extra each year, creating financial hardship for many. The reforms contained in this package reaffirm the Government's commitment that by 1991 no resident will be required to contribute more than the statutory contribution.

The only exception to this would be the small number of aged people with substantial assets or income who wish to pay for care and accommodation outside these funding arrangements. A small proportion of non-government nursing homes for the aged, comprising up to 6 per cent of the beds in each State, will be permitted to charge residents an additional contribution to that which would otherwise be payable. The Commonwealth benefit normally payable for these homes will be reduced by a minimum of 50c in the dollar for each dollar by which the unregulated fee exceeds the fee which would otherwise be charged. Nursing homes wishing to qualify for these arrangements will be subject to selection by tender. This proposal provides flexibility for service providers who wish to cater for patients who wish to purchase a higher level of accommodation or services. These arrangements modify those previously foreshadowed last year reflecting the views of industry, consumer and union groups, expressed in subsequent consultations. Legislation to implement this proposal will be brought forward for consideration in the Budget sittings.

The Government is committed to the provision of respite care services as part of its strategy of responding positively to the care needs of aged people. Respite care is essential to prolong the length of time frail aged people can continue to live in the community among family and friends. Respite care is also critical in providing support, relief, and stress reduction for carers of frail aged people. This Bill proposes amendments to the National Health Act 1953 and the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954 to increase the availability of respite care services in nursing homes and hostels and to make these services more accessible to aged people. The long term objective is two places per 1,000 aged persons in both hostels and nursing homes with an additional 4,000 places available by 1995.

The Bill enables regulations to be made that provide for a payment of a respite care supplement in addition to the Commonwealth nursing home benefit and the Commonwealth subsidy to hostels. Nursing homes will receive a supplement based on a percentage of the standard infrastructure cost component of fees, which will be determined in writing by the Minister. The Minister proposes to set this supplement at 35 per cent of the standard infrastructure cost.

In hostels respite care subsidies will reflect the level of care. The current respite subsidy of $8.05 per day will be retained for `hostel care' level residents. For `personal care' level respite residents, there will be a payment of the personal care subsidy plus a supplement also based on a percentage of the personal care subsidy. This percentage will be set at 25 per cent. The supplement will be payable for 63 days for each recipient in a year and will provide an incentive for organisations to offer respite care services. Arrangements for approval of admission for respite and classification of patients will be in line with the arrangements applying to new admissions to permanent care.

The Bill also provides for persons involved with the provision of respite care not to provide false or misleading information consistent with similar amendments by Parliament for nursing homes and hostels in the Budget sittings of 1987. The Government has a continuing concern at the range of practices used by some residential care providers which may result in inflation of costs which must be met either by taxpayers or residents or both. The Government has agreed to provide additional resources for a continuing program to detect and prevent fraud.

The National Health Act is also amended to allow contributors to health insurance who wish to transfer from one health benefits organisation to another because of factors such as lower contribution rates and other benefits, to do so without having to face difficulties through the imposition of new waiting periods. These measures improve the freedom of choice for that half of Australia's population which currently has private health insurance. Members will be able to transfer from one organisation to another without the imposition of waiting periods, or with reduced waiting periods where part or whole of the waiting period has been served in the previous organisation.

Over the past decade a number of reports to Parliament have criticised the number of inappropriate admissions to nursing homes. The Government has responded to these criticisms by supporting the development of regional multidisciplinary geriatric assessment services to ensure that aged people seeking care could be fully assessed and advised of the most appropriate way of meeting their needs. It is now intended that these assessment services may approve admissions to specified nursing homes or nursing homes in a particular region. The insertion of a new provision into the National Health Act will enable this to be done.

The Bill also provides for the amendment of section 40ad of the National Health Act. This amendment will enable waiving of the 26 February 1988 deadline for proprietors to apply for fee increases resulting from costs that were incurred prior to 1 July 1987, but of which the proprietor did not become aware until too late to meet the 26 February 1988 deadline. This concession will be granted where the proprietor could not reasonably be expected to have made the application before 26 February 1988.

Clause 17 of the Bill would enable the approval of a proportion of a fee increase sought by a nursing home proprietor to overcome cash flow problems caused to proprietors where there are a significant number of fee applications awaiting processing.

Provision is made in Part III of the Bill to amend the Australian Institute of Health Act 1987 to clarify a cross-reference and to remove an unnecessary provision relating to the making of annual reports. Part V of the Bill seeks to amend the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Act 1987 caused by the wording of a transitional provision. Part VI of the Bill Provides for the amendment of the States Grants (Nurse Education Transfer Assistance) Act 1985 to simplify the process of appropriating moneys for the purposes of that scheme.

The new hostel respite care arrangements under the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954 are expected to cost an additional $1.9m in 1988-89, $3.4m in 1989-90 and $5.2m in 1990-91. The new financial arrangements for nursing homes and related arrangements are expected to result in increased expenditure of $17.6m in 1988-89, $44.7m in 1989-90 and $58.7m in 1990-91. There is no financial impact upon the amendments to the Australian Institute of Health Act 1987, the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Act 1987 and the States Grants (Nurse Education Transfer Assistance) Act 1985. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

The speech read as follows-

This Bill, together with its companion bills, Supply Bill (No. 2) 1988-89 and Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1988-89, seeks interim appropriations for the services of the Government for the period 1 July 1988 to 30 November 1988, by which date it is expected that the equivalent Appropriation Bills, which will form part of the Budget for 1988-89, will have been enacted.

Supply Bill (No. 1) seeks appropriations totalling some $8,689m for the ordinary annual services of the Government. This is $37m, or about 0.4 per cent, greater than the equivalent amounts provided in the Supply Act (No. 1) 1987-88.
A significant part of the increase reflects commitments which have been approved by the Government, price and cost increases and exchange rate variations.

Major increases are: $125.3m for Department of Defence running costs, largely reflecting the flow-on of national wage case determinations and second tier awards from 1987-88 and transfer of defence removal costs from other appropriations; $32.6m to meet higher rate of student allowances and higher numbers of students qualifying for the Austudy benefits; $25.5m for the program for families with children due to the large full year effects of new services coming on-stream in 1987-88, the finalisation of capital grant projects under the 20,000 places commitment and indexation for cost increases; $24.3m for the program for aged people who need residential assistance reflecting the transfer of funding for approved services for non-nursing home residents from a standing appropriation, increased capital grant expenditure under the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954 and the Government's decision to increase special and geriatric assessment services.

The running costs appropriations of departments have been adjusted to include the salaries costs of departmental secretaries and other relevant officeholders. At present these salaries are met from a special appropriation established under the Remuneration Tribunals Act 1973. This change, which has been cleared from a legal point of view, aligns departmental running costs `appropriations' with departmental running costs `budgets'.
Finally, the Government has moved amendments to the Supply Bills (Nos 1 and 2) 1988-89 and the Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1988-89 in the House of Representatives.

These amendments are necessary to overcome restrictions on the use of the advances to the Minister for Finance, the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives brought to notice by a recent legal opinion on the interpretation of the `urgent' and `unforeseen' criteria which must be met before an issue can be made from the contingency advances. The advances are provisions authorised by the annual Appropriation and Supply Acts and are necessary for the smooth running of a government because they provide flexibility, particularly for urgent and unforeseen expenditures.

The current wording was introduced into Appropriation Acts on the recommendation of the 1979 report of the Senate Committee on Finance and Government Operations on the Advance to the Minister for Finance.

However, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts during the course of its most recent inquiry into the Advance to the Minister for Finance, has obtained legal advice from the Attorney-General's Department which indicates that where, due to clerical error or inadvertence only, an amount for an expenditure has been omitted from an Appropriation Bill, that amount cannot be regarded as unforeseen and, therefore, should not be funded from the AMF.

It has been assumed by successive governments that the criteria for the use of the advances does not preclude a situation where expenditure was foreseen but through clerical error or inadvertence no provision was made in the relevant Supply or Appropriation Act. The AMF and the subsequent advances to the President and Speaker have been administered on this basis prior to and after the introduction of the present working.

In order to overcome the restriction on the use of the advances recently brought to notice by the legal advising it is necessary that the clauses relating to the advances in the Supply Bills (Nos 1 and 2) 1988-89 and the Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1988-89 be amended to reflect the intention that clerical inadvertence be regarded as unforeseen. The only alternative to this course of action would be to introduce, for urgent passage, additional Appropriation Bills to meet each occurrence of an omission of an amount in relevant Appropriation Bills, where a government was inextricably committed to meet payments.

The Parliament will be provided with details of amounts issued from the Advance to the Minister for Finance to cover errors and omissions by the addition of this category to those currently shown in the monthly tabling of issues from the Advance to the Minister for Finance. This document is tabled pursuant to recommendations in the previously mentioned 1979 report of the Senate Committee on Finance on Government Operations.

The last amendment required for the Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1988-89 is to increase the supply funding for the Parliamentary Reporting Staff. An amount of $935,000 was omitted from the Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1988-89 in respect of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff.
