TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Australian Rifle Club Regulations (Repeal), as contained in Statutory Rules 1988 No. 17 and made under the Defence Act 1903, be disallowed.

We believe that the Australian Rifle Club Regulations (Repeal) as contained in Statutory Rules 1988, No. 17, made under the Defence Act 1903, should be disallowed. To recapitulate a little, I inform honourable senators that since 1903, under the Defence Act, the Commonwealth Government has had responsibility for the supervision of rifle clubs and associations throughout Australia. The link between the Federal Government, in particular the Department of Defence, and rifle clubs and associations is an historical one, there being a strong belief in the need for a prepared and trained civilian defence force to supplement the regular defence forces. It is clear that the Government no longer thinks that this is a matter of any validity. Under this statutory rule, notified in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette, Special No. S 56 on 25 February 1988, the Government has repealed the Australian Rifle Club Regulations, breaking an 85-year-old tradition.

It is necessary to examine some of the reasons that might lie behind this action. There is no logical reason for the Federal Government abrogating its responsibilities in this way and changing the arrangement-passing control of these clubs and associations back to the States. In fact, this runs quite contrary to the Federal Government's present attitude towards firearms which, given the much talked about gun summit of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), is very much that firearms control is a matter in which the Commonwealth should involve itself. One of the portions of the Prime Minister's statement after the gun summit, dated 22 December 1987, was to the effect that the meeting had noted the advances made in the Australian Police Ministers Council towards achieving uniformity. This was the one area of gun control where there was uniformity. On the one hand the Australian Labor Party seemed to be most anxious to be seen to be taking a responsible attitude towards gun control-it seemed to enjoy the media coverage it was getting at that time-but at the same time it was attempting to wriggle out of its responsibilities to have a supervisory role and control of rifle clubs and associations.

What has been done? As a result of the repeal of the rifle club regulations and orders under the Defence Act, which it has been said will come into effect on about 30 June, from that date it will be necessary for all rifle clubs to comply with the State or Territory law relating to their place of residence. Many problems would arise from these changes. One which is a practical problem for those who enjoy shooting as a sport-in passing I might say that Australian sportsmen have had considerable success in this area of sporting activity-is that the carriage of firearms across State and Territory borders would be extremely difficult. A rifleman who lived in Western Australia and who wanted to take part in the national Queen's competition in the Australian Capital Territory who decided that he would drive across, perhaps bringing his family with him to make a holiday of it, would need of course to have his Western Australian licence or permit. He would need a South Australian licence or permit if he travelled with his rifle in his vehicle across South Australia. If he took a certain route he could require a Victorian licence or permit and a New South Wales licence or permit and, finally of course, an Australian Capital Territory licence or permit to enable him to take part in the event in Canberra. Or, for example, an Australian Capital Territory shooter, who would go out of the Australian Capital Territory many times a year, would take part in competitions in New South Wales and Victoria and perhaps further afield. He would finish up with a whole range of licences and, without uniformity, if each State merely has its own licences and permits arrangements, this could make it extremely difficult for the sport to continue. Many shooters visit other States several times in a year. This highlights the desirability of reasonable and sensible uniform legislation so that this absurd situation does not arise.

The former New South Wales Government indicated that it did not quite know how it was going to deal with this problem of sportsmen travelling from one State to another. It looked as though shooters would have to have a licence for every State or Territory that they entered. As a result of the election of the Greiner Government in New South Wales it seems that a more rational attitude towards gun laws is prevailing and the Government has indicated its intention to retain the reciprocity arrangements with other States or Territories where shooters are licensed but that has not yet come into being. The Australian Rifle Club Regulations were the only form of uniform firearms legislation in existence, albeit depending on the National Rifle Association for satisfactory implementation. But nothing put forward by the Government indicates that that was in any way unsatisfactory. Neither the rifle club movement nor its individual members have abused the privileges bestowed by the regulations which, as I indicated, have been in existence since 1903. In spite of this, the Labor Government has simply decided for no apparent logical reason to destroy the legislation which has worked well for the last 85 years, to destroy the one element of uniformity which exists.

It is recognised that there probably need to be some changes. The shadow Minister, Peter White, attempted to talk to the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) and wrote to him without any success. We recognise that there are issues to be discussed and we would be anxious to talk to the Government about them but that has not been possible until now. By disallowing these regulations, we hope that the Government will enter into discussions and eventually come forth with a package which has the well-being of the clubs in mind, as well as the need for the security the Government talks about.

One of the other potential problems relates to the inspection and certification of the rifle ranges. In the past regular inspections have been carried out about every three years by an officer, appointed by the Minister, who is called the inspector of rifle ranges. He issues a certificate of safety if he is satisfied that the range comes up to the required standard laid down for classification by the Department of Defence. With the repeal of these regulations, the inspections will be carried out by an officer delegated by the State or Territory government in which the range is situated. We may well have a situation where different arrangements apply for every range.

There have been suggestions that the former New South Wales Government planned to increase the safety area by about 200 per cent. That would have closed down all but about two rifle ranges in New South Wales. It seems clear that the former Labor Government in New South Wales, aided and abetted by the Federal Government in repealing these regulations, was attempting to wipe out the sport, proposing to increase the safety area merely as a device to achieve that.

Many thousands of sports men and women use the ranges for recreational and sport purposes. It is my view that there should be ranges where they can enjoy their sport. The clubs that I know of go to great lengths to look after the young people who want to be involved in shooting, to see that they are channelled into the clubs, that they are taught safety and responsibility in firearms, and that they do not enjoy their shooting by driving around the countryside firing at road signs and other things. The Government's attitude has totally ignored the responsible approach that the clubs have taken in the past.

I understand that now the New South Wales Government has a working group of defence, police and shooting club representatives looking at the best way of dealing with the rifle ranges with a view to ensuring that they continue to operate. This may mean that ultimately there will be different standards, but that ought to be avoided if possible. I believe that if the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, took a leadership role in this area he could achieve the uniformity that he seems to want, and perhaps the arrangements for clubs could operate better than they have done in the past. We do not believe that this in any way would compromise public safety. There have been no incidents to date on any of the ranges complying with the old regulations which suggest that there is a need for new regulation in the safety area of the clubs. That is not a credible explanation.

With the repeal of the regulations, additional problems are created for the clubs with respect to club rifles. Club rifles are used and made available for new members. They have been essential in recruitment drives. This ensures that new members of rifle clubs learn responsibility with firearms long before they start buying firearms themselves, the sorts of weapons they would use as competitors on the ranges.

In the Australian Capital Territory it would also be necessary for courses to be conducted in firearms safety, as has been proposed in the new gun ordinance. I hope that the ordinance in the Australian Capital Territory is being reviewed in relation to what it was going to be earlier this year. Prior to this year there were discussions about changing the Australian Capital Territory ordinance. Most of the people I have talked to who knew something about it were pleased with the arrangements coming into effect and were quite happy with the changes that were proposed. But that was not the case once the heated environment of the New South Wales election took over.

In recent times one of the problems with the Federal Government's changes to Australian Capital Territory gun laws has been a general lack of information available to those most concerned about their impact. The rifle club here is not certain how those provisions would operate for the holding of rifle club licences in the future. The rifle clubs' administration of course would be adversely affected by the changes. They would be put to considerable trouble administratively by the repeal of the regulations, rewriting constitutions, rules, by-laws and competition laws to eliminate all reference to regulations and constitutions. The Rifle Association would also be affected. None of that impact seems to have been taken into account by the Government. It is not impossible to make these sorts of changes, but the necessity for doing so has not been clearly defined. I believe it is important that these regulations be defeated, that the disallowance motion be supported, and that the opportunity be left for the Government to reappraise what should occur, to discuss the matter with the Rifle Association, with the Opposition and with people who are concerned about the degree of safety.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would not understand it. You have understood none of it so far. There would be a very low entry level if we had to discuss it with you.
—I did not hear what the Minister said.
—It does not matter.

—I am saying that we believe there should be discussion with those involved, with the people who are concerned and with the Opposition, which has an interest in this. The shadow Minister attempted to talk to the Minister for Defence. He wrote to the Minister before the matter came up for debate in the Parliament, before the disallowance was moved, but that opportunity was not taken up. The Government wanted to go ahead with it in any event. It seems to be a knee-jerk reaction to some ghastly events which have taken place, and no-one denies that.
—It has nothing to do with that. These regulations were drawn up before those events, in effect.

—If they were drawn up that long ago, that makes it even more surprising that there has not been more discussion about their impact and what they are trying to do. If that is the case, I find it quite extraordinary.
—They were in the pipeline even when you were in government.
—In those days there were considerable discussions with the Rifle Association and the clubs concerned. I have a considerable file about the discussions that were taking place at the time.
—You did absolutely nothing about it.
—Is the honourable senator suggesting that I knew nothing about it?
—I am saying that the Liberal Government spent seven years doing nothing about it. It knew the regulations were a shambles.

—The Liberal Government was aware that the changes needed to be made, and discussions were going on. I certainly knew about it and my predecessor, John Knight, knew about it because it was his file, which I inherited, that first drew the matter to my attention. No-one is suggesting that there are not matters that ought to be revised, but this is a very ham-fisted way of dealing with them and it ought to be rejected. I believe it is an attack on responsible gun owners and users. If in fact it was all planned well before, the timing of the Government's bringing it forward was very poor indeed. It is clear now that Victoria has backed away from the draconian legislation that it was thinking about during the time of the New South Wales election. It is clear that the whole gun summit was some sort of reaction, like the tax summit and the drug summit. It was interesting to note the comment in the Australian that the first the South Australian Premier knew about it was from news reports. I suspect that that was probably the case, and that seemed to be so at the time.

SPEECH.PARA: Significant solutions are required to the whole area. Many of the problems in the social area have very little to do with guns or their availability, but are problems which cause these acts of violence to occur. Acts of violence are also carried out with motor cars and knives. In fact, the number of murders that take place with knives and other instruments is quite significant. None of us would deny that they are matters of great importance, but attacking gun clubs in this way will not make the slightest bit of difference to the way firearms are used in crimes and acts of violence of the kinds that have occurred. There is a lot of interest in my area in a new gun ordinance and in what is going on in the other States. The local clubs are not happy with the level of advice and information they have been receiving. They have had a good relationship with the Department of Defence and the situation has worked well for, as I have said, some 85 years. It would be a pity if the Government were not able to sit down and work out a satisfactory way of proceeding. It is my hope that these regulations will be disallowed and that the Government will embark upon the course I have suggested for the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will support this motion of disallowance. In doing so I would like to acknowledge the attempts on the part of the Minister and the Government to accommodate particular needs that the Democrats have in relation to the Australian Rifle Club Regulations. I believe we have had constructive dialogue and we are now faced with the possibility of resolving the difficulties and problems with all parties coming to the table fairly soon. That does not alter the fact, however, that we find ourselves supporting the motion of disallowance for reasons which I will now briefly elaborate on.

SPEECH.PARA: The eventual effect of the regulations would have been to transfer to the States the control of rifle clubs and associations, and we believe the ultimate effect would have been the closure of a considerable number of the controlled safe spaces where people are now able to use licensed weapons. The loss of such controlled safe spaces, we believe, would have encouraged people to use their weapons in uncontrolled and unsafe spaces, and that would have been contrary to the public interest.

We believe that this question can be viewed on two levels. The first is the effect on clubs and associations and their members, who have been very responsible. It would be difficult to cite a group in our community which has such an impeccable record for safety as that of these gun users. Yet they would have been the ones negatively affected by this particular regulation. However, we were more concerned with the effects in the broader context of gun control. In the past, the rifle clubs and associations have made a considerable point of the fact that through membership of clubs and associations people were able to acquire small arms skills which were put to very effective use indeed in two world wars. However, the situation has changed quite dramatically and we see rifle clubs and associations as providing the opportunity in the 1980s and into the 1990s for people to acquire small arms skills which will allow the safe and responsible use of small arms in times of peace.

The history of these clubs and associations is a very long and proud one. The National Rifle Association dates back to 1860. In fact, at the time of the First World War some 50,000 members of the Association in New South Wales alone enlisted to fight for their country. The Association's record in sporting attainments is a very proud one indeed. During two world wars six Victoria Cross winners came from clubs and associations. So, looking back on a proud history going back to 1860, it is little wonder that the clubs and associations are very concerned about a set of regulations which could dramatically truncate their membership and possibly deprive them of the majority of the spaces which they require to continue to function effectively as sporting organisations.

Under the Department of Defence a number of regulations have been in place over the period since 1901. Certainly the current regulations have gradually fallen into disuse. They are most inappropriate for the 1980s and into the 1990s. Worst of all, they have not been applied, so that a degree of laxity has developed around the current regulations. Certainly, the situation that prevails at the moment is most unsatisfactory.

There is an urgent need for review. In that process of review I think it is understandable that clubs and associations are out to protect their privileges. That is quite an understandable reaction. At the moment they do enjoy some privileges. As Senator Reid has already indicated, they are exempt from the need for licences. The imposition of licence requirements on them would be a great inconvenience. They are also exempt from the need to have liquor licences in their clubs. They have certain privileges in relation to ammunition. They are protecting their interests and privileges. Having regard to their proud history, we believe that it is probably reasonable that they would react in that way.

TALK.START.PARA: —But is it justifiable?

—That is something that must be discussed. It seems to us that the imposition on them at the moment is worthy of discussion. As the Minister mentioned in his earlier interjections, during the period of the Menzies Government there was considerable review of regulations and over a period of almost three decades now there has been an acknowledgment of the fact that the regulations are inadequate, are in disuse, are not being applied, and that the time is right for review. It is probably unfortunate that this regulation has thrown that process into confusion. It is certainly unfortunate that it coincided with a period of intense and fairly emotive discussion associated with the New South Wales State election. Of course, election campaigns are probably the worst of all contexts in which to discuss things rationally and to arrive at the right solution.
—Especially State elections.

—Especially State elections, as the Minister says. So it is certainly time to tidy up. There is a feeling of that need among the bureaucrats who administer this area of regulation on behalf of the Minister. That is also understandable. It has been sitting in their `too hard' tray for a long time and they are fairly anxious to resolve the problem. They attempted, of course, to pass the difficulties to the States. It is the reaction of the Australian Democrats that this would be most unfortunate because we believe that we are moving into an era in which we need uniformity of gun laws and that the responsible and necessary thing, as we move into that era, is to have available areas of safe, controlled space called rifle ranges, where people can qualify in the use of, acquire competence in the use of, and prove their competence in the use of, small arms. Whether those small arms are rifles, pistols, automatic or semi-automatic weapons is an area for debate and negotiation. Certainly, the Australian Democrats believe that we must move towards uniformity of gun laws and that the rational thing, as I say, is to have available places where these weapons-which are used, hopefully, by fewer people-are used in controlled, safe spaces.

SPEECH.PARA: Our feeling is that if these controls pass to the States we will certainly move into a grey area. The reactions of the States are unclear. We know that the reactions will not be uniform, that they will be divergent. We believe that it is contrary to rational uniform gun control to pass the matter to the States. We sense lurking in the background pressure from potential property developers who would like to get their hands on many of the spaces which are now used as rifle ranges. Obviously, the example that has been in the news lately is the Anzac Rifle Range, which occupies a nice piece of real estate in New South Wales. Perhaps it would be appropriate for that to be put to alternative uses, but we sense lurking in the background developers who would like to get their hands on quite a number of these spaces. The spaces fall into three broad categories: Commonwealth land under Commonwealth control; State land under State control; and private land on lease to clubs or associations. In other words, putting it in blunt terms, we sense a potential real estate rort.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has nothing to do with the regulations, though.

—The application of these regulations and the transfer of control to the States means no control. It means that the situation is out of control-out of the control of the organisation that has controlled it responsibly, well and constructively for 80 years and that happens to be experiencing a hiccup about whether or not it should continue in that role. We believe that it should.

SPEECH.PARA: As gun controllers, the Democrats would like to see in the next decades fewer guns in the hands of fewer people. We acknowledge that some people need to have and should be entitled to have guns. Those who have guns should be required to prove their competence. But, first of all, people have to acquire a competence. In other words, they have to be taught how to use guns. There is a need for safe controlled places where they can use guns and where they can be trained in and acquire the necessary skills and prove their skills.

We think it is unrealistic in an area the size of, say, New South Wales to have only two places where that can be done. Quite obviously, if there were only two places-and that was the case under the previous State Government-people simply would not go to them to acquire competence, or prove their competence or have their competence tested. We see that as being an unfavourable development.

In summary, we believe that the effect of the regulations would ultimately have led to the closure of ranges, and we view that unfavourably. The Democrats prefer the status quo in the short term. We urge the Minister and all interested parties to come to the table as soon as possible. The Minister has outlined to us-and we must accept the fact-that there is some doubt at the moment about liability if there were to be an accident. Admittedly, there have not been accidents previously. But if there were to be an accident, under the regulations at the moment probably the individual, the clubs or the associations involved would be liable. That is a serious problem and there is a need for quick action. However, we believe that the status quo in the short term will ensure that most satisfactory solution and provide us with the time to arrive at an ongoing long term solution to the problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have decided to intervene at this stage of the debate because I am sure that the speeches that will be made by Senator Brownhill and Senator Panizza will be along similar lines to that made by Senator Reid. Of course, those speeches are basically unnecessary because Senator Reid, as a Whip, can count and she knows that the regulations will be disallowed. But, of course, everyone has to get on to the record and make irrelevant speeches in this place. The speeches are basically irrelevant if they do not go to the nub of the matter. Therefore, the speeches are made not to assist us with the disallowance of regulations but as something to send out to all constituents.

SPEECH.PARA: As usual in this place, as so often happens, we seem to be stuck between a rock and a hard place. Even though it was not said specifically, the Liberals are pretty soft on gun laws in any sense and the Australian Democrats are fairly hard on them. Apparently we will be defeated by being caught in the middle sitting on the fence. For the record, that is basically what has happened here. Senator Reid said that we are trying to wriggle out of supervision and control of gun and rifle clubs. There has been no supervision and no control of them for almost three decades.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because the Commonwealth hauls off the inspectors.

—Right; because the Commonwealth hauls off inspectors. Who did that? Was it Sir Robert Menzies who did that? We have had a few Liberal Prime Ministers. The original decision to pull out of this area, basically on the grounds of advice from the Department of Defence that these regulations were no longer valued for defence purposes, was made under the Menzies Government in 1959. Since that time-the great white father of the Liberal Party apparently disagreed with the view held by Senator Reid-there has been no direct relevance to defence in the rifle clubs. Subsequently when Sir Robert Menzies retired Prime Minister Holt must have taken the same attitude. He did not intervene and reimpose supervision and control. When he went Prime Minister Gorton did not intervene on this issue; when Prime Minister Gorton went, Prime Minister McMahon did not intervene; and, finally Prime Minister Fraser did not intervene. Here we have the creme de la creme of the Liberal Party--
—You left one out.

—Senator Panizza says that I left one out. I did not go to the Country Party and Black Jack McEwen because he was only given a month or two in the big job after he blackballed McMahon. He was not able to connive his way into it and he had other things on his mind than supervising gun clubs in that very historic period. He was too busy blackballing the late Sir William McMahon. But to come in here and say that we are trying to wriggle out of supervision and control in 1988, when the decision basically was made in 1959 for defence reasons that the regulations relating to rifle clubs were no longer relevant, is amazing.

SPEECH.PARA: The second amazing thing that is said is that we are attacking rifle clubs. I am here to state that we are not. I have a great deal of admiration for rifle clubs. I am going to visit one next Saturday-the Williamstown range in Melbourne. I look forward to that. We are not saying that the rifle clubs are irresponsible or that they have not behaved with decorum; they clearly have and they represent some of the best citizens in this country. I will come to the nub of it later as to why we seek the repeal of the existing provisions. But to come in here with that accusation is simply false.

We then hear the assertion put forward that what we want is uniformity around Australia. We might get uniformity on certain rifle clubs, but in terms of dealing with guns in the community, those opposite are creating a lack of uniformity within each State. They say, `If you happen to be a rifle shooter in a rifle club on this particular range you have these rights, but if you happen to hold a pistol or a bazooka, or whatever else is allowed if you are in Queensland, you have a different set of rights and responsibilities'. So the argument on uniformity is basically a shallow one.

We then have the red herring of the sell-off argument. What Senator McLean said about the sell-off of ranges is a complicated matter. I would not like to see the overall number of ranges available reduced, but I do say to him that it has nothing to do with the regulations and, more to the point, the real problem with some of the rifle ranges at the moment is that the places where they are can be much more socially useful for other purposes provided they are replaced somewhere else with accessible ranges. In other words, if there is a range in the middle of Williamstown it may be more socially desirable for the community-remembering that it is in the western suburbs of Melbourne, which is a deprived area-to put all sorts of community environmental things in that area and then move the rifle range out to the other side of Bacchus Marsh. But it really is not a relevant issue with regard to the regulations. If there are sell-offs, they will occur no matter what sorts of regulations we have in place.

I suggest that decisions will be made by government on two grounds-social utility and fund raising. I am honest enough to say that fund raising is one aspect available to government. We have been asked to knock over these regulations and it is said that that will force us to come to the table. We will come to the table; we will be begged to come to the table. But to say that we have not been to the table, as some people have suggested, is not true. I have been involved in discussions with representatives of rifle clubs. As late as a couple of weeks ago they flew to Canberra to meet with me after the disallowance motion was defeated in the House of Representatives, but before it was brought on in this chamber. I was happy to talk to them about some of the issues. The Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) came to my office to do so too. He was happy to do so. I thought that we had come to a fairly amicable arrangement with them. Apparently, the accusation is made that we have not discussed it with the Liberal Party of Australia. I have not discussed it with the Liberal Party because, given its attitude in the House of Representatives, I thought that Opposition members had made up their minds on the issue. But if they say they have an open mind on these things I will make sure they are properly consulted and brought into the negotiations when the issue comes back.

We are really dealing with Statutory Rule 1988, No. 17. This was gazetted on 25 February 1988 and repealed the Australian Rifle Club Regulations as part of a package. That package also included a new regulation-the Defence (General) Regulation-which exempted rifle clubs from State liquor licensing requirements during a shoot. It also made a firearms order which exempts members of rifle clubs from State gun licensing requirements. It needs to be clearly understood that this package was reached after lengthy negotiations with the National Rifle Association of Australia last July. The Government, through Senator Tate, the Minister for Justice, announced at the Premiers Conference on gun control last December that exemptions from liquor licensing and gun licensing would be repealed after six months. I think that was to be by about 1 July this year.

The Australian Rifle Club Regulations were largely concerned with internal administration of rifle clubs. For many years now these parts of the regulations have been in disuse as the rifle club movement, like any other sporting association, has established itself on a self-standing basis. The only active parts of the regulation were those concerned with exemptions from liquor licensing and gun licensing. We regard it as inappropriate that the Commonwealth Government should be involved in these issues, which are properly for State and Territorial authorities. So, for the Opposition to make its case today, it really has to say not whether the regulations are good or bad in a technical detail, but whether the Commonwealth needs the power over this area and whether it should have that power. It seems to me that the argument so far relies on history. I find it rather strange that, standing in a States rights House, I hear one conservative Liberal member, and no doubt many more, jumping up and saying, `We want the Commonwealth to have power; we don't want it devolved to the States'. It is an interesting argument; I wonder how consistently it will be applied to other legislation. When we seek the power out there for one vote one value, we will hear the Opposition coming up with all the arguments for State rights. But still, I guess we live with those forms of hypocrisy. For many years it has been the view of the Defence Force that sports rifle shooting has no significant military value. That case has not been addressed here today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, it was.

—Senator McLean says that it was. I have to say that it was inadequately argued or failed to compel me with its logic. I will acknowledge that Senator McLean has at least raised it. I am simply saying that it is up to the Opposition to prove that Federal powers should override State powers in this matter. The one argument historically used from the start of the century was that firing rifles had a big defence responsibility. But the defence forces and the Department of Defence, under the great white father Menzies and all the other Liberal Prime Ministers, took the view that it no longer had that effect; that it, like a lot of things, had outworn its usefulness. Just because something was useful in 1920 does not mean it has relevance today. This is one of those classic issues.

SPEECH.PARA: It is difficult to argue that, because the sport provides shooting skills, it should have a special defence relationship. If that argument is to be sustained I simply argue: why do we not regulate on pistol shooting? Many people in the defence forces use pistols as they do rifles. Parachuting is now an essential military skill. Are we supposed to bring in parachuting regulations all over the place specifically because parachuting may have a defence requirement? Do Senator Panizza and other members of the Opposition want us to bring in regulations for all the martial arts: kung-fu, tae kwon do and all the rest, because they will have a military connotation? I wonder. They may provide useful skills but are they absolutely essential skills that require the Federal Government to intervene over the States?

While the repealed regulations were in force, members of rifle clubs were subject to no effective gun control, other than internal discipline. They have been exempted from State laws while the Defence Department was in no position to ensure that proper controls were enforced. What has happened is that rifle clubs-I admit that they use self-discipline-have no control in their various States, basically, in many of these areas, yet they have no supervisory body and no control from us. What does the Opposition want us to do-set up an internal police force to go round to all the rifle clubs now that they have self-management? Is that what the Opposition wants us to do, as well as enforce every regulation? I dare say that, if we did that and started pulling up citizens of rifle clubs and placing them in magistrates courts, honourable senators opposite would be the first to jump up and say that we were pettifoggers and to ask what we were doing persecuting the rifle clubs because of minor breaches of regulations. The Opposition would be arguing for self-control, self-organisation, of those groups.

The States have a basic responsibility for control of these activities. As far as we are concerned, the Commonwealth has no desire to override them. I make the point again: the States are in charge of various guns in the community, with one exception. The Opposition has to justify that exception and say why different principles and attitudes will apply to that one exception because of an historical oversight, almost, these days.

The purpose of the general regulations and the firearms order was to provide rifle clubs with time to negotiate with the States on their requirements. We have made it quite clear that, if the date of 1 July was not satisfactory, if that would put too much pressure on them and did not give them enough time, we were willing to extend it. We were willing to extend the date to the end of the year, if necessary, to give them more time to negotiate with the States. We are still willing to do so. We have made it clear that we are willing to do so. We have made it clear to the rifle clubs that, if they are saying that we are putting pressure on them and that they have to reach a quick decision by 1 July, we will extend the date to the end of the year. They agreed with us, but apparently the Opposition does not do so.

The degree of exemption from State gun laws enjoyed under the repealed regulations has been widely misunderstood. The exemption is from State licensing requirements. I want to stress that it is from State licensing requirements. There is no exemption if weapons prohibited by the States are held by a rifle club member. In other words, if a State government wanted to prohibit a particular rifle, it could not be used or owned by that member. The only exemption is to whether he is licensed to use within a State a particular weapon that is allowable within a State. The argument that we will do away with all sorts of guns in this way is nonsense. If the States are so minded, and they do not like the Commonwealth regulations, they are likely to go much further than the Commonwealth ever would. So, in the end, this could act as a weapon to be used against rifle clubs. The motion to disallow and leave in existing things could be used as a weapon against them, to bring them under control, to ban the weapons-not just the licensing aspect.

The exemption applies to members of clubs approved by the Minister. The reality is that the process for approval of clubs is covered in one of the parts of the repealed regulations which have been in disuse. No approvals have been given for many years and this is because the rifle club movement has been self-managing since the 1960s. If we disallow these regulations which give the clubs some cover of their liability, at least to 1 July and, if extended, to the end of the year-and most of these clubs have not been given proper approval-they will be liable; they will have no cover whatsoever. The Opposition should think about that when it seeks disallowance. I say here that, if things go wrong, it will be on the Opposition's head.

Madam Acting Deputy President, I am certain that you would be interested to know that, reflecting the anachronistic state of the repealed regulations, members of clubs are required to be male. Apparently, no female members of clubs enjoy any exemptions. That is how hopeless these regulations we seek to repeal are. In other words, if a male takes his spouse there and is shooting, she is not covered by the exemptions because she is female. What a ridiculous set of regulations. I wonder why Senator Reid in her pitter-patter for the rifle clubs did not mention that fact.

After this notice of motion for disallowance of the repeal of the Australian Rifle Club Regulations was given, further concerns were raised, particularly by the Australian Democrats but certainly by various rifle clubs, about the safety of rifle ranges. One of their concerns-I think Senator McLean reflected on this-was that by handing these ranges back to the States we would give the States the power, through false safety levels, to squeeze out the rifle ranges and then presumably sell the land. I think it needs to be understood and emphasised that at this stage there is no connection between repealed regulations and range safety. The regulations did not provide exemptions from State legal requirements on safety. So that is really in part, if you like, a non-issue. However, many of the ranges are established on Commonwealth owned or leased property and for that reason the Commonwealth has overseen their safety.

It should also be emphasised that the regulations have no link with the issue of whether the Commonwealth should continue to own or lease rifle ranges. That is a policy question and quite distinct from the regulations. However, on behalf of the Minister for Defence I am able to say that he is prepared to consider representations made to him on the question of range safety and other rifle club issues. In other words, we would be willing in the right circumstances to promulgate regulations which would give a uniform template-the same as used by the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation. If we had put these regulations through and an accusation were then made that the regulations would lead to the closure of ranges and that people would go out and shoot in an indiscriminate manner in the countryside, we would have been willing to use at least one of our powers to put in a template with a reasonable safety distance-not some ridiculous one imposed by State governments. That offer is on the table. It is not going to stay on the table forever because we are not going to be salami-sliced back on everything and make all the offers. Something has to be given back. The thing we really seek is the admission that these regulations are so outdated, outmoded and unenforceable that they should go, unless there is a compelling reason and argument otherwise. Here today so far that compelling reason has been paper thin.

Two things have to be proved. Firstly, it has to be proved that there is still a defence requirement for rifle shooters and that there is a benefit to the defence of this country. That has not been established here at all. Basically, it has never been argued much by the rifle clubs, which insist on the sporting nature of the activity. I concede that and endorse it. I am sure that everyone would like to see Australian shooters continue in world class competition. The second thing that has to be established is why we should override State power in this matter. Why should we create inconsistencies within States where rifle clubs are treated in one way and every other form of shooter is treated in another way?I think it should be mentioned briefly that the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances also referred to this question of time. I think it argued that the sunset clause was far too brief. I indicate again today that had these regulations continued we would not have had a problem in extending them beyond 30 June 1988.

We are getting to the situation where, quite obviously, these regulations will be disallowed. What that really means in the long run is that we will have a whole area of confusion. The Opposition is not proposing to disallow the other two changes we have made. Those changes are already in place. They cannot be disallowed or changed. The Opposition is changing one section. So, instead of having the mess that we had, say, in June last year we now have a much more complicated mess. What that means for the rifle clubs of Australia is that most of them are not properly registered, most of them are not covered in a legal liability sense. They are covered only as long as these regulations are in place. They would have been covered if a proper agreement had been negotiated with each State government. That is the position. That is the effect of disallowing these regulations.

In summing up, I again stress that the development of these proposals pre-dates what some people would call the hysteria on gun laws. They have been in the pipeline for quite some time. When it was appropriate to bring them forward, they were brought forward, with no particular dependence on what happened as a result of events in other States involving the misuse of guns. The accusation that we are in some ways out to get, nobble or in any way destroy rifle clubs is absolutely untrue. As I have said before, the initial regulations were not enforced for 29 years. It was a Liberal Government that made the decision in 1959 to opt out, and from 1959 to 1972 and from 1975 to 1983 the Liberals did not make any changes. They allowed the whole system to slide. I do not blame them for that, because they said on Defence advice that Commonwealth control over these areas was no longer of any relevance. That is what they were told, and so previous Liberal governments cannot be blamed for the fact that a situation evolved whereby the regulations fell into disuse. But they fell into disuse for the very good reason that the then Liberal Party Prime Ministers and Ministers for Defence could see that the regulations were useless, that they contain no defence component whatsoever and that they should slide.

It seems to me that the only argument that can be brought to bear now is: `Look, we have put rifle clubs in a privileged position; why should we take their privileges away? After all their members are voters and they have lobbied us; why should we affect them?'. But we have to ask ourselves every now and then why one group of shooters should be put in a privileged position if there is no justification for it. What is unique about them that places them in a privileged position? The eventual answer is, `Absolutely nothing'.

I am a realist. I recognise that these regulations are going to be disallowed. But I think in the long run, once they are disallowed, the people who will suffer most will not be the Liberal senators sitting on that side of the chamber, who will wash their hands of the matter and move to another issue; the people who will suffer most will be the members of the rifle clubs themselves because the clubs will be placed in the invidious position of having no proper legal liability cover. The clubs will not be properly approved and, in the end, they will have to come back to the Commonwealth Government with a set of proposals that we can negotiate on. As I say, we have negotiated before and we remain ready to negotiate again. We cannot negotiate for months on end as we do have other priorities, other things to do, but we still remain open to negotiation on these matters. In the meantime the clubs will be put in a terrible position. I know there is no point in going on-as there is not ever in this chamber-because even if I have mounted a logical argument I will not change the eventual vote. I would like to wish this matter a speedy passage but I notice the other side is prepared to put up more speakers. It is ironic that we have called a one-day sitting to get through non-controversial Government legislation but we will be lucky to start debating it by 8.30 tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the last day for this. It is not our fault it has just been brought on.
—Maybe it was not Senator Reid's fault on the matter of public importance. We will be lucky to start debating Government legislation by 8.30.
—It is Senator Walsh's fault.
—Now we have the whingers on the other side saying it is Senator Walsh's fault. If they cannot stand the heat in the kitchen they should get out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) has tried to shoot me down in flames-pardon the pun-I would like to make a couple of things clear. I have 30 years experience in rifle clubs, and have competed for three different clubs. The coalition parties have the full support of the National Rifle Association of Australia (NRAA) behind us. We were informed by the Minister earlier today that we are not working in the best interest of the NRAA and that the NRAA has been talking to the Government. As of late yesterday we still had the full support of the Association.

SPEECH.PARA: As has been said in this debate, rifle clubs in one form or another have existed in Australia since the mid-1800s. No special licences were needed but a member of a rifle club had to carry identification and was limited to four rifles. The Government's intention has been made clear. Under section 124 of the Defence Act, the Governor-General may make regulations. Statutory Rule No. 17 repealed the Australian Rifle Club Regulations. This, in effect, transferred the control of rifle clubs from the Federal Department of Defence to the various State governments. This was deemed, as the Minister said, to have happened on 15 March 1988. Under section 123g of the Act, which allows the Minister to make orders, the Minister made order No. 56, which came into effect on 25 February 1988, directing that members of all rifle clubs and associations affiliated with the NRAA would not be subject to the firearm provisions of their own States or Territories where rifles were used by authorised clubs for any organised shoots, or where public carriage of rifles used for this purpose was from storage to the range and back again. As I said, one was limited to four rifles.

The insertion of order No. 56 provided NRAA clubs and associations with time-approximately six months-to adjust to State laws. With this course of events, these clubs and associations assumed the same status as any other sporting club and association. The end result provided much disparity between the various laws of the States. The Minister shot us down on that one. He said that it was okay to have regulations made by different States. But this sporting organisation has existed for many years. The Australia-wide uniformity would be lost to all the clubs and organisations. It was found that in making order No. 56 the Minister had omitted small bore rifle organisations. Small bore rifles such as the old .303 with a .22 barrel fitted were left out. The Minister subsequently made order No. 66 on 4 March to include small bore rifles, but curiously lifted the ban on automatic and semi-automatic rifles as well as the limit of four rifles per person. No explanation has been given for that. If there are dangerous weapons they are the automatic and semi-automatic weapons. Lifting the limit of four rifles per person does not worry me greatly because not many people will rush out and purchase .762 rifles at a cost of $1,000 each and exceed that limit.

TALK.START.PARA: —Only collectors would do that.

—Yes. Perhaps it may be opportune to portray the history of rifle clubs in Australia as well as their importance and achievements. As Senator McLean said, the first rifle clubs were established in Australia in the mid-1800s with the formation of the Sydney Rifle Club in 1842. Australian rifle teams began competing in inter-colonial shoots--
—We had slavery then. Do you want to restore that?

—Yes, we did, but this is a little different from slavery. These competitions nurtured good relations with America. In 1876 we competed in the Championship of the World in Philadelphia. Every year-and I have competed in more than one-we have the premier event, the Queen's Prize.
—That is terrific. We agree with that.

—Good, you agree with it. To be able to keep it going we need to remain uniform. The first Queen's Prize was held in Queensland in 1878, with New South Wales and South Australia coming in in 1879 and 1891. These competitions are held over ranges from 200 yards to 800 yards, going up in stages of 100 yards.
—Yards or metres?

—The old ranges were measured in yards, but these days they are in metres. The umbrella responsibilities of the rifle clubs were taken over by the Army, as I said, way back in 1901, and since 1903 the Defence Act has guaranteed special rights-I know that that does not go down too well with the Minister for Home Affairs-for full members of rifle clubs. This includes having the right to possess and carry rifles without State licence. But by the same token when the NRAA wanted to keep this uniform, it was prepared to license them with State authorities, so that they would then be under the umbrella of the Commonwealth as well. However, the Minister's Department would not listen to them.
—What happens if the State bans those rifles? They can't carry them any more.
—That is right, they cannot carry them any more; but obviously the States will have the good sense to keep a sport like this going.
—Of course. Therefore, they should control the sport.
—There are other firearms, such as pistols, that are used in clubs.
—You have just hung yourself. You said the States could do this adequately.
—The Minister has had his go.

—Yes, the Minister has had his go, but I do not mind arguing it out. As was said, it was a valuable defence. The Minister cuts me down when I am dealing with these valuable defence people. A lot of people who went into the Army came out of rifle clubs over the years, and they have nothing to be ashamed of. These people are held in high regard around the world. In 1921 the Commonwealth Council of Rifle Clubs was reconstituted as a civilian organisation under the Department of Defence. In 1931 it was transferred to the control of the Military Board and functioned as a reserve to the Citizen Military Forces. There was nothing wrong with that. In 1946 rifle clubs came out of the recess that had been imposed on them by the war, and were re-established under the Army. In 1971 the umbrella organisation became the NRAA.
—Why did Menzies dump them?
—Why didn't he? He probably had a good reason. What is more, why did not Whitlam dump them in 1973-74?
—Why did Menzies dump them in 1959?

—Why did not your Prime Minister dump them? We could argue all night about that one, but no one will ever win the argument. We had the chance, admittedly, to dump them then and your side had the chance to do so in 1974. It has taken four years of this present Government to try to do the same thing. So do not point the finger at Menzies or at anyone else, if your side has not been prepared to do it for itself.
—I want you to explain why.

—My explanation would be as good as the Minister's as to whether it should or should not have been done under Whitlam or the present Government. The arrangements that had been put in lasted until this year. Since 1903 we have gained fame all over the world by our rifle shooting. The latest such occasion was at the Edinburgh Games, where Golinski of New South Wales and Corbett of Victoria won the silver in the pairs. Australia has about 500 full time clubs, with 8,000 members-they are quite large in numbers. On and off over the last 30 years I have been a member of three different clubs. Since the formation of the first clubs in Australia, they have been a reliable source of teaching young fellows to shoot. Senator McLean-and I am not one to agree too often with the Democrats-pointed out that that is an area where young people can learn to use their rifles. The cadet detachments having been done away with throughout most of Australia, where many of us used to learn to handle rifles, at least we can now use the rifle clubs. Indeed, when my own two sons asked for gun licences, I said `Get into a rifle club and learn how to handle a rifle before you ask me whether you can have a licence'.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the dinner break I was dealing with the history of Australian rifle clubs. As I said, since the formation of those rifle clubs there has been a good and reliable source of teaching young people to handle rifles. The present policy of the NRAA is to admit women and men at the age of 16 years, although there is a move to drop the limit, with members not being able to own a rifle until they are adept at handling one. They must complete at least three months apprenticeship and must participate at least four times a year in standard practice or in competition to remain a member. So much for history.

SPEECH.PARA: I now come to the Opposition's view and my view. The Government has stated that it no longer considers that rifle clubs and associations bear any relevance to the country's defence needs and that it is no longer appropriate for the Defence Department to be involved in their affairs. My view is contrary. As I have already said, in the past Australia has drawn on the skills of rifle clubs for the nation's defence forces. This has been not only in time of war; there has been close liaison in time of peace. This valuable asset will be lost under the present proposal by the Government. In handing control over to the various States a number of factors detrimental to the continued existence of the clubs will occur. They include the adjustment of safety regulations away from those of the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation. At present there is a safety template of 1,830 metres and it is anticipated that the increase in the safety template under State laws will mean that many civilian ranges will not be able to comply. As I said, at present the safety distance is 1,830 metres, which I presume is the old 2,000 yards. With even the newest rifleman on a rifle range there is very little chance of a bullet passing the stop butt. Increasing the template would cause many civilian ranges to close and would prevent the building of new ones because it would be outside the resources of rifle clubs. As I have already mentioned, Australian riflemen have achieved fame in various competitions around the world so the closing of civilian ranges will disadvantage this national sport.

The Government has already disadvantaged a large number of civilian shooters by selling Williamstown rifle range in Victoria. On a recent trip to Sydney I noticed that the Anzac range, which was mentioned by Senator McLean, is on the market. Like Senator McLean, I consider that this could be as a result of developers anxious to get onto that good piece of dirt for their own ends rather than leave it to the sport that has had it for so many years. On hearing of the impending sale of the Anzac range I inquired about the Swanbourne range in Perth to see that it was not to be sold. I was assured that Swanbourne was not to be sold and that the Army is even updating its facilities there. Incidentally, the Special Air Service Regiment is located adjacent to that range in Perth.

By forcing the closure of any additional ranges the current trend of disadvantaging rifle clubs will continue. With the handing of control of rifle clubs and associations to each State body, the NRAA would be disadvantaged during national competitions, as I have already pointed out, because of the lack of reciprocal arrangements for the carrying of rifles across State borders. Senator Reid mentioned this earlier. It is all very well for us to say that this will not be a problem but unless the requirements are set out in black and white they could cause difficulty. The change has not come about because the Minister for Defence was tired of rifle clubs or for any reason of that nature. It has come about because officers of that Department considered that it was demeaning to their Department and it was time to get rid of the rifle clubs. That was obviously the easy solution.

After the gun summit and the subsequent saga there is very little chance of uniform gun laws. There could have been uniform gun laws until a few State elections came along and that was the end of it. The repeal of the regulations has not been brought about by the quest for uniform laws, nor by the Hoddle Street and Queen Street tragedies. The Minister told us this afternoon that the changes were in the pipeline anyhow.

If the practice of continued lease arrangements agreed by the Commonwealth is discontinued, the rifle clubs using these ranges will be at the mercy of State governments, some of which would like to see many of the ranges closed. It is all very well to say, as the Minister intimated, that one could sell ranges, such as the Anzac range and Williamstown, in the busy areas for development purposes. But who is going to pay for the new ones? The Federal Government will grab what is there. It will certainly be outside the reach of the rifle clubs.

What will happen if these regulations are disallowed? The Minister for Home Affairs, Senator Ray, said this afternoon that they would be left wide open. I am sorry that the same Minister is not in the chamber now because I was enjoying the exchanges we were having about these rifle clubs. I have sought a ruling from the Deputy Clerk of the Senate, backed up by the Clerk. It is not that I did not trust the Deputy Clerk's findings, but it is good to check with both the Deputy Clerk and the Clerk to see whether they give the same reading. They did. They state that by disallowing the regulations we will get back to exactly what we had before. A few regulations will not be repealed by disallowance. Senator Ray said that he would welcome my incorporating this document in Hansard. A section of it states that there could be some ambiguity. Madam Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to have the correspondence from the Clerk of the Senate incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Senator Panizza
You have sought advice on the possible consequences of the disallowance of the Australian Rifle Club Regulations (Repeal) (S.R. 1988 No. 17).
The Australian Rifle Club Regulations (Repeal) is part of a complex delegated legislative package designed to
Terminate the involvement of the Defence Organisation with the establishment, administration and control of rifle clubs and associations;
Continue the exemptions which these bodies enjoy from State and Territory gun and liquor laws, (the intention is that the exemption is to be temporary but there is no sunset clause);

Provide interim controls over the use of guns and liquor by these bodies pending the application of State and Territory laws in about 6 months, by which time, it is said, all necessary administrative arrangements will be in place.
The legislative package comprises the following-
Australian Rifle Club Regulations (Repeal)
Rifle Clubs (Firearms) Order (25 February 1988)
Rifle Clubs (Firearms) Order (Amendment) (4 March 1988)
Defence (General) Regulations (S.R. 1988 No. 18)
The disallowance of the Australian Rifle Club Regulations (Repeal) will produce a number of consequences including the following-

(i) Since the Regulations repeal several sets of earlier regulations which have, until now, controlled the activity of the clubs and associations, their disallowance will revive those earlier regulations. They will come back into force from the moment of disallowance (subsection 48 (7), Acts Interpretation Act 1901).

(ii) Those revived regulations will give rise to certain rights and obligations which may repeat or conflict with those recently put in place by the remaining pieces of legislation in the aforementioned package which have not been disallowed. A situation of considerable legal uncertainty may arise from this.

(iii) If the Australian Rifle Club Regulations (Repeal) is disallowed, the Government cannot, without permission embodied in a resolution of the Senate, make any Regulations ``the same in substance as'' those disallowed, until a period of 6 months has elapsed (subsection 49 (1), Acts Interpretation Act).
JOHN VANDER WYK

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The NRAA knows full well that, after so many years-since 1903 or whatever it was-some of the regulations need tightening, something needs to be done. All along it has endeavoured to get around the table with the Minister but has not been successful in this. As I said earlier, I have been in constant contact with the NRAA which has maintained all along that it would prefer to have these regulations disallowed and then come back to the negotiating table.

SPEECH.PARA: I welcome the support we have had from the Australian Democrats today. As I said earlier, I do not often praise the Democrats but in Senator McLean at least we have an experienced Army man, experienced in the handling of rifles and on rifle ranges. He has seen what this is all about. In winding up, I will get on to a few of the points made by the Minister at the table, Senator Ray, before the suspension of the sitting for dinner. Once he could see himself in the corner, just like the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) did with the media legislation, he started to give us red herrings. The last time we were here the Minister for Transport and Communications decried our objections to what that legislation would do to the people in the country. I immediately jumped to my feet to talk, but my Whip and my Leader prevented me from doing so.

This evening I shall not take that Minister to task but I shall certainly take to task the Minister who was at the table before dinner on what he was saying. He got on to the argument of States rights. He is trying to give rights back to the States so they can make their own regulations and rules about rifle clubs. It may have suited that Minister to say that this evening. As I said earlier on, I wish he had remained in the chamber. When we were discussing the heritage legislation there was no concern shown for States rights, whether in Tasmania or Queensland. The Government rode roughshod over them and did not worry about them. Once the heritage legislation takes effect we will see how much Senator McKiernan stands up for States rights in Shark Bay. I ask the Senate to disregard that argument completely because the States to date have had complete faith in the Commonwealth to run these rifle clubs properly.

As I said earlier, there are 8,000 members, plus their supporters, in rifle clubs throughout Australia-so we could class the sport as having a fairly medium sized following-and their wishes should be taken into consideration. The Minister who was in the chamber earlier feared that, if these regulations were disallowed, they could not be brought back for six months. I understand, from reading this document, that the same regulations cannot be brought back within six months but that legislation that would suit the NRAA, the Federal Government, the rifle clubs and probably the State governments could probably be brought back in here next week.

I did say that the coalition would be very happy to sit down with the Government and formulate policy. I am sure the Australian Democrats would be very happy to join in such a round table conference with the Minister responsible, with us and with the NRAA. All we need is the invitation from the Minister to do so, and we will be only too pleased to accept it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The regulations which the Government seeks to repeal relate to rifle clubs and associations throughout Australia and if the Government were to win this debate, I think it would have a far-reaching effect. I am not going to speak for very long, because this matter has been debated very well by my colleagues, starting with Senator Reid. Senator Panizza has just given a wonderful explanation of this debate which I will not elaborate on. The thing that concerns me most is that there has been no explanation by the Government as to why it wants to repeal the regulations. Since 1903 the Federal Government has had responsibility for the supervision of the 500-odd clubs in Australia and the 8,000 members who shoot at those rifle clubs. We have to ask ourselves why it is all being changed now.

SPEECH.PARA: Defence preparedness has been part of the Australian way of life, along with the use of rifle ranges. The Anzac Rifle Range in New South Wales, as the previous speaker said, is still subject to legal action and it may be some 18 months to two years before it is resolved and we know what the outcome is. There has been a terrific amount of opposition from all the gun clubs to the changes that this Government is trying to impose on the community. As I have said, for years they have been doing a responsible job training people in the safe use of firearms. Under the present Department of Defence controls there has always been uniformity throughout Australia, and that is as it should be. With the transfer to the States of control of the rifle ranges this situation will change and inconsistencies will creep in. Shooters will have to apply for separate licences when they travel interstate, for example.

Rifle range leases on land under Commonwealth control will be terminated and the leases will be renegotiated with individual clubs. Again, that will lead to inconsistencies throughout Australia. This measure will cause enormous financial pressures on clubs and many will be forced to close or seek alternative ranges. This could lead to a breakdown of the educational role played by the clubs. The Federal Government has been getting at a very cheap price a corps of trained firearms personnel throughout Australia, which will stand future generations in good stead as a deterrent to anyone who wanted to use force to come into this country. This corps of good rifle persons is now under threat.

The rifle clubs have always been well able to administer their own affairs. I do not think that is in dispute here tonight. However, the facilities provided by the Defence Department-the provision of the land-will be lost, and we are concerned about that. If the Federal Government is genuine in its desire to curb the increased misuse of firearms it is going the wrong way about improving the situation. This move is likely to lead to a decrease in the number of clubs with facilities and will therefore lead to a reduction in the number of trained personnel available to instruct people in the safe use of firearms. That is another point that this Government has not thought about. If legislation similar to that proposed by the former New South Wales Labor Government were introduced anywhere else the problems would be enormous. Just consider some of the problems that would have arisen in New South Wales if the Labor Government had been returned. Rifles would have been able to be used only on the home range. Where would that have left the inner club shoots?

TALK.START.PARA: —They could borrow theirs when they had finished with them.

—Luckily the New South Wales people saw the wisdom of changing the Government in that State because of what would have happened there had former Premier Unsworth been returned. Clubs would have lost their liquor licence privileges and they would have had to make application to local police licensing sergeants. There was to be an increased danger zone area in New South Wales-from 150 acres to 450 acres-which would have caused great problems. There was to be a lengthening of the danger zone around each rifle range from two kilometres to 4.5 kilometres, which probably would have meant that only a couple of rifle ranges in the whole of New South Wales would have been able to be used. Victoria has different legislation from that which applies in some of the other States. So the inconsistencies that would abound, with all the States being different, would cause terrific problems.
