SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Student Assistance Legislation Amendment Bill 1987, on which we had a reasonable amount of debate a couple of weeks ago, deals basically with penalties for fraud. At present, under the Student Assistance Regulations the maximum penalty for offences is a fine of $100, although it is possible under the Crimes Act for a person to be sentenced to a maximum of two years imprisonment for deliberately making an untrue statement in connection with or in support of an application for assistance.

SPEECH.PARA: I will move some amendments during the committee stage of the Bill and I will leave my remarks in connection with them until then. I wish to raise some other matters in connection with penalties. It is not at all obvious, particularly in the 1988 Austudy information brochure, that the Government had or has any intention of increasing penalties. I will be interested to see whether the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) in his second reading response informs the Senate of the plans the Government has to publicise these very much increased penalties. As I have said, this information is not in the 1988 Austudy brochure, from which most students would be expected to get their information on Austudy. It may be in the 1989 brochure.

The second reading speech made by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) gave no indication of the types of savings that the Government anticipated would result from the measures in this Bill. The explanatory memorandum says that the Government expects these measures `to result in significant savings'. It goes on:
It is not possible, however, to quantify these savings until compliance surveys have been undertaken to investigate further the extent of fraud under Austudy.

What will be the financial costs of detecting and preventing fraud compared with the savings? Presumably, the Government must have had some basis upon which it made the decision to take this course rather than some other course. Hopefully, if the Government is looking at significant savings it would have looked also at the cost structure that it has managed to build into this Bill. In that regard, I think the Senate would be very interested to know whether or not those costs are in fact less than the savings. If so, I think we can ask ourselves, in lieu of the recent statement made by the Wran committee with regard to the graduate tax, whether the net savings will be returned for student assistance in any way. This might test the bona fides of the Government with regard to the propositions that have been made in the Wran report; for example, whether any savings made in this area will be used to improve the very meagre stipend of the Commonwealth post-graduate award scheme.

The Austudy scheme is an age-related student assistance scheme and covers not only those students in higher education but students aged 16 years and over. It is one item that seems to have escaped the debate since the Wran committee report was published. Presumably the argument which applies to higher education in the Wran report also applies to all the non-compulsory years in secondary school. That was conveniently fudged, as was the technical and further education matter, by suggesting that those hard decisions would be put off to another time. I suggest that there is no philosophical, financial or any other basis upon which we could exclude the non-compulsory secondary school years. Presumably people get an advantage out of those and it seems to be the sole basis upon which the Government is likely to make any decision about whether or not it goes ahead with that scheme.

Austudy replaced the previous assistance scheme. I think that it is pertinent to the general debate that is going on in the community at the moment that we look a little more closely at this whole financial package of support for students. In 1988 a dependent student will get maximum assistance when the adjusted family income is $16,000 or less. This limit was increased from that in 1987, of $15,745, by less than would match inflation. The figure of $16,000 in weekly terms represents 64 per cent of adult average weekly full time earnings-I think that that is an important figure to remember; the December quarter Australian Bureau of Statistics figures were used in this instance-whereas it was at a comparable level to the average weekly earnings when the predecessor scheme was first introduced in 1974. That particular proposition is somewhat difficult to come by from the statistics, but a very interesting and authoritative review of that was undertaken when the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission was undertaking its review of efficiency and effectiveness in higher education, and that is its estimate. That is a very important item which has been missed from the current debate in the community about whether or not students on lower incomes are able to partake of higher education.

Somehow or other people seem to have assumed that it is only the fee that is of any importance in this area. In assuming that, they have missed the two major determinants of entrance of people from lower socioeconomic groups into higher education-firstly, the educational benefits that those children are able to receive in primary and secondary schooling; and, secondly, the financial support schemes that are available during higher education. After all, it is a far greater cost to live and house oneself while one is studying in higher education than it is to pay even the fees suggested in the Wran committee report.

If we look at the failure by governments in 1974 to increase the income limit at least to full indexation, we see that we are obviously faced with a decreasing ability of children from lower income groups to partake of higher education in an effective way. But it goes beyond that. Of course, the living allowance for dependent students is another area which is reduced as the family income increases. It is not payable if adjusted family income exceeds the following levels: if a 16- or 17-year-old student is living at home it is $26,000 in round terms; if a student is living away from home it is around $31,000. If the student is 18 years or over and is living at home that figure goes up to $28,000, and if the student is living away from home it is $34,000. The Senate should note that a lesser rate of reduction applies if the student has a brother or sister who is 16 years or over. The allowable family income then rises. If we consider that, together with the fact that the Government has under active consideration an assets test on Austudy, we are looking at a very difficult area for many students.

The area which has probably tended to be neglected in the debate is that of independent students. I refer to the May mini-statement of last year-of course, we are about to have a May mini-statement this year-and note what this Government has done to assist low income groups to partake of higher education. In 1978-79 the then Government took nearly $30m out of Austudy-on the Government's estimates for that year the figure was $27.6m. In 1988-89 it is projected that $59.2m will be taken out. The Government will take $60m from Austudy which is, in its terms, the money provided for low income groups to partake of higher education. This is the type of commitment that this Government has to assisting people from those groups in the community who have the talent and imagination to partake of higher education.

The Government has directly attacked the major area of support for low income groups and I believe it has done so in a most cynical way-by manipulating the criteria by which a person is able to get those particular allowances. It is interesting to note that in the period leading to the March 1983 election when the Labor Party was in opposition, the current Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), who was then the shadow Minister for education, so presumably we can put some credence on his word, said that the Liberal-National Party Government of Mr Fraser had `cynically manipulated' the criteria by which students were able to get assistance to higher education and that the incoming Labor Government would liberalise these to an enormous extent. Since 1983 we have had a continuous and continuing erosion of support for students through the Austudy scheme. At the moment it is far more difficult for a student to get the independent rate. Of course, that status is now granted if a student has reached or will reach the age of 25. This is presumably the only area left in our community where we consider a person to be still a child when he or she is 25. Everywhere else one is presumed to be an adult at 18 years of age, but in education we say, `No, they are children until they are 25 because the parents have to look after them and we are going to base the determination of their ability to undertake study on the income of their parents, despite the fact that they may be 25'.

What else has been used to erode student support? The Government has changed the criterion of the amount of work. Status is granted if the person has been employed in the work force for a period totalling three out of the previous four years. Until 1988 the period was two years. We now find that, by that type of operation, the Government, in its own terms, is able to save $60m which would otherwise have gone to students in lower socioeconomic groupings in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is enough to buy two F18s.

—Probably that is what it will be used for. One of the other arguments that have been touted around-it might be worth while mentioning it at this point-is the one that the Minister mentioned the day before the report of the Wran Committee on Higher Education Funding was released; that is, since fees have been taken off with a wave of the hand there has not been any change in terms of assistance to those groups in the community which are disadvantaged.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting that, since Susan Ryan has left, the Government's commitment to the advancement of women seems to have evaporated. When fees were taken off, the major educationally disadvantaged group in the community at that stage was women. Women comprised about a quarter of the tertiary education student body. This year, they comprise one half of that body. In other words, we have seen one of the major social changes of our times taking place because it is via higher education and entrance to the professions that the women of this community have been able to gain their rightful place.

Despite all the laws that we pass in this place, women's average incomes are less than those of men with comparable jobs. At least we have, by a series of policy mechanisms, enabled breakthroughs to be made in higher education, but we have not gone far enough. It is interesting that women in this community make up 6.6 per cent of enrolments in engineering in higher education and 66 per cent of enrolments in arts. In the higher education sector there is a massive disproportion with regard to the ability of women to partake of the types of educational advantages that they ought to be able to partake of on an equal status with men.

This Government and this Minister, with a wave of the hand the day before the Wran committee report was presented, dismissed an operation that had been going on for some time. I am not saying that this all came about as a result of the abolition of fees; that would be absolutely stupid. Obviously it came from a whole host of areas, not least of which were the very effective campaigns run by women to raise their status and to make the point to the males of this community that they were no longer willing to be treated as second class citizens.

It is undeniable that the removal of fees was a major advantage because, on the reimposition of the administration fee, in terms of the fine grain studies that were done at a number of institutions, we saw that the two groups that suffered were women and mature age students. Interestingly, women and mature age students were the two groups that suffered from the administration fee. Why was that? It is pretty easy to see that many mature age students were women, particularly single mothers who were trying to gain a variety of qualifications to support themselves and their families, which is something which I thought this Government would have supported. They found themselves, at the beginning of the academic year, having to fork out an amount which might seem piddling to us but which was very large in their budgets. They were unable to do so because they had to provide uniforms, school books and whatever else for their children. As women have been doing so often and for so long, they put the educational advantages of their children first. It might be a short-sighted policy, but it is one with which one cannot argue.

When fees are reimposed, we will find that women's access to higher education will be rolled back. The Government can wave its arms as much as it likes, but women's access to higher education will be rolled back. It is still the case in this community that when a family has to choose which member of the family should partake of higher education, because it cannot afford for each member to do so, those old traditional values will reassert themselves. Women again will be in the disadvantageous position in the family in which, on average, they have always been. Despite the fact that they might be the brightest members of their families, they will not get the chances. Until those particular social values are changed-and we are far from that at the moment-this move by the Government will disadvantage women greatly in an area in which, I think, great strides have been made, although, of course, when one looks at some of the other factors, for example, in terms of women's penetration of the higher levels of academia, one notes that we still have an awfully long way to go. I think that the arguments that have been put up can be dismissed. They can be dismissed on the basis of fact. They can be dismissed on the basis of any understanding of the types of forces which operate in our society to give some groups advantages over others.

I think another point that we have been trying to grapple with for quite some time is the interrelationship between the support we give to students and the support we give to unemployed people in our community. I imagine the Government will soon make an announcement, through some other report of course, that, since people who get unemployment benefits are being advantaged by them, they will have to pay those benefits back when they get employment as well! That announcement might be in the May mini-statement or the Budget. Presumably it would be based on exactly the same proposition and would relate also to those people who partake of the non-compulsory secondary education sector. People who use roads will probably also have to pay. I imagine that the Government will turn all roads into tollways!

The difficulty with the comparison between the education allowance and the unemployment benefit is that, in spite of the fact that in 1983 the then shadow spokesperson for education for the Labor Party Opposition, who is now the Minister, said that these would be brought together in this Government's first Budget, we are now, in 1988, five years on, still grappling with the problem. The Government has eliminated only part of the disincentive. This year for 16- and 17-year-olds the at-home secondary rate has risen from $40 to $50 a week to align it with the maximum job search allowance. I should say that the allowances for those unemployed in that period have been reduced. That is how the two amounts have come together. Of course, the standard job search allowance in the May economic statement of last year was $25. As for students aged 18 to 21 years, the maximum rate for tertiary students living away from home has risen from $80 a week to $91.20 to align it with the intermediate unemployment rates. However, the at-home rate for students aged 18 to 21 years, while increasing to $60 a week from $55 a week for tertiary students and $45 for secondary students, is still less than the unemployment benefit.

I think it can be argued further that the benefits under the Austudy scheme and unemployment benefits continue to be misaligned because, while Austudy is means tested on parental income-as I pointed out before when I cited the example of 25-year-olds being considered children-unemployment benefits are not means tested. Unemployment benefits for people aged 18 years and over are not dependent on parental income. Therefore, there is a major disparity between those two support mechanisms. Again, it is a disparity which tells against lower socioeconomic groups. While some students will get the maximum Austudy, which is the same that they would get if they were in receipt of unemployment benefits, I believe that we will find that many potential students would still find unemployment benefits offering a greater amount than they could receive under Austudy. Of course, not only the 18-year-olds but also the over 21-year-olds are in that bracket.

I have already mentioned the support schemes of Austudy, which are rehearsed again in this Bill. The original intent of the support schemes was directed quite specifically at assisting those whose parents were not able to support them while they undertook higher education. The difficulty at the moment is that a combination of the reduced unemployment benefits, longer periods before unemployment benefits can be received and improvements in the education allowance have helped, in some way at least, to reduce youth unemployment. Certainly this is indicated in the latest Australian Bureau of Statistics figures. We have also seen an increased retention of this age group in school education and in technical and further education training. I say `retention'; I do not use the word `participation'. There is a difference which seemingly the Government has not yet woken up to; I hope it does soon. Any schoolteacher will explain the difference between retention and participation. It is fairly elementary, but the Government still does not accept it.

As far as higher education is concerned, putting aside for one moment the school education and training sector, Austudy, in its former guise of the tertiary education assistance scheme, along with the abolition of fees, has been criticised for not facilitating a broader socioeconomic mix. Recent studies have found that in certain areas the mix is not all that different from that which existed in 1974. I have suggested one element where it is different, and there are other elements, but it is remarkable that there has been any movement at all. When fees were abolished, again according to the Review of Efficiency and Effectiveness in Higher Education, over 70 per cent of students were receiving some government support compared with the current 40 per cent-70 per cent last time we had fees compared with 40 per cent now. So if we remove fees and then take away the major support mechanism-that is, the mechanism by which people live and clothe and house themselves-fairly obviously we are not going to do terribly much about changing the socioeconomic mix.

The problem we will face is a problem faced by the United States. It is a problem that will bedevil the Government if it goes down the track proposed by the Wran committee report. The vast bulk of taxes in this country are paid by pay-as-you-earn (PAYE) taxpayers who are on basically middle class incomes. They already pay. The cry in the United States when it tried the Wran approach was that only the very poor and the very rich could afford higher education. The United States had to bring in support mechanisms for the middle classes so that everybody had support mechanisms. We will get back to that. Unfortunately it will take 10 or 15 years and we will have destroyed a couple of generations in the process.

The political realities are there. They are the political realities that the Australian Labor Party did not address in 1983. It went on a binge in relation to what it was going to do about private schools but reneged on its proposals when it got into government. Of course the 1983 policy would never be implemented by any government that felt pressure from the private sector, and it was not. In fact, while the Labor Party was meeting at one of its splendid conferences and actually putting through a resolution, the Government had to make a decision which went in exactly the opposite direction and entrenched funds for private schools at a level they had never had in the past. I do not know why the private schools sector is still upset with the Labor Government because it gave them something that the Fraser Government never did.

This Government was not willing to address the political issue in the context of 1983 and it is not willing to address that political issue now. That is, in time the PAYE taxpayers will revolt because they will be required not only to finance the entire system through their taxes, as they do now, but also to pay for their children. The poor, who do not pay taxes, will not be expected to pay and the very rich, who of course do not pay taxes, can afford to pay. The PAYE people will be the ones who will be hit twice, and they will revolt. If this Government is re-elected it will have to change back to a system which enables the children of the people who pay the taxes in this country to have reasonable access to higher education.

A number of other points could be made, particularly in regard to the pittance which was given to our higher degree students. The Government is not willing to face this matter. In 1959 the award was 85 per cent of the salary of a research assistant, 73 per cent of a university tutor's salary, and 64 per cent of a grade 1 research officer. The ratios remained more or less constant for about 15 years. Since that time, however, they have dropped markedly. In 1987 it was not 85 per cent but 40 per cent; it was not 73 per cent but 40 per cent, and it was not 64 per cent but 37 per cent-an incredible reduction in support given to those undertaking higher education. Whilst this Labor Government railed against the Fraser Government move to introduce fees on second higher degrees, it has been more damaging to the ability of people to undertake second and higher degrees. In gross terms we are putting out fewer than under the last Fraser Government. That is an extraordinary proposition to have to face.

This Government has perpetrated another of its con tricks on the community and expects to be able to get away with it. However, I do not believe that this time the education community will wear it. The students certainly will not wear it. Neither will those people who want a higher education be willing to wear it. Higher education is part of the solution to the economic problems that face this country. It is not part of the problem and should not be treated by this Government as such.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Despite the slightly strident tones of Senator Macklin, I do not intend to canvass all the issues that might be drawn out of a consideration of foreshadowed and green papered possibilities in the Government's overall contribution to the educational possibilities for Australians, particularly young Australians. It is important to note one or two matters which I believe have widespread community support and appreciation in this Government's approach to educational assistance, particularly for young people in our community.

SPEECH.PARA: For many years one of the matters which were of great concern in the community was the fact that unemployment benefits were higher than student assistance rates. This obviously acted as a disincentive to those students, their families and the households in which they lived, to consider undertaking some form of education and training, and acquisition of knowledge and skills, rather than taking the unemployment benefit. This was a very clear disproportion which acted in a way which undermined the possibilities of those young Australian to put themselves in a position where they might participate in the work force with the added educational qualification or skill. It is this Government which has moved to align the benefits for both student assistance and unemployment to a comparable amount of dollars, to remove that particular disincentive to participation in education. I believe that throughout the general community that has been extremely well received.

It is also important to note-without being as naive as Senator Macklin charged the Government with being-that it does not always follow that the mere fact that one remains at school means that one is really participating in some sort of educational process. The fact is that the retention rate of those students participating in years 11 and 12 in our secondary system has increased very dramatically. Over the period 1983 to 1988, roughly some five years, the retention rate to the final year of schooling, year 12, has increased from 40.6 per cent to 53.1 per cent, while the retention rate to year 11 has increased from 63.6 per cent to 71 per cent. I state those figures for the record to indicate that this Government's policies, including the aspect relating to student assistance, are providing more opportunities for youngsters to remain in the education system. Undoubtedly that has great merit and provides a sounder basis for the sorts of opportunities in which we wish to participate in years to come.

The Opposition has moved a second reading motion amendment which supports the amending Bill, whose main task is to give the Government more ability to combat fraud and to recover overpayments made under the scheme. The provisions in the Bill are comparable to those in the Social Security Act 1947. It requires individuals and organisations to provide information needed to verify entitlements and requires debtors to disclose their financial situation. It makes it an offence to give false information in relation to an application for assistance and so on. These are matters which the community would require any government to make provision for to ensure that the expenditures not of tens of millions but of hundreds of millions of dollars in well-merited support of students is not abused. In particular, there is a general reaction in the community against those who would fraudulently manipulate any system of government assistance because not only is it in an individual case an act which has criminal elements, but it creates an atmosphere in the community where those students who in this case are properly entitled to support will not have that general measure of community support. That is what will happen if the general community thinks these schemes are riddled with those who merely manipulate, use and abuse the process.

Therefore, there is an overall general reason for tackling the problem of fraud and combating it with measures which one hopes will act as a deterrent and which do not have to be invoked in many instances. It is improved detection and the structure of penalties provided which we believe will provide a deterrent value such that the provisions of this Bill will not need to be invoked in many cases. But it is essential that provision be made to combat fraud and to deal with people who fail to repay overpayments. The Opposition's second reading amendment is to the effect that:

the Senate condemns the Government for its disgraceful mismanagement of the Austudy scheme, causing distress and financial embarrassment to thousands of students and their families who have had to wait for lengthy periods before receiving their entitlements.

Although this amendment may have been well-conceived, or at least plausibly conceived, last year, it bears no relation to the operation of Austudy in 1988. It is true that in early 1987 delays arose because it was necessary to introduce a new processing scheme and the old computer system simply could not cope with it. We know that that was the case and there was much debate in this chamber about it, particularly during Question Time. I am informed that during 1987 the computer system problems which caused the delays were rectified. The result has been that the system has functioned smoothly for 1988. The vast majority of applications were processed within three weeks of receipt. That is better than the four to six weeks which Senator Patterson said was accepted by students as being realistic. Despite an increase in applications, 98 per cent of applications received so far this year have been processed compared with 62 per cent at the same time last year. We believe that the teething problems-and there were of course testing problems-with Austudy administration have been overcome. I do not believe that the Opposition's second reading amendment bears any relation to the facts as they have been experienced by many thousands of students in the course of this year.

The rate of successful appeals was referred to earlier in the debate. For the information of honourable senators, the rate of successful appeals to the student assistance review tribunals, is currently running at about 17 per cent. The Price Waterhouse report on fraud in the area of student assistance was also referred to in the debate. The report concluded that there was a need for improved deterrence and detection arising from the potential, rather than proven, level of fraud. Recommendations of the report, which included increased deterrence, more streamlined checking and automatic data processing system changes, are being acted on.

In that situation I believe that the general second reading amendment proposed by the Opposition ought to be rejected by the chamber because, as I said, I do not believe it bears any real relationship to the situation that we are currently aware of. I was told that in the earlier debates some particular instances were raised by Senator Patterson and Senator Vanstone. The Department has been asked to take up those matters. I think some letters may have been tabled or some particular instances were raised and the Department will certainly take them up.

On Senator Vanstone's general point that the powers would need to be used responsibly, I am advised that the provisions-of course, I would want to give this assurance to the Senate-will operate under strict guidelines and will be available only to designated officers. As I have come in as duty Minister, I am not sure whether Senator Macklin has foreshadowed his amendments on the penalties.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I have not.

—Then I will leave those to the committee stage. The Government believes that this Bill is timely and is drafted in a way which meets the concerns of the community and also that it will operate fairly and provide the Austudy financial assistance to students which they require in a way which will have the general support of the community. I believe this is very important if taxpayers' dollars are to be devoted to this very important purpose. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

That the amendment (Senator Vanstone's) be agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 8, clause 6, proposed paragraph 31h (a), line 21, leave out ``12 months'', insert ``1 month''.
(2) Page 9, clause 8, proposed paragraph 36 (c), line 15, leave out ``6 months'', insert ``2 weeks''.

The two amendments here are similar to those concerning a Bill debated on 25 March which dealt with penalties. At that time my colleague Senator Coulter moved amendments, basically the same as those I have moved here, that is, to bring back into some type of correspondence the penalty which is a monetary penalty and the penalty which is a financial penalty. The section we are referring to is that concerning a person who contravenes these various subsections and states:
is guilty of a summary offence punishable on conviction:
in the case of a natural person-by a fine not exceeding $2,000 or imprisonment for 12 months . . .

The point which my colleague put, and which I supported at the time and which had the support of the Opposition when Senator Lewis expressed very similar views, is that the Government had not in fact fulfilled an undertaking that it had made to the Senate some time ago, in fact when Senator Gareth Evans was Attorney-General, to undertake a comprehensive review of penalties in all Acts. Because of that, we had been waiting about four years for a result to come out of this particular inquiry, an interdepartmental committee or some other hole which it had gone down, and we were unwilling to wait any longer. The Opposition took exactly the same view. Indeed when Senator Lewis spoke he warned the Government that he would take a similar view with future Bills.

I think one of the advantages of moving these amendments and putting the Government on notice that we intend moving these amendments consistently to these Bills, is that we do require from the Government some type of response as to when its inquiry with regard to penalties is actually going to bear some fruit. I will put these two items together, the $2,000 fine and the 12 months imprisonment. We are talking about a student, or with regard to a corporation, a fine not exceeding $10,000. I believe if we use the average weekly wage as a benchmark, and take that as being the amount of a penalty for 12 months, rather than a fine of $2,000 and 12 months, we would come up with $2,000 and one month. They are the comparable penalties in terms of the type of income.

The Senate made these amendments to a previous Bill, and I think it did so on very good grounds, because of the Government's failure to address this issue in any serious and comprehensive way. Likewise, we believe that the period of six months should correspond with two weeks. It would be ironical indeed if the Senate, having reduced the penalties for non-compliance by companies operating in a particular area-that is, in the textile and footwear area-to get some comparability between fines and imprisonment, should not do so again in this area with regard to students. The reason I say it would be odd is that one could imagine that a company at least would have the possibility of finding the $2,000, or a business person who is not a company but who is operating a business might have a better ability of finding $2,000 than would a student. We could imagine that students, in committing an offence under this legislation, which is much more likely, given the types of stringent possibilities that we have seen coming out of the report of the Wran Committee on Higher Education Funding, than it was when this Bill originally hit the deck in the Senate a couple of weeks ago, could be very tempted to try to get round the provisions in this legislation. If they do so and cannot come up with the $2,000, they will face a penalty of up to 12 months imprisonment.

Senator Patterson has suggested they might be able to study while they are there. I am sure she meant that in jest. While I understand that these are maximum penalties, it seems to us that, when setting penalties in a Bill, we should try to make some fist of comparability. The Government promised to do this. It even foreshadowed that it might be looking at a comprehensive Bill in the regard to penalties at some stage when Senator Evans was the Attorney-General. But absolutely nothing has happened. It is not an excuse to say, as Senator Button said last time, `It is all right; these are the same penalties we used in other Acts'. We know that they are the same penalties as used in other Acts-and they are wrong. We have to get some rationality into this matter, and I am quite sure that the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), who is an eminent lawyer, is well able to comprehend the disparity between a maximum penalty of $2,000 in our society and a maximum penalty of 12 months imprisonment. The relationship is absolutely ludicrous. Yet if we in the Senate are in any way serious, I do not think we can allow legislation to continue to go through this place with this shoddy approach to penalties.

Penalties are an important part of the enforcement mechanism of any Act. The Australian Democrats support the inclusion of penalty clauses. It is sensible to do so. But we do not think that this means that the Government can merely wave its arm or pluck out of the air any old figure it likes. It has to come up with some basic principles upon which it will set down penalties in the Act-and referring to other outmoded, outdated and wrongly drafted Acts is not the way to do it. I hope that the Government will accept this and as soon as possible will follow through with the promise made to the Senate over four years ago and come up with some comprehensive action with regard to penalties across the board. not only in these types of Acts but in all Acts that go through this Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition will not support the Australian Democrats' amendments. It should be clear from Senator Macklin's speech that the Democrats deserve at least some explanation of that position. We are concerned about the disparity between fines set in legislation as maximums and the equivalent gaol term. It is true, as Senator Macklin has pointed out, that in many cases the maximum gaol sentence, if converted to loss of income on average weekly earnings terms, represents a far greater loss of income than the maximum fine represents. Conversely, the maximum fine divided by average weekly earnings represents a loss of income for a period of weeks far below the maximum option for weeks in gaol.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Macklin has pointed out, this disparity has occasioned us on a previous matter to support a similar amendment. That matter related to the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority. In that matter we agreed that the gaol term should reflect the fine as represented by a loss of average weekly earnings time. The Democrats will no doubt claim that we ought to support their amendment on this occasion on the ground of consistency. They would say, `Having supported us at that stage, why not tonight?'. Of course, what we have to remember, however, is that this Bill needs to be seen as part of a whole scheme relating to the clamping down on fraud against the Commonwealth in social security areas and Austudy. There is a very strong case for the Parliament maintaining consistency in the different pieces of legislation which seek to improve the integrity of systems that are designed to distribute taxpayers' funds, of which social security and Austudy are just two very prominent examples.

I have listened to what Senator Macklin has had to say tonight. He has indicated that it might well be the responsibility of other people to come up with a comprehensive package of reforms in this area. Perhaps the Australian Democrats may care to take it upon themselves to look at all the pieces of legislation, of which this piece is just a part, and to put forward a coherent package of reforms, rather than simply pick off the pieces of legislation as they are considered. There is no dispute about the disparity to which Senator Macklin referred. That disparity quite obviously is there. One would not want to waste time in trying to argue that it was not. Perhaps it is inappropriate for us to address that disparity on an `as it comes before us' basis and a more considered approach is required. Certainly, as this legislation is part of a package dealing with fraud against the Commonwealth in the delivery of taxpayers' funds, there is an argument for maintaining consistency within that package.

In presenting such a package of reform the Democrats may well care to address the need for the two options presented in regard to options for sentencing-that is, gaol and/or fine-to be the same if converted to an average weekly earnings base formula. There are, of course, some who would say that when there is an option for sentencing in terms of gaol or a fine, the two are not meant to be equated, that when one has the option of one, the other or both, they are never meant to be looked at as being the same but are there simply to provide the judge with a range of options that will enable him or her to come up with a sentencing package that fits the alleged offence. So it may be that there are examples outside the sphere of those to which the Democrats have turned their minds thus far where it is appropriate for the judge to have a range of sentencing options covering fines and prison penalties, where each is not meant to reflect the other in average weekly earnings terms but is meant simply to provide the judge with an option of a mix. We have settled our minds on this matter, and I would be interested at some later stage to hear what the Democrats have to say about the argument that it is perhaps too simplistic to put the two options together and say that the fine ought always to be the same as the gaol term when one reduces them to an average weekly earnings basis.

When the Democrats put forward such a comprehensive package, they might also address the flexibility of judges to select the sentence that is appropriate for the offence committed. It is not the case, as one might think from the arguments we have heard tonight and on other occasions, that a judge will regard the maximum gaol term as being equivalent to the maximum fine. That seems to imply that judges have no capacity to distinguish between the two and why the two are offered. The Democrats might also address the question-no argument has been presented tonight in this regard-as to how one achieves the balance, if one believes that the gaol sentence and the fine ought to equate in average weekly earnings terms. One can put one up or bring the other down in order to achieve a balance and the answer may not be the same in all cases.

The coalition acknowledges the point that the Democrats raise that there is an extraordinary inconsistency on an average weekly earnings basis between goal terms and maximum fines. While we understand that on the basis of consistency they would want us to support them this time as we have before, in order to keep a consistent approach through the range of Bills that deal with matters of this sort we will not be supporting them tonight. However, we look forward to them, if they so choose, or perhaps the Government, addressing this matter in a comprehensive fashion rather than just taking this aspect of each piece of legislation as it comes forward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Opposition for indicating its support for the range of penalties provided in this legislation. In response to Senator Macklin's amendments, I simply say that there is a lot of merit in what Senator Vanstone put to us about the usual pattern of penalty provisions in our system whereby we give to a judge as much flexibility as possible to deal with the tremendous variety of factual situations with which he can be confronted and the mitigating circumstances which might be taken properly into consideration.

SPEECH.PARA: I agree with Senator Vanstone's statement that it is not simple to try to find some real correlation between a maximum penalty by way of a fine provided for in a particular provision and a maximum penalty provided by way of a term of imprisonment. These penalties are not set in legislation in order to be strictly comparable but to provide a range within which a judge can make a selection. It may well be that for a particular individual, and indeed for deterrent value quite apart from the circumstances of a particular case, a one-week term of imprisonment might in a particular instance have a much greater impact on the individual and on society than a maximum $5,000 fine. In such a case there is no relationship between the monetary penalty that might be imposed and a term of imprisonment. Lots of factors must be taken into consideration by a sentencing judge or magistrate and this legislation provides that possibility by setting maximums.

I think it is important to note that these provisions are consistent with government policy that has been accepted hitherto by the Parliament. As I understand it, the penalties that have been chosen are the same as the maximum penalties for similar offences under the Social Security Act. I believe that when one is dealing generally with income maintenance legislation, whether it be in the area of Austudy or social security benefits, some consistency and a common approach would seem to be sensible.

I also note-and by coincidence this has been made available to me-that clause 11 of the Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill 1987, which is now an Act, contained the following provision which was accepted:

Where a natural person is convicted of an offence against a law of the Commonwealth punishable by imprisonment only, the court may, if the contrary intention does not appear and the court thinks a pecuniary penalty appropriate in all the circumstances of the case, impose, instead of a penalty or imprisonment, a pecuniary penalty not exceeding:
Various categories are then given, one of which is:
where the offence is punishable by imprisonment for a period exceeding six months but not exceeding 12 months-$2,000;

So there seems to be an acceptance by the Parliament, including this chamber last year, that that sort of proportion in maximum penalties was about right. But in making that statement, one would also be willing to admit that this is not an area in which it is very easy to find the correct comparabilities. Senator Macklin, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, has plucked average weekly earnings out of the air for consideration. That sort of proposition may not be appropriate. I am advised by Senator Maguire, for example, that in South Australia the idea of average weekly earnings on an Australia-wide basis has not really much applicability of the real average earnings of the great mass of the working community-wage earners and lower salary earners-in the South Australian community.

To take average weekly earnings, which are truly an average of all wages and salaries throughout the community, including those of the very high salary earners, is perhaps to come up with a figure which does not bear a lot of real relation to the average income, let alone disposable income, that is available for most persons in our community. On that point, it would probably be a more real penalty to devise some system of multiples of after tax earnings, real disposable income. But, of course, it would raise very large administrative and other difficulties in ascertaining that.

Nevertheless, the point about trying to find some proper sentencing principle in this area is an important one. Honourable senators will be aware that a review of Commonwealth criminal law, under the chairmanship of a former Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia, Sir Harry Gibbs, is being conducted. As I understand it, it is hoped that the reports on this matter, including the appropriateness of various penalties, will be available during this year. That will provide a well-considered basis for a more general review by this chamber of the structure of penalties under Commonwealth legislation. But we believe that what is being put down in this legislation is consistent with the Crimes Legislation Amendment Act 1987 and with social security legislation already in place. For that reason, I commend to the Senate those provisions in the Bill as it stands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

It is a serious amount and a serious length of time. I believe that some comparability at least between the individual and the corporation is needed. The comparabilities of the maximum fines applicable to individuals and the maximum fines applicable to corporations and how to deal with them first arose about four years ago. Senator Vanstone suggested that we come up with some type of overall scheme--

TALK.START.PARA: —Or the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that what Senator Patterson has said about some of the exigencies and causes which might motivate a person to commit a fraud sound plausible in some instances, but that does not in any way counter the necessity for this Parliament-and for this Government to bring measures into the Parliament-to ensure that the moneys which are, after all, moneys derived from exactions imposed on ordinary Australians in the community should be spent according to the strict tenor of the provision made for the expenditure of those moneys. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Social Security Amendment Bill 1988 which will amend the Social Security Act 1947. A wide range of matters are covered by this Bill. I note from the second reading speech of the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, that the Government believes that `over the last two years this Labor Government has embarked on a program of major improvements in the quality of administration and decision making in the social security portfolio'. The Government alleges that the program has dual objectives-and admirable ones they are-firstly, to ensure that every Australian resident obtains adequate income support as and when it is needed; and secondly, to protect the revenue, in other words, taxpayers' funds, by ensuring that payments are not directed to those who do not require them. In dealing with the Government's approach, the Minister for Justice said in the second reading speech:

SPEECH.PARA: We have done this through close attention to the detail of the administration of each program to maximise the accuracy of social security decision-making.

It is odd that the Government makes that statement early in the text of the second reading speech on a Bill which deals, at least in some part, with anomalies not picked up at the time of the initial legislative change. I suppose that we are left in a position of saying `Better late than never', but certainly the number of anomalies picked up in this Bill is no indication that the comment made by Professor Gruen in trying to give some priority to the attention to detail paid by this Government is in any way realistic.

I turn to some of the detail in the Bill. The Government seeks to make a change with respect to the manner in which certain compensation payments will be treated. This is an important change and requires that in future where compensation settlements are made those people who up to the date of settlement have been claiming either sickness or unemployment benefits will have to pay back the sum total of those benefits. For the purposes of the Act 50 per cent of lump sum settlements will be taken as being the result of economic loss. There is some concern over this move, and the Opposition intends to monitor closely the implementation of this aspect to ensure that it does not turn into a way which allows certain people to be unfairly treated as a result of this amendment.

The Bill also deals with West German restitution payments and seeks to clarify those payments. It is interesting to look at a Press release issued by the Minister for Social Security, Mr Howe, on 30 November 1987 entitled `Restitution payments for Nazi victims'. The first paragraph of that statement reads:

The Minister for Social Security, Brian Howe, said today that the Social Security Act would be amended to clarify the way social security income tests are applied to restitution paid by the German Government to people who were persecuted by the Hitler regime.

It goes on to point out that this statement is made as a consequence of a meeting held with the Executive Vice-President of the Federation of Australian Jewish Welfare Societies, Mr Walter Lippmann. The release continues:
In 1985 Mr Howe announced that German restitution payments for loss of income are taken into account under pension income tests, and that all other restitution payments would be disregarded.

Mr Howe went on to give further details. But the point I raise is that his Press release of 30 November 1987 indicated that the Government intended to clear up the ambiguity that existed with respect to restitution paid by the German Government to people who were persecuted by the Hitler regime. The coalition says that this Bill, which is an attempt to put into effect the Minister's announcement of 30 November 1987, is unsatisfactory. This is a matter of concern to us, and most certainly to the Jewish community in Australia. I am sure that my colleague Senator Peter Baume, who will speak immediately after me, will be able to amplify these matters further. It is important to note that the Government indicated that it was going to clear up an ambiguity and that its moves were to be made after consultation. The coalition still believes that consultation has been inadequate to come to that conclusion because certainly the legislation is inadequate to deal with the matter outlined by the Minister.

To put the matter in perspective for those people who until now have not taken an interest in these matters I shall give some of the background. The restitution payments we are referring to are provided by the West German Government to, as I understand it, approximately 1,000 people living in Australia who suffered under the nazi regime. They receive the payments as a consequence of their being in concentration camps or elsewhere, but one way or the other they suffered as a consequence of the monstrous administration in Germany at the time. Following the war they migrated to Australia. Perhaps it puts the matter in some perspective to indicate that the size of the payment depends on an individual's war history and suffering but that the general range is between $100 and $300 a month.

Within the general outline of those payments there are two particular matters that we wish to raise. Firstly, those who are receiving compensation payments are, as I understand it, assessed on a percentage basis for loss of health, and a component of that may be described nominally as a loss of earning capacity. I further understand that the Government's amendment could be interpreted in such a way as to have the entire restitution payment described as income. Of course, that would have substantial consequences for the recipient of that payment in terms of social security benefits provided by this Government.

The second point I wish to raise, in terms of the inadequacy of consultation, deals with people affected by the rules that I understand as the Reichversicherung rules. These people were working in Germany between 1933 and 1939 and during that time they would have paid superannuation contributions from their salaries. As a result of the nazi restitution laws of 1949 some of those people are eligible for entitlements because of the income losses they clearly suffered. Despite the Government's proposed amendment, these payments could still be interpreted as income. This is the point that the coalition seeks to address; namely, that income is not defined and should be. I foreshadow at this time that during the committee stage of this Bill we will move:
Page 2, paragraph 3 (a), lines 21 and 22, leave out ``(other than an amount expressed to be paid for lost income)'', insert ``(other than an amount expressly to be paid for lost wages or salary)''.

The coalition believes that this amendment will in some way clarify the ambiguity that we see as still being there and the ambiguity that the Minister's statement in November 1987 indicated would be resolved. The Bill covers a number of other matters with respect to the family allowance supplement and some other matters but I turn at this stage to the second reading amendment circulated in the name of the coalition. I move:
At end of motion, add `, but the Senate deplores the fact that:
(a) the Hawke Government's economic and social policies continue to cause a fall in living standards for Australian families, and
(b) the Prime Minister has refused to meet his 1987 election pledge that by 1990 no Australian child will be living in poverty.'

In March 1983 the average family had a further $42 a week as disposable income. One does not need to spell that out in terms of loaves of bread, pounds of butter, or whatever. I am sure that we all understand what a further $42 a week in disposable income means to an average family.

TALK.START.PARA: —Four bottles of red for you.

—The Minister indicates that it will be four bottles of red. He obviously drinks more expensive bottles of wine than I do. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) says, following the election disasters that this Government has faced-namely, in Adelaide, Port Adelaide, Victoria, Western Australia, New South Wales and Queensland-that there is nothing wrong with the Government's policies, that all the Government has is a marketing problem. I recall raising in this chamber with Senator Reynolds the matter of whether the Government had lost touch in terms of its economic and social policies because they were continuing to cause a fall in the living standards of Australians. Senator Reynolds denied that the Government was out of touch with needy Australians. I recall further reminding her that the Caucus has now insisted-I think the Press release says `called for', but nonetheless it has insisted-on social justice impact statements from each Minister accompanying any proposal. I recall Minister Reynolds still denying that that was any indication that the Government was out of touch and refusing to acknowledge that it was an indication from Caucus that that is what Caucus believed.

SPEECH.PARA: Minister Reynolds advised the Senate that the Office of the Status of Women was advising the Cabinet on these matters as they related to women. She denied that the Caucus call for social justice impact statements was any reflection on the adequacy of advice being offered by the Office of the Status of Women, saying that it was simply an extension of that sort of advice to the whole population rather than to women in particular.

It seems to me that if legislation is to be fair to low income and disadvantaged women then, presumably, at the same time it is going to be fair to low income and disadvantaged men. It is only in very limited circumstances that if the interests of women were catered for the interests of men would not be catered for. Minister Reynolds obviously has the idea that status of women matters can always be separated and dealt with in isolation.

However, the new Federal President of the Labor Party, Premier Bannon from my State, has said that this Government is quite clearly out of touch. That is the point of the second reading amendment which has been moved by the coalition. Whilst it does not say that the Government is out of touch, surely the words indicate that, irrespective of the public relations machine the Government has put forward, the economic and social policies of this Government are continuing to cause a fall in living standards for Australian families and that the Prime Minister has thus far failed and, although he has not had very long, he will fail, to meet his pledge that by 1990 no Australian child will be living in poverty.

A further example is the housing problem today. This is the Government that, due to some ideological binge, chose to remove negative gearing and denied that it was having any substantial effect on renters, particularly renters in New South Wales. The Government continued to deny that its actions were having any such effect right up until the pending New South Wales election when something had to be done, at which time it was forced to renege, do a gigantic about-face and go back to where we said it should have been all along. It not only made moves like that. One could look at perhaps more concrete indicators of how the Government's policies are causing a fall in living standards. One could look to the ever-increasing number of people waiting for public housing in this country or, if one wanted to turn away from statistics and look to more realistic matters, one could look at the growing numbers of families living in caravans, whose kids would have no idea what it is like to go home and sit by the fire, because one does not generally have a fire in a caravan.

Let me deal not in great detail with but at least make some reference to part (b) of the coalition's second reading amendment dealing with the pledge of the Prime Minister that Australian children will not be living in poverty in 1990. It seems clear that the Prime Minister's much publicised claim that no Australian children will be living in poverty by 1990 is not much more than that. He seems to have, and I assume that his views are a reflection of the Government's views, a blind belief that poverty is simply a function of the almighty dollar. He does not seem to understand that poverty is far more than that. It is a function of the lack of options or understanding of the options that are available to one. The eradication of poverty is not to be achieved by throwing taxpayers' money at people who are living below an income line that is deemed to indicate they are in poverty. The eradication of poverty will be achieved through a range of social policies that produce a more equitable society, one in which people understand what their options are and are in a position to take advantage of those options on behalf of themselves and their families. The sorts of options I am talking about, to name just two, are education and employment. If a family does not understand what options are available to themselves and more particularly to their children in terms of education, that family will continue to live on a very low income or in poverty stricken circumstances. If the family does not understand what employment and training options there are, or if there are inadequate training options, it will continue to live in poverty. For the Prime Minister to indicate that he can fix this in such a short space of time indicates a clear lack of understanding on his part as to the nature of poverty in Australia. Poverty, as I have said, is far more than simply a lack of income and cannot be removed by increasing social welfare benefits for those who are perceived to be in poverty stricken circumstances.

Members of this Government crow incessantly about the family allowance supplement. I want to say a number of things about that. Firstly, it was extraordinarily late in coming. This Government got into office in 1983. It is now 1988 and this is the first move made by this Government to address the problem of families in all that time. The Government is silent on its record until this time. (Quorum formed)

Prior to the quorum being called I was referring to the crowing that this Government does on its own behalf in relation to the FAS scheme. I indicated that this measure was really the first substantial thing that this Government had done with respect to families. I would not wish to exclude from that the much approved changes made to maintenance collection, which came about with the support of the coalition. Of course, I cannot mention those initiatives without mentioning that Senator Durack on our behalf put forward a number of amendments, which the Government has now accepted but which when Senator Durack put them forward originally it consistently refused to accept.

TALK.START.PARA: —He dealt with only one aspect of it.

—The point has been made that Senator Durack's Bills dealt with only a limited aspect of the wider range of matters which, I accept, are dealt with by the child maintenance collection legislation. That is quite true. But that interjection is evidence of what seems to be a pretty heartless situation, that if one is intending at a particular time to deal with only the problems faced by a limited group, that limited group can, as far as this Government is concerned, just wait. Basically it can just go jump over the fence until this Government is prepared to put a package of legislation forward and incorporate those amendments in that package and seek the electoral glory, such as it is, for itself.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the interjection put forward by one of my colleagues opposite indicates just the view that the coalition is seeking to point out. It is typical of the attitude of this Government that everything can wait; people in need can wait. The number of people who missed out on the benefit of Senator Durack's amendment while the Government was considering getting its act together I would not like to calculate and present the Government with. But that is typical of its attitude. These people can just wait until the Government has got it all together and then they can accept its particular amendments. It is a shameful situation that the Government chose to take that path, but nonetheless it did.

The other point I would like to speak on in relation to this particular scheme is that it covers only a limited proportion of families. The Government would do well not to crow about how wonderful this scheme is and say what a wonderful job it does for families when there is such a limited proportion of families that it in fact helps. In support of the second reading amendment that we have moved about the falling living standards of Australian families, let me refer honourable senators opposite to an interview given by Senator Crowley in Adelaide several weeks ago. She acknowledged, in fact, the inadequacy of the systems put forward by the Government. I noticed some quiet overtaking honourable senators opposite, probably because they have not heard the interview, but they would do well to listen to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon a matter of public importance was submitted to the Senate for discussion. It dealt with the Government's failure to address the question of trade union abuse of power. In my address to the Senate this evening I will not only endorse the terms of that matter of public importance but also add that the reason that the Government has failed to stop the abuse of union power is that it has refused to stand up to union officials. It is the so-called union officials who have been responsible for the abuse of power and authority and, indeed, abuse of the laws of the land.

SPEECH.PARA: The people of the heavily industrialised area of the Latrobe Valley, the area in which I was born and raised and in which I have an electorate office, have far too often been subject to this abuse and intimidation of their basic rights as rank and file members. The abuse and intimidation inevitably have come from a small but influential section of union officialdom in the Latrobe Valley. Nobody who lives in the Latrobe Valley will forget or forgive the 1977 power dispute. Mr John Halfpenny led his union in a most bitter, worthless and unnecessary dispute that adversely affected not only the families of Latrobe Valley but most Victorians. The union leadership in this dispute was bereft of reason, compassion, wisdom or common sense. It is no wonder that my office gets a great many representations from rank and file unionists about union abuse. It is no wonder that I receive a great many representations because this area of Latrobe Valley is represented at both State and Federal levels by Labor parliamentarians. Now that another viewpoint is represented in the Latrobe Valley, there will be stronger representation of the rank and file. The Australian Labor Party (ALP) has failed to deliver the voice of the Latrobe Valley rank and file.

To this end the recent gun laws debate and subsequent State legislation became a strong test case for the rank and file in the Latrobe Valley. In this case the rank and file's anti-gun laws legislation stance was being ignored by union officials at branch meetings. The dissatisfied unions were able to organise both a rank and file committee and a petition not only stating their opposition to the gun laws but also requesting that the union officials make their views known or they would withdraw their union dues. I say quite openly that my office and my services were given to this rank and file committee.

The result was a backdown by the union officials, a spate of visits by State Ministers to the area to meet the rank and file committee and, of course, the inevitable awakening of State and Federal Labor parliamentarians to the rank and file cause. Clearly, what was happening was that the union officials were not doing their job of representing the rank and file. They were far more concerned with protecting the troubled State Government's gun laws. Clearly, their loyalties were with the ALP and not with the workers. The result proved that the rank and file, when organised, are the most effective and responsible force for controlling irresponsible union officials.

Another case of union officials misusing the power of their office has been brought to my attention. The Senate would recall the Queensland power dispute in 1985 and the effect that that dispute had not only on the people of Queensland but also on industrial relations in this country. During the long drawn-out Queensland power dispute the Victorian Electrical Trades Union in the Latrobe Valley imposed a $5 a week levy on Latrobe Valley workers. The levy was meant to have been sent to support the striking workers in Queensland. One wonders whether all or any of the money ever reached the families of the striking Queensland workers, particularly if one takes into account the 1977 distress fund collection of $160,000 by the Latrobe Valley unions which was never distributed.

Further to this, one Mr John McNamara led many in bucking the union officials' move to impose this levy by not paying the prescribed levy and eventually having that levy removed. Since that time the ETU has led a vendetta against Mr McNamara by black-banning him from his work site. This vendetta has now been taken to the most bitter level. Of late the ETU has been threatening Mr McNamara with legal action to collect unpaid unions dues from the time the ETU black-banned him in May 1985.

The ETU's actions in this whole affair have been to deny Mr McNamara basic work rights. For a union to force one of its members from his job and then insist that he pay dues shows that the ETU officials have contempt for the rights of the ordinary worker, for the rank and file. The ETU's action to force payment of union dues again raises the very serious question of compulsory unionism versus freedom of association in this country. Mr McNamara is not going to be left to be hung, drawn and quartered. He has my full support and will be given the support of my office. Mr McNamara has sought legal defence against the ETU demands. Clearly this vendetta by the ETU officials must be fought.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to refer to a matter that is of importance in the Australian Capital Territory. I refer to an article which appeared in the Valley View of 4 May in an article called `Kelly's Corner' by the honourable member for Canberra. The article, which is headed `Bad luck, Canberra!', states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition's confusion over media ownership does not matter much.
But the effect on Canberra, and of other regional areas, of their eventual decision to block the Government's extension of audience reach from 60 per cent to 75 per cent does matter.

Senator Evans, the Minister for Transport and Communications, has indicated that aggregation of Canberra, Wollongong and Orange into one area could have moved forward to early 1988 under the 75 per cent rule.
That would have meant two more commercial stations for us to watch. That would have given us a much greater choice of sport, of movies, and of current affairs.
Thanks to the Opposition, that is now off, for at least a year.
It will be late 1989 at the earliest that aggregation can happen.

I find it very interesting that the article suggests that it will be late 1989 at the earliest before aggregation can happen. As I understood the legislation, this was to occur by the end of 1989. In fact, many of these stations are prepared and anxious to proceed with aggregation before that time. As far as WIN4 and Orange, the two stations which will be coming into Canberra, are concerned, I understand that they wish to proceed at the beginning of 1989. I do not think there is any doubt that they wish to commence at the beginning of 1989.

The Government is clearly trying to foster confusion in the community. Perhaps it is doing so to harm us. Perhaps it is a smokescreen for what it is intending to do in this area. I think it is time that the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) gave us a few answers. When does he intend to present the Government's timetable for commencing television aggregation? Will he be requiring all television licensees in the respective approved markets to aggregate simultaneously, which because of different capital requirements, incidentally, is not supported by most regional television operators? If this is the case, is it true that this will have the effect of delaying the introduction of additional commercial television services to some regional viewers?

Given that some regional television operators have expressed a desire to aggregate a lot sooner than the Government's proposed timetable-that is, early 1989, not late 1989, based on the 60 per cent audience reach-does it indicate that the quite outrageous claim of the Minister of Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) in this article that such a limit will delay the commencement of the aggregation process is totally false and should be seen for what it really is, that is, some sort of political smokescreen? I believe that we are entitled to know. It is perfectly clear to anybody that under the present legislation, with the intention of those stations which have said that they wish to aggregate, the two stations which intend coming to Canberra can do so early in 1989. If there is to be any delay it can only come, not from anything that the Opposition has said or done, but from a decision of the Government which is yet to be announced. I say to the Minister for Transport and Communications that it is time he gave an honest answer to the Senate and to the people of the Australian Capital Territory as to his or the Government's intentions.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
